I had known very little of Sylvia Plath but ever since last year, my friend Amna Hussain (damn goodreads for not having the friends tagging option. THANK YOU AMNA!!!) started sending me excerpts from her journals I’m looking her up. I started reading her only novel The Bell Jar but somehow couldn’t read past the very first chapter, not that it wasn’t catchy and interesting but reading about mental illness when you yourself aren’t feeling quite well isn’t a perfect match. Anyway, this year I started pilling up books on mental illness in my TBR list and The Bell Jar was the first one I added but didn’t pick it up until now. And once that I picked it up, I just couldn’t put it down. It took me three days to read it but I think I still have missed parts of it and I need to re-read it. No, I’ve read every word in it but it’s like you know when you read something and it feels so surreal, so ethereal that you want to read it again and again till it feels normal? Although I doubt I’ll feel anything but normal after reading this book.“To the person in the bell jar, blank and stopped as a dead baby, the world itself is the bad dream.”The Bell Jar is Plath’s own story. Most of it. She wrote it as her semi-autobiography from her being a literary prodigy to her descending into mental illness to the point where she was hospitalized and getting electro-shocked. And it’s not your everyday novel where the patient with mental illness magically gets better and lives happily ever after. I’m not saying that mental illness is incurable and I’m proud that so many people who are battling and defeating it. But some books and movies out there have made it look quite easy. Not our Sylvia Plath though. She writes like her pain ooze out of her and she put it on paper. It feels so real, more than real. Maybe it’s because she wasn’t making it up and she felt everything she ever wrote. I literally got shivers at scenes like the one where she stood on the roof of her hotel and flung her clothes into the darkness till she’s left with nothing but a bathrobe, when she slashed her ankle with a razor and when she went to the cellar and took those sleeping pills. I just can’t wrap my head around it.It isn’t possible for me to grasp her emotions, her misery, and helplessness as she writes:“I felt very still and very empty, the way the eye of a tornado must feel, moving dully along in the middle of the surrounding hullabaloo”“The silence depressed me. It wasn’t the silence of silence. It was my own silence.” Often she writes phrases that’d hurt your heart for her and you’d feel so much love for her, she writes like; “...to a true-blue gal who promised she would wait-- She’s the sunflower of the Sunflower State.”Her emotional state was so fragile yet she wrote novel, journals and poetry like none other could do. She loved writing, she loved reading and it broke her when she couldn’t do it anymore. God, there’s so much pain in her words that is beyond our imagination. And I just can’t shake her words out of my head. I can read her words all day and still can’t get enough. As she herself writes:“everything I had ever read about mad people stuck in my mind, while everything elseflew out.”She writes about what she was going through like, “… I told him I believed in hell, and that certain people, like me, had to live in hell before they died, to make up for missing out on it after death, since they didn’t believe in life after death, and what each person believed happened to him when he died.” “I thought how strange it had never occurred to me before that I was only purely happy until I was nine years old.”Here are some other excerpts from the book: “There must be quite a few things a hot bath won’t cure, but I don’t know many of them. Whenever I’m sad I’m going to die, or so nervous I can’t sleep, or in love with somebody I won’t be seeing for a week, I slump down just so far and then I say: “I’ll go take a hot bath.” “I saw myself sitting in the crotch of this fig tree, starving to death, just because I couldn’t make up my mind which of the figs I would choose. I wanted each and every one of them, but choosing one meant losing all the rest, and, as I sat there, unable to decide, the figs began to wrinkle and go black, and, one by one, they plopped to the ground at my feet.” “If neurotic is wanting two mutually exclusive things at one and the same time, then I’m neurotic as hell. I’ll be flying back and forth between one mutually exclusive thing and another for the rest of my days.” “The trouble was, I hated the idea of serving men in any way” “A summer calm laid its soothing hand over everything, like death.”“I took a deep breath and listened to the old brag of my heart. I am, I am, I am.”“If neurotic is wanting two mutually exclusive things at one and the same time, then I’m neurotic as hell. I’ll be flying back and forth between one mutually exclusive thing and another for the rest of my days” There is so much more I want to write about this book but my emotions aren’t at the right place and I don’t think I’ll write the right words. I just feel so much for Sylvia Plath. Her life, her works, her suicide, everything at the moment is so overwhelming. I’ll just cry now.

The Bell Jar wasn’t required reading in high school, but I believe I picked it up the summer before I went to college. I haven’t read it all the way through since, although I’ve looked at specific passages again over the years. The book tells the story of college student Esther Greenwood’s mental breakdown and recovery one summer. It’s inspired by the author’s own summer of 1953, in which she and 19 other college students worked as guest editors (all expenses paid!) at Mademoiselle magazine. After returning to her modest New England home from the whirlwind, chaotic experience, Plath fell into a depression, attempted suicide and then went to a series of mental institutions before recovering and returning to school for the second semester of her final year at Smith. Years later, of course, she would write the poems that would secure her posthumous immortality.Plath’s life, work and mystique continue to fascinate generations of new readers.What do I remember from that first reading?• The dark, sardonic humour.• The vivid poetic imagery (it’s clear Plath was a poet first, a novelist second).• The clear-eyed depiction of the constraints on women in the 1950s.• The remarkable section about the fig tree and not wanting to choose one career/life path over another. (It’s often alluded to, most recently in the Netflix series Master Of None.)• The disturbing sections in the first mental facility.• The hopeful ending, which, in retrospect (Plath committed suicide at 30), turned out to be not so sunny. • The very funny story about getting out of chemistry class in college.• The brilliant opening sentence, which besides setting the story in a specific place and historic context (summer, 1953, New York City) also suggests a lot about the narrator’s state of mind. And the electrocution is a grim foreshadowing of the electroshock therapy she’ll receive later in the book. Here it is:“It was a queer, sultry summer, the summer they electrocuted the Rosenbergs, and I didn’t know what I was doing in New York.”What didn’t I appreciate back then?• To be honest, I didn’t know what a bell jar was. Now I can see that it’s associated with other scientific images in the book, like the dead fetuses that Esther’s on-again/off-again boyfriend, Buddy Willard, shows her, and the corpse and dissection she gets to see.• I remember thinking the second half of the book felt choppy and episodic, especially after the polished and casual tone of the first half. I still believe this, but now I think it’s intentional. Plath is trying to recreate the fragmented state of Esther’s mind. • There are other things that occurred to me this time around. Esther wants to write her senior thesis on “twin images in Finnegans Wake” (although she hasn’t read Joyce’s book yet). If you look at The Bell Jar, there are lots of images of doubles/twins, alternate versions of herself that Esther rejects (Joan, who, remember, also dated Buddy Willard, and Doreen). Esther dreams of an alternate life as Elly Higginbottom. And look at the number of times Esther looks at a mirror and doesn’t recognize herself. It’s startling.• I was also aware of the various mother substitutes in the book, from Esther’s scholarship benefactress, Philomena Guinea (based on the real-life Olive Higgins Prouty), to her “pug ugly” magazine editor, Jay Cee, to the kindly physician Dr. Nolan. • I’m sure Plath is alluding to other symbolic initiation rites with the attempted rape by the “woman-hater” Marco, and the loss of Esther’s virginity, which lands her in the emergency department.• I appreciated the various types of women presented in the book, which, in a way are offered up as examples for Esther to follow or not follow. Think of the perennially pregnant Dodo Conway (is that a great name, or what?), the sly, sarcastic Southerner Doreen, the perky midwestern Betsy... Final thoughts… • Treatment of mental illness has come such a long way since the book’s posthumous publication. What a shame Plath couldn’t have benefited from some of that as a teenager and young adult. But how satisfying that we have a record of her experiences with depression. (At her lowest state, Esther can’t read or write.) • In the early parts of the book, Esther refers to her present-day life – she’s married and has a child – and I wish that had been followed through in the rest of the book. • Plath died at 30. THIRTY!!! Imagine all the books she could have written had she lived. • But let’s be grateful that she left behind this book, which, even though flawed, still captures that feeling of insecurity and uncertainty that we all have before venturing forth into adulthood.Note: for more in my re-reading series, here are reviews of To Kill A Mockingbird and Lord Of The Flies.

*edit in october 2023: bumping this up to 5 stars because the fig tree quote & i want to reread and annotate it. i am so happy that i finally got to this book! i knew i would like it and i wasn’t wrong, i really enjoyed the writing style, and i found the story interesting! it was really interesting to see her perception/the reality of gender and gender roles in the 50s. it was also SO interesting to read about psychiatric care during this time, i would immediately be pushed over the edge if my therapist told me some of the things her therapists/doctors said to her! the only thing keeping me from giving this 5/5 stars* is that it is exactly what i expected it to be, even though i went into the book only knowing it was about a depressed girl. although i loved the writing style and overall book, i was expecting everything that happened and nothing shocked me. it wasn’t necessarily predictable, but i wish there was something that happened that didn’t make me go “that makes sense”, which is what i thought after every “big” thing that happened. besides that, i think it was a great book to have on my fall tbr!also, as i knew going into this book, some of the descriptions in this book were racist, and i also know the author herself was anti-semitic, so i’m glad i got this second hand. if you’re thinking about reading this definitely check the content warnings!

I read this while visiting an old girlfriend in Bedford. One day she had some sort of appointment and she drove us out to wherever it was. It was one of the few times we had snow in England, and the pavements were covered and the roads were reflecting the sunlight quite harshly. I was to stay in the car, and I distinctly remember being there for a fair amount of time, reading The Bell Jar in that silent white world; there was no one else around. The muted atmosphere lent itself to the book's quiet but monumental emotion. I was greatly moved by a lot of passages in the novel, especially considering Plath's biography and subsequent suicide not long after the book's publication. When C. returned I remember being irrationally frustrated with her wanting to talk about snow and complain about the appointment and what we were going to do for the rest of the day. Plath's work made me want to sit in silence and thoughtfulness. I have since read a lot of her poetry and think it is just as good.

Esther Greenwood is on the road to fame and fortune when a dark path beckons...the farther she goes down the path the more it envelopes her. Sylvia Plath would have produced more enduring works of fiction if not for the dark path she found herself on. This story is all the more haunting due to the fact that it is the echo of what she was going through.

I am profoundly moved by the afterword of this novel which encompasses biographical elements drawn from Plath's own life and how they fit into this novel. Sometimes the most brilliant minds are also the most troubled, and in Plath's case, in her darkest of times, her words flowed like a river unto the paper revealing the ever so slight glimmer of her thoughts, writing through life up to the week before her death by suicide. Admittedly, I have known of The Bell Jar novel, it keeps appearing every now and then with my book friends, but I have been the most ignorant of book connoisseurs waiting way too long before giving it a try. In my streak of reading some classics, I chose this one as an audiobook on my runs and sad to say, I didn't get on with it at first. It wasn't the narration that threw me off, but I couldn't make sense of the content and where it was heading, albeit the writing was brilliant, blunt at times and an honest coming of age story of the talented, young academic Esther followed by her undoing due to mental illness. The novel takes part in the fifties and still feels very relevant today. Esther is writing columns for a paper and spending time in NY City, the place where every who of who wants is trying to make a break, hone in on talents, keep up with the glitz and glam and rub with the right sort of people. But Esther sees through all of it. She is done with shallow people but finds herself trapped over and over in the wrong crowd. She forms strong opinions about life and relationships, one might say, she is very resolute. Contemplating her own virginity and the options to be had besides men that either take advantage of her or desperately cling to her, she forms her ideas of when and how it should happen. It is brilliantly clear to her that having children is not for her. As everyone around her is experiencing and exploring permissibly, she is caught between a rock and a hard place of her mother's opinions on boys and her circle of "friends" activities. As the summer draws to an end, Esther does not make the cut for one of the literature classes she had hoped to take, and from there begins to isolate herself and spiral into depression. Her mother is trying to find her the help she needs and she is shuffled from one doctor to the next where she lands quickly in an asylum receiving the most horrible shock therapy as her treatment. Considering Plath's own stages of mind, which I learned from in the afterward, I would consider this characterization of Esther to be as close to the real torment as it can get, yet many chapters were left for interpretation by the reader versus spelling out the horror of darkness that took hold of her. If I was maybe a younger reader, I think I would have found myself in parts in Esther. Her resolute views on having a family life or more so the decision against it so adamantly were a stark contrast to my own when the time came, but perhaps also count as a tribute to her self awareness in sane moments compared to the depths in which she was lost and questioned everything in life. I'm not sure how I would have felt overall reading this as a young person, though it did garner a short reset of time for me as so many things are relatable and relevant still for today's young woman coming of age and I have been there once too. Suicide is a part of this novel that enters about midway and if a reader is more sensitive or struggles with themes of depression, this may not be a suitable read. It isn't graphic or horrific, I don't think that was Plath's style to write anyway, but I can see how Esther's unraveling and suicidal thoughts can stagger the effects on a person suffering already. As I finished the novel, I am ever so curious about this author's life and the parallels drawn in The Bell Jar. My overall sense is that I am glad I read this book, but there isn't a moral to be found or a solution. Perhaps I am left with a bit of sadness for both Esther and Sylvia, and just for a little while, I will carry this story in my heart, albeit a bit heavy filled with sorrow. If you have read this, feel free to share your thoughts. I know most have done so in school or former studies. I am just a curious reader who wonders what other's may have taken from this novel. Maybe someone has read it twice? Once as a student and then later again in life? How differently was the impact each time of reading?I am off to the next book, but feel free to comment :)Happy reading book friends. More of my reviews here:Through Novel Time & Distance

A bell jar is a piece of laboratory equipment used to contain vacuum. The Bell Jar is the only novel written by the American writer and poet Sylvia Plath. The novel is semi-autobiographical, originally published under the pseudonym "Victoria Lucas" in 1963, with the names of places and people changed. Plath committed suicide a month after its first UK publication. Pursuant to the wishes of Plath's mother and her husband Ted Hughes, the novel was not published under Plath's name until 1967 and was not published in the United States until 1971The Bell Jar chronicles the life of a young woman’s descent into mental illness, one that mirrors that of the author’s own experiences. Like Plath, Esther Greenwood is a straight A student who faces the choice of either further studies, marriage or a career. She stumbles through, thwarting each worthwhile chance as it is presented to her. Botching the end of a month long assignment at a top NY magazine, she resolutely shuns all the college courses open to her. This begins what will be a lifelong over-analysis of self and her shortcomings. Esther feels caged by the limitations that life now offers her, feeling herself trapped inside the bell jar. Electroshock therapy follows psychiatric therapy that leaves her resolved that suicide is the answer. Platt’s own battles with life choices, mental collapse and subsequent admissions to mental institutions can be seen quite clearly in her rendition of the character. The real test of this novel is if one would read it, having no prior knowledge of Plath’s own life or her fame as a poet, and still appreciate the story simply for itself. The answer would have to be a resounding ‘yes”; The Bell Jar would stand solely on it’s own merit and still be a real success. Recommended Reading 4★

I have a confession: I have never read a Sylvia Plath poem. Instead of rectifying that situation, I decided to listen to the audiobook of her novel instead. By the way, YOU SHOULD TOTALLY LISTEN TO THIS BOOK because it's narrated by Maggie Gyllenhaal and she does a fantastic job.The first half of the book is an interesting look at Esther/Sylvia's early life (because this book is very autobiographical) - she wins a lot of awards, is very successful, and navigates living temporarily in a big city for the first time for an internship. Then she returns home, and things quickly spiral downhill. I don't know what was more shocking - Esther/Sylvia's sudden onset of clinical depression or how it was "treated" (scarily an accurate representation of how the condition was handled at the time). This book will absolutely stick with me. I know reading a book about depression is only skimming the surface for how it must really feel to actually suffer from depression, but I feel like now I have at least a slightly better understanding of it. We may never know why some people must suffer this way when others do not, but I think reading books like this will help strip away the stigma and will develop deeper empathy for those who do have mental health afflictions.

In a hotel suite in Nashville, songwriters sit strumming guitars, taking notes, drinking Tennessee whiskey or sweet tea, writing a song about Esther Greenwood, the narrator and central protagonist of Sylvia Plath’s 1963 novel The Bell Jar.Cash: For me, looking back on this painful book, I have to separate my thoughts between Esther and Sylvia, and the tragedy.Waylon: But you must also allow that the book is at least semi-autobiographical. I think of your Delia and Dolly’s Jolene, but Esther, and Sylvia writing her, as fragile and broken, good women who were overwhelmed with depression and insanity. Esther is like my Amanda, but unable to love or be loved.Dolly: Esther is complicated, we see some of her changes to be foreshadowed while in New York, but the dramatic transformations happen when we follow her back home and the subtilties of Sylvia’s writing guides us down into darkness.Kris: I love Sylvia’s writing, love how her poetry shines through in the charming similes and metaphors. I thought of other poets like Dickey and Robert Penn Warren and Paulette Jiles whose prose is made better by the verse that lives between the lines.Willy: I loved it too. The transition from fun college girl in the city to depressed and suicidal back home was for me, a stark and abrupt alteration. While I agree that there were some hints that the story would go that way, she fell fast and definite. The bell jar is a symbol of isolation and Sylvia shows Esther to be emotionally shut off from the world.Dolly: A beautiful but sad story, told with warmth and emotion, but I also smiled and even laughed sometimes, Sylvia’s droll word play was the seam that held this together and could in some regards be considered a dark comedy.(They all consider).Kris: A drama told with some humor, but I don’t know that it was a comedy.Waylon: Sylvia’s inclusion of some humor, and how she described events could also be a comedic relief, breaking up the tragedy and also both highlighting and softening the dark themes.Cash: I can see how this book has been influential in the past sixty years since its publication.Dolly: I liked Esther, felt like I knew this character and felt sorry for her and I felt terrible that Sylvia was exploring these ideas while writing. Like Jolene, she does not realize how her self destructive ways are also selfish and hurtful to those she loves. Esther can be kind, but the world is a dark place from her vantage and she cannot escape the demons that haunt her.Cash: Sylvia’s descriptions of sexuality, and of more conservative mores while also allowing for a frank and open sensuality was also both endearing and a little disconcerting die to the context.Kris: The suicidal attempts and anxiety, as well as the descriptions of her treatment also made me think of Ken Kesey’s One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest, which was published a year before Plath’s book. We also see in her idea that the bell jar can descend over her again and the asylum graduates who stay there, never truly recovered, is a dark omen about Sylvia’s own recurring nightmare.Waylon: Pundits who have not read the book, or who are commenting on Sylvia’s death, will draw all kinds of odd takes, but at the end of the day, this is a beautifully written tragedy.

"La campana de cristal" tiene una prosa que constantemente nos remite a lo fúnebre, lo deprimente, lo obsesivo y lo melancólico. Me removió varios recuerdos y pensamientos de ese matiz, fue una lectura densa, pero no necesariamente en un sentido negativo. Por algún motivo, llevo un imán que atrae este tipo de lecturas amargas en momentos donde estoy en mi propio limbo. Fue mi libro soporte, mi luz y guía para atravesar ese camino neblinoso por el que transitaba al momento de leerlo. Honestamente creo que todos podemos empatizar con la protagonista, aun sin haber pasado por la depresión. Sin embargo, siento que para aquellos que la padecemos es un libro que llega y pega de una manera diferente, porque entendemos con certeza las cosas que llevan al declive a Esther. La misma Plath tuvo depresión (algunos dicen que bipolaridad también) y por eso esta novela es un poco autobiográfica, refleja mucho de su auténtico sentir. Es una lectura dura, pero necesaria.

I loved this book—and I can’t even put into words why exactly that is.
“I saw my life branching out before me like the green fig tree in the story. From the tip of every branch, like a fat purple fig, a wonderful future beckoned and winked. One fig was a husband and a happy home and children, and another fig was a famous poet and another fig was a brilliant professor, and another fig was Ee Gee, the amazing editor, and another fig was Europe and Africa and South America, and another fig was Constantin and Socrates and Attila and a pack of other lovers with queer names and offbeat professions, and another fig was an Olympic lady crew champion, and beyond and above these figs were many more figs I couldn't quite make out.”
 Sylvia Plath gives her heroine* in this novel a very distinctive voice that notedly sets her apart from many others with a mental imbalance. There is a fragility in her words, as well as a precision to the way she arranges them, and strung together they form an immensely powerful narrative.Sylvia Plath is a poet at heart—and it shows in her writing. I was more than once struck by the almost lyrical touch her prose displays, eerily reminiscent of Lana Del Rey’s darker, more sombre, and melancholic songs, ever so reminding me of her Born to Die era aesthetic.

I don’t think this is a book that will appeal to all audiences—despite being recognised as a classic—but I was simply mesmerized.
“I saw myself sitting in the crotch of this fig tree, starving to death, just because I couldn't make up my mind which of the figs I would choose. I wanted each and every one of them, but choosing one meant losing all the rest, and, as I sat there, unable to decide, the figs began to wrinkle and go black, and, one by one, they plopped to the ground at my feet.”
*It should be noted, that The Bell Jar is a semi-autobiographical work.

Most people read this book as a pseudo-autobiography of Plath, and that's what it is. But it's also a mostly-decent novel about a woman unravelling under the pressures of the 1950s and slowly learning to take control of her own life, and that's moving whether it's true or not. Though Plath's writing is best in her poems, the book is spiked now and then with razor-sharp passages that make it worth reading. It would be interesting to go back in time, re-read this book before I'd ever heard of Plath, and see what I thought of it then. I suspect I'd like the book more, and so would most people.

I went into this novel knowingly aware of everything that happened to Sylvia Plath, and after reading this particular book, I have found this has affected me rather profoundly. Plath's prose in this is poetic and rather haunting in a way, especially knowing that Esther's thoughts, were quite often Plath's own. For me, even when Esther is freed from the bell jar, that didn't bring me much solace, as I realised rather abruptly, that this book is only part fiction. After reading The Bell Jar, especially if one hasn't had first hand experience with clinical depression itself, I think this book could help change a person's perception of that. Many still think that depression is a case of feeling a bit blue every now and again, and it is a simple case of popping a few pills to fix it. This is called ignorance, and is more or less demeaning depression outright."I took a deep breath and listened to the old brag of my heart. I am, I am, I am.”Plath held my attention throughout this dark read, with her alluring writing, and even though I felt pain when reading parts of this, there were also parts that made me smile, especially when Esther gave her solid descriptions in regards to what she thought of the world, as her honesty just shone through. I am so glad that I finally read this beautifully sombre read, in which Plath's death haunted every single page.

As a man, I feel vastly unqualified to review what has become required reading for the modern feminist. So, I'll simply leave a few thoughts. The writing is beautiful. The story is depressing. Esther is an amazingly deep and complex character. Buddy Willard is a douche. I didn't love it. I didn't hate it.

Sometimes, once in a long while, a book comes around, with words so cogitative that they bounce off the pages and hit me with pangs of echoing familiarity and intriguing strangeness. And that, The Bell Jar does. Numerous times. And it's scary that I'm relating to a potential depression victim. ( Maybe, relating is a strong word, I could understand her might be more fitting. At least, That's what I'm telling myself. )
“I wanted to crawl in between those black lines of print, the way you crawl through a fence, and go to sleep under that beautiful big green fig-tree.” 
And I want to crawl in between those black lines of print, the way you crawl through a fence, and tell Esther, that everything will be alright. Because no one ever told her that. Throughout the book, an eerie feeling that defies all logic haunted me, as if I could change the course of things. As if I was responsible for what happened (Nothing dire happened ). That's the height of perfection Plath has achieved with this book. I don't know if it's because of the rich prose replete with palpability that justifies every emotion in the spectrum or because of the intellectually crafted introspective protagonist who gives life to those thoughts.Whatever the reason may be, Sylvia Plath has presented it exquisitely in this novel with a shockingly realistic protagonist, Esther Greenwood ( maybe because it was just Plath, herself, in diaphanous disguise. )The publisher's note before the book talks about Sylvia Plath's life and how this novel is a stark parallel to her own plummet. This urged me to read more about the author. And you'd be surprised by what I found. How her life was literally chronicled in this book. And how what wasn't said here was scarier. I usually don't like a book with depression even along the sidelines because it always sounds so bogus to me. It is appalling how so many of the books seem to have reduced depression to a bunch of asinine tendencies freckled with bouts of petulance and angst with the person wading boisterously through the seas of neurotic idiosyncrasies. What they seem to forget is that it's not always a roar, it can be a whisper too. Subtle and sinuous and frightening. It's so subtle that only several pages after her dive into depression did I actually realize what had happened. The signs were there, from the very beginning, unhappiness and disinterest that gradually morphed into a lurking shadow of doubt about life itself. And I was terrified for Esther and I was terrified of her, of what she might do. Her deviated thoughts and her box full of razors. Because in my head she is real. As real as the author who created her, the same one who also suicided at the age of 30. This book's success, lies in the fact that it presents us a pre-depression Esther and a post depression one but only later do we realize that there is no fine line dividing both. And of course everything that has been described feels smotheringly real because Plath knew what she was writing about. This book made me wonder whether it's really more difficult to write down reality than it is to fabricate fiction. It's just a guess but I felt it worth mentioning because I've been thinking about it a lot. What might have gone in her head when she wrote this ? Would she have thought that some day, about half a century later, a girl in a different continent would be reading this, feeling an agonizing emptiness at the futility of her empathy ? Or was this book just a sobbing reprieve ? I don't think I've ever read more about the author than the book and now I look forward to reading her forte, confessional poetry. I highly suggest you know the story of Plath's life ( and death ) before you delve into this book. And you must read this book.

When I turned the last page of book I found my mind gaping in void. What one is left with after finishing a book, I went through it since very beginning of The bell jar. First, the topic hits home to me. Second, it's a reflection of a true life. Third, sadly the brilliance of a burning candle finally succumbed in a bell jar, devoid of respiration, devoid of oxygen. My mind can't stop thinking numerous ways to save a life with such genius brain. Maybe she had lived long had she been a man and not a woman. Maybe if her husband, Mr Hughes had still been with her, we've had left with very rich books, enlightening and shading light on the darkest secrets of human mind along with a guide to overcome the obstacles in those dark pits of opaque bell jar. She's an inspiration all right but it'd be a great lesson and had impacted many lives practically, positively, had she made through it.The sensitive minds feel deeply than normal ones. Every thought comes to them magnified, glaring bright and living them blinded, indecisive. And being so integral and true to themselves they are left hanging in between, often failing in reality. I recall V Woolf, I recall John Nash and there's an impressive list. Unfortunately we still don't have cure for this mind trait. The intelligence is often left alone in their grooves, unable to mix in society. It has been in past, it's in presence and it seems to project so in future. Finding the conspirators around, blurred words, the sight of own clothes making one creepy- they all are intense symptoms. The falling in the endless tube, the hopelessness of life are there too. Did I see a struggle there? It's a fight, of course. But Esther did not show strong will to come out of it. She seems giving in to the urge of relief that comes with the end. I think Plath hasn't been true to herself in the book entirely. There must be thousand flip switches in mind and there must be some combination of them which keeps one hanging to dear life. For Esther, it's natural instinct of body which resists on several failed attempts of suicide, I am I am I am. But I bet Sylvia Plath couldn't come out of it without that strong will. Life is battle but for some it's war every minute. We can see the struggle of crippled to move a foot forward. But those who struggle inside mind with depression, we expect them to be normal. We fail to empathizing, to show care, love and understanding they so much are in need of.Well, I'm talking of her life rather than book but it's her life, the book, isn't it?I find Esther a girl next door, nerdy, intelligent, tender, insecure, secluded, scorned at. With her prominent prose she helps reader put on the goggles and let's us slip in her life easily. Her agony becomes our agony. The dazzling light of honesty allows us see things clearly. It must take a lot of courage to be this true, especially when it's reformatory. She doesn't ask or see it in pitiful flights. Instead her humor seems natural. Her candid description of her femininity and despair are shocking for that time. On top of that the simplicity of writing blended with her poetic prowess is stunning. You can't help but feel the suffocation of bell jar.I wish those were the final words of her, the bell jar would just shatter and splinter, never been able to close in.“All the heat and fear had purged itself. I felt surprisingly at peace. The bell jar hung, suspended, a few feet above my head. I was open to the circulating air.”

Il giovedì in cui ho finito di leggere La campana di vetro, mentre tornavo a casa in macchina dopo il lavoro, si è scatenato un acquazzone improvviso e violento. Mi sono fermata con le quattro frecce sul bordo della carreggiata ad aspettare che il turbine di acqua e grandine si calmasse un po’.I libri che ti restano accanto dopo averli finiti sono sempre i migliori, pensavo, e guardando la violenza del vento attraverso il vetro del finestrino, per un attimo ho immaginato Esther guardare una vita che non le appartiene attraverso il vetro della sua personale campana di vetro. Fuori il tumulto degli alberi scossi dal vento, dentro il rumore assordante della grandine sul vetro. Fuori la vita che scorre in un turbinio incessante, dentro un cuore che batte e ti ricorda che esisti, “io sono, io sono, io sono”. È facilissimo entrare nei panni di Esther, capire la sua fragilità nascosta dietro una voce cinica, tagliente, ironica perfino. È facilissimo volerle bene e starle accanto mentre sprofonda nel suo inferno privato, assistere - impotenti come lei - al senno che la abbandona pian piano per far spazio ad un terrore nudo, alla “sensazione di essere ricacciata sempre più in fondo a un sacco nero senz’aria e senza fine”. Nel racconto in prima persona si coglie una voce duplice, quella matura di Esther narratrice che si guarda indietro e - ormai guarita - ricorda e racconta, e quella infantile di Esther diciannovenne, disorientata e spersa, che lotta contro l’attrito di mille forze che la spingono verso strade che la società ha già spianato per lei. Ma lei lotta con le unghie e con i denti, fino ad essere schiacciata dalla possibilità di ciò che potrebbe essere, fino a desiderare la morte piuttosto che una vita vuota e asfissiante sotto la campana di vetro. Io ho amato ogni pagina, ogni frase ed ogni parola. È un libro doloroso per la sua autenticità e per la consapevolezza che l’epilogo di Esther non si trova all’ultima pagina. Eppure per libri così soffrirei altre mille volte. #AmericanLitClub, quante perle stiamo scoprendo 🤍

Reading a biography of Sylvia Plath's summer in New York made me want to read The Bell Jar again, but I rarely reread books, and I thought it had only been about three or four years since I'd read it for the first time. Then I checked back and realized it had been over ten years. TEN years. It's not much of an exaggeration to say that just about everything that's happened in my life has happened in the past ten years. Therefore, anything with emotional import must be read again. I remember loving the book last time, and I think I loved it even more this time. Plath's depiction of depression is amazing—she puts to words things that should be impossible to put to words. The book is also an immersive experience of that particular time and the options you had (or didn't have) if you were a young woman and/or had had a mental illness (as Esther's ex-boyfriend puts it, "I wonder who you'll marry now, Esther. Now you've been... here."). When it's not busy being harrowing, the novel is also very funny (my favorite line: "If there's anything I look down on, it's a man in a blue outfit."). Plath depicts Esther very early on as an avid observer of people, and that trait comes in handy in both the absurd moments and the devastating ones.I've heard this book described as a sort of female Catcher in the Rye, but I don't really agree. I think a lot of people identify with Holden Caulfield when they're young, but if they go back to the book as adults they're more likely to just be amused, or even annoyed. I don't think the same is true of The Bell Jar. I think with The Bell Jar the qualities you admire are only going to show themselves more vividly and heartbreakingly as you grow up.

4 and a half stars.What Esther Greenwood really wanted was to be her own person, but the world isn’t really built like that. The world is built for people who can easily fit into a few sets of molds, and those who can’t fit wander at the periphery, always feeling like they are looking in at a place they aren’t really a part of. Esther is perfectly rational in a world where logic is not what dictates people’s behaviors and societal expectations; for instance, she gets very angry when her steady admits to having had an affair while demanding she remain sexually innocent, and wants to even the score while she lives in New York for her summer internship, but she doesn’t know how. The job and the big city lifestyle do not give her the satisfaction other girls seem to get out of it, and she can’t see how her roommates’ vacuous behavior reflect in any way the idea of feminine independence she had in mind.In fact, while no one says to Esther that the best she can hope for in life is to get married to a successful man and have plenty of children, everything her mother, colleagues and doctors say and do implies as much. Her own identity is never given room to shine as it is buried under the expectation that she will eventually become a housewife. When you realize that you will always be rerouted on a road you don’t want to travel, no matter what you do, you feel trapped - and Esther only sees one way out of this trap…There were many elements of this book that resonated very strongly with me and I did not find it to be depressing; if anything, it’s a lucid and realistic exploration of depression, and of how one can feel stuck by life – and eventually disconnected from it. I am very familiar with the confusion about identity, expectations, sex, independence, purpose and sanity, and I really appreciate that Plath wrote about it in the almost matter-of-fact way she did. There’s not a hint of hysteria, self-pity or melodrama in “The Bell Jar”: just the story of how the paradoxical heavy feeling of emptiness can hit you so fast and so hard you will never have seen it coming.It’s impossible to read this without thinking of Sylvia Plath’s life, as this book is a roman à clef detailing her own experience with mental health, electroshock therapy and suicide attempts, as well as her thoughts on gender roles and the double standards she constantly ran up against. It seems absurd to call her prose poetic since she is better known for her poetry, but it really is, in a light, vivacious and often darkly funny way – even when the events take a turn for the worse. Her wit and obvious brilliance shine through her words beautifully, and it pains me to think that had she lived later (or simply had a less puritan upbringing), she would not have endured the suffering she put on the page, and ultimately surrendered to it. It is heartbreaking to know that Plath gave Esther the hopeful end she never felt she had a shot at.A quiet, introspective work about disturbing and uneasy subjects.

See, that's the thing about some of these old classic books. They become so iconic that you almost feel like you are doing something wrong, or you are being too "predictable" if you like them.For its time, this book was a giant feminist cry, and it still bucks a little bit against the system with a protagonist that is NOT looking for love or marriage. But, I think the thing that struck me more than anything was the tragic way mental illness was treated back then. Shock treatments, insulin treatments, and lobotomies were standard care for these poor patients. It just made me feel so outraged on their behalf!Of course the patriarchal system where men controlled women's bodies in every way was also murder-inducing. From the condescending attitudes towards illness, like telling a female that her (common) complaint must be all in her head, to the barbaric way they treated childbirth, it made me wish that when I was born I could have slapped my doctor. My mother was one of those women who was left to scream alone in a labor room, then drugged in a twilight sleep just in time to be taken to a delivery room, on her back, to have a baby pulled out of her with forceps. Ugh! I can't imagine the fear and horror that the mothers must have felt, all alone, in a society that acted like giving birth was dirty or shameful.Thank God that we don't have those types of attitudes going on in our society nowadays.Okay, we still have a little bit more work to do. I'm just happy that the millennial generation females have a zero tolerance policy when it comes to male-bullshit.

This is a beautiful, however depressing book about Esther who suffers from a depression and consequently wants to commit suicide. She feels like she is living in a bell jar with no contact to the outside world, and as a reader you are being enclosed in this bell jar together with her. This was a reread for me, and once again I was very much affected by the dark and depressing mood of this book. Sometimes, it becomes too much for me and I have a sudden urge to read something light and fluffy, but at the same time that's what makes me admire this story so much - it talks to my emotions and makes me feel something. This is Sylvia Plath's only novel and it has impeccable writing in it. I don't read poetry and so I haven't read any of her poetry, but I can sense from this book that this is a woman who knows how to play with words and descriptions. Her language is beautiful, and it encaptures and enchantes the reader once and once again. However, I still have and will probably always have some kind of emotional distance to this story because of its depressing message and mood; this book doesn't make me feel happy and good about myself in the least, but at least it evokes some very unique and unexplored feelings in me and that's why it gets 4 stars from me.

A haunting and unforgettable novel with -don't we all know- autobiographic elements in it. This is one of the sad books that doesn't try to make you cry or agitate you. I love how feminism could be breathed in this book through Esther. I think she'll be one of the wittiest, most honest and saddest literary heroines of all time for me.

The Bell Jar by Sylvia PlathGenre: Roman à clefHow do you rate a book that you liked and didn't like too? A book that doesn't leave you even after you turn the last page, and yet a book that you don't think you can read again? A book that is as intellectually stimulating as it is emotionally exhausting? Honest answer: I don't know.As Sylvia Plath's only published novel, The Bell Jar has been in my TBR since a long time. Especially as I'm not much into poetry, this book seemed to be a great way of knowing the troubled poet intimately. I'm glad that I waited all this time before attempting the book because I wouldn't have been able to appreciate the dark beauty of this painful story in my younger years. Esther Greenwood, the leading character of this semi-autobiographical novel masquerading as a fictional bildungsroman, is an intelligent college student with dreams of becoming a poet. After being selected for a summer internship at a women's magazine, her mind slowly start unravelling and she struggles with her identity, her place in the world and the meaning of her life. The book unveils her slow, steady descent into the dark pit of mental chaos, where everyone and everything seems hopeless and the only solution seems to be an escape from life. The bell jar is something we have all seen in our school labs, an inverted glass jar generally used to display some scientific object. For Esther, the bell jar symbolizes a kind of entrapment by her mental struggles. It's like her mind is enclosed by a bell jar. She can view the world from inside her jar, but she can't escape it. At the same time, people can view her through her bell jar but cannot touch her, and I don't mean touch in the physical sense. There is always a barrier between her and others, and she can't find a way out of this invisible cage.Considering the fact that Sylvia Plath herself struggled with psychological ailments in her adult life, there is bound to be a big question mark over how much of this book is just fiction and how much is an indication of the ghosts in her mind. Add to this the fact that she finally succeeded in her attempt to commit suicide a month after this novel was published, and you become even more uncertain of the hazy boundary between fact and fiction. But no matter what the truth of the matter is, there is no denying the fact that Plath captures the pandemonium of a suffering mind perfectly. As a reader, I just felt helpless because I could see the path of self-destruction that the protagonist was on, but I couldn't do anything about it. The Bell Jar is a book that has left me with deep thoughts and no answers. With the topic it covers, there is no way I can say that I "enjoyed" this book, and yet I couldn't help but continue reading it. I'm feeling as muddled as its protagonist because I'm at sixes and sevens about whether to recommend this book or not. So let me just leave this review without a rating, and without an open recommendation. It's a book not meant for everyone, but for those who do read it, it's a book that will not leave you easily. My rating: No idea.********************************************Join me on the Facebook group,

Sylvia Plath’s writing is beautiful. It’s no surprise she was a poet as The Bell Jar is peppered with imagery such as:“A summer calm laid it’s hand over everything, like death.” And:“I felt very still and very empty, the way the eye of a tornado must feel, moving dully along in the middle of the surrounding hullabaloo.”Esther Greenwood (part Sylvia, if you will) starts out as a seemingly ordinary young woman going through her college years but before long, you realize there is something wrong. As I was drawn deeper into Esther’s mind, I found myself reading slower, absorbing the intensity of the words. For such a short book, there is much to contemplate. Plath gives us such an intimate look inside the mind of a person suffering from depression. This book is haunting and memorable.

For the first time in a long, long time, finishing a novel left me feeling genuinely sorrowful. Not because the ending was especially sad (it's not), or because I didn't want the book to end (though that is kinda true). I felt this way because I knew that Sylvia Plath left us far too soon and the world had somehow been a much better place with her in it.Her style here flows like intimate conversation. For me, The Bell Jar transcends the author/reader relationship, it felt warmly personal and private. Maybe because I knew it was a fictionalized autobiography? Or maybe because Esther, Platt's protagonist, reminded me of someone I once knew and loved? Either way, this is high on my list of favorite books.
