4.5 starsI know, I know what some of you guys might be thinking right now: “four 5-star books in a row, mmm… kind of suspicious, huh?” (Or maybe I’m just exaggerating). Either way, believe it or not, each of the last three books I’ve read has been an outstanding experience, and The Bell Jar is certainly not the exception.This book is a little difficult for me to review, since its narrative and story were different from what I was expecting to read. Despite the fact that my first assumptions were completely wrong (I will explain why soon), it turned out to be a great novel, beyond my own expectations.First of all, I thought I would find, once I decided to dive into it, a depressing, quite sad story of a person who is suffering from depression, and second of all, I believed it might be quite hard to get through it due to this particular scenario. Well, I was totally wrong, because even though we have here a precise portrait of the different stages of depression, I couldn't feel real empathy for our protagonist, Esther Greenwood, who was dealing with this situation in the novel. Please, don't get me wrong, but I felt as though the narrative was 'cold' and distant from the reader – of course this was my perception and the way I felt it throughout the story. Was it a problem for me? Not at all; on the contrary, I am glad of the way the book is written, because somehow I was able to be kind of a witness, and to see these events in which our protagonist had to go through. Besides, I'm not saying you as a reader can't feel anything while you are reading this book, but speaking of my own experience, there was sometimes like a barrier between the protagonist and me, and the same case with other characters, the plot, and so on.Despite it all, I really liked Sylvia Plath's prose quite a bit: I felt as if she was writing poetry instead of a novel, since there are a lot of beautiful phrases at which you can go deeper and deeper – they are so remarkable and they could have more than one meaning; in short, it is an excellent writing style. Speaking of the plot, this was another surprise. From my point of view, there is no plot; I never saw a real plot, but a bunch of paragraphs and ideas which were not always connected among them – again, this is not supposed to be a problem once you are diving into the story. There's neither a beginning, nor an ending, since the novel pictures a part of this difficult situation in one person's life. In addition, this book is considered such as an autobiographical novel, and this is another aspect which is important to think about: this book and Sylvia Plath's life are truly connected. They are so connected that it is not possible to separate the author life from her novel.Perhaps all these things were done on purpose, perhaps the objective of Sylvia Plath was not to make us feel empathy or sad for her protagonist after all. Actually, according to her mother, her intention of writing this novel was clear and concise:“What I’ve done,” I remember her saying, “is to throw together events from my own life, fictionalizing to add color--it’s a pot boiler really, but I think it will show how isolated a person feels when he is suffering a breakdown... I’ve tried to picture my world and the people in it as seen through the distorting lens of a bell jar.”*Having said all this stuff, I must say I really enjoyed reading this book. Since I have been in the bell jar twice in my life, I really could relate to some events, thoughts and attitudes which take place in Esther's life. For instance, when she said, "... tell me why I couldn’t sleep and why I couldn’t read and why I couldn’t eat and why everything people did seemed so silly, because they only died in the end," it made me think of many people who have felt the same way, made me think of myself and the moment I used to feel like that. At the end of the day, we all are trying to face our inner demons, and to come positivity back in our lives, however, when depression manifests itself in one's life, the best thing we can do is to look for help. In my experience, a person who supports you, and professional help, are important in order for you to get better. Don't give up, never.Now, I don't know if I would recommend this book to everyone after all I have said. For instance, I read it in a book club, and there were people, half of the group or so, who didn't like it. Overall we had different opinions, different conclusions and the like. So, I guess it's up to you guys; as for me, it was a good one to be remembered for a long, long time.----* This paragraph is included in the final notes of my edition.

Plath's only novel, published four weeks before she committed suicide, is autofiction before autofiction was a thing: Confessional literature, in this case focusing on a writer who suffers from depression or, judging from the mood changes, even bipolar disorder. The author's 19-year-old alter ego Esther Greenwood at one point even decides to write a novel about herself, with a protagonist whose name also has six letters (like, hm, Sylvia). The main plotline goes like this though: Esther, a working class undergrad English major, does an internship in NY for "Ladies' Day" magazine (real life equivalent: Mademoiselle). Her co-workers represent the two urges she is torn between: Wild and free Doreen, and pious, held-back Betsy. They relate to the famous fig tree story, which is included later in the story and stands as a metaphor for Esther's destructive indecisiveness. In flashbacks, Esther thinks of her fiancé Buddy, a somewhat typical 1950's dude, plus she has several encounters with men we would today call problematic. Back at home, she learns she has not been accepted into a writing course, which shakes her confidence and self-image, as they are mainly defined by academic endeavors. Esther gets so depressed that her mom sends her to see a psychiatrist, which marks her entrance in the mental health system. At the same time, Esther ponders gender relations and struggles to find a direction in life.While everybody and their mother throws this together with The Catcher in the Rye, I think there's another suicidal depressive who was undergoing traumatizing electroshock therapy and wrote about his illness whose work should come to mind here: David Foster Wallace. His poetic essay The Planet Trillaphon as It Stands in Relation to the Bad Thing is in some ways the male perspective on suffocating under a bell jar. The parallels are haunting. Plath is so fascinating because she defied expectations, because she was angry and fierce (just check out Ariel), because she was a proto-feminist, and because she spoke out about an illness that is now less of a taboo, but still a difficult topic. Also, her language is great.

“Death must be so beautiful. To lie in the soft brown earth, with the grasses waving above one’s head, and listen to silence. To have no yesterday, and no tomorrow. To forget time, to forgive life, to be at peace.” I fell head over heels with Sylvia Plath throughout this book.Knowing how much of this is autobiographical makes me desperately sad. And seeing her experiences in the psychiatric hospital showed how wrong it was to have put her there. She was so lovely, and so independent, but she didn't have a clue how big she really was and how much her work was and still is idolised today.She writes as though she can see into my soul. She understands every little nuance that I have, every thought of doubt and despair, and still she continues on. She writes with extreme wit and warmth yet utter abject fear that she is leaving herself behind and that the one thing she is striving for she will never receive.She uses her own voice to address subjects that we all think and feel, but are too scared to confront, and for that reason I love her.

The Bell Jar introduces us to the world of mental illness in the 1960's where shock treatment was considered the norm and was also very prevalent. This semi-autobiography depicts the life of a young girl and her dissent through a suicide attempt from a mental breakdown and then later being committed to a mental asylum. This is a very depressing tale, a scary journey a young girl takes where she describes how she struggles with every day life. A very well written novel that will stay with me.

“‘We’ll act as if all this were a bad dream.’A bad dream.To the person in the bell jar blank and stopped as a dead baby, the world itself is the bad dream.A bad dream. I remembered everything.”
“An autobiographical work which I had to write in order to free myself from the past”, Sylvia Plath said this when told a friend about what she thought about her novel. I don’t know what else she could have said, but I personally feel that she shouldn’t have related it to being a semi-autobiographical account back then. People actually are mostly piqued by their massive interest in reading the original account of an American girl’s psychological breakdown, in the way of reading suicide incidents in newspapers. But it should be regarded more as a novel, I feel than as the slightly fictionalized form of the events of summer and autumn after Plath’s junior year.I don’t know, it’s a kind of book that made me go through an extreme dilemma: for it gets uncomfortably relatable at times while at other times it is totally irrelevant, it is an extremely lucid, easy read in the beginning whereas gets quite hard to go through at certain points. It’s as if she is more traumatized than anything by the fact that she can neither be the perfect conscientious student that she once wished to be nor the devil-may-care rebel that she found in her friend Doreen. And it’s the suspension between the two poles that destabilized her, rather grotesquely, I feel.I don’t know how to sum it all up: to put it rather straightforwardly it is a glimpse into the psyche of a major poet, and at the same time, a witty and devastating coming-of-age drama (not talking about Good Will Hunting). Ironically, instead of undergoing a positive progressive education in the ways of the world, Esther learns from her mental illness, gaining sanity over some tragic, even awkward incidents and graduates not from a college, but from an asylum. The only place where it falls a bit below my expectations is that I thought this was going to be a devastating read both emotionally and psychologically, but somehow it isn’t that hard-taxing for me as people had made it out to be. But it is very much readable and very much relatable even for a not morbidly-depressed teenager that I am. It’s not at all what I feared it to be, i.e. a bit toxic. Rather it is very much humanizing and much more shimmering with hope rather than gloomy glumness. Also kudos to her for speaking my heart out on the rather ‘awkward’ concept of: why does it matter to you if your wife’s virgin or not if you are not so yourself?It’s even more relatable than when Emily Maguire said: "Boys are rarely told that their virginity is a gift, or indeed that their sexuality is about “giving” something to another person – lightly or not. Boys “get laid”, “get lucky”, “get some”. They “take a girl’s virginity”, “take advantage”; if they’re thoughtful, they “take their time”. Boys are not taught to think of themselves or their virginity as something to be offered up, unwrapped and enjoyed." Plath does take her perception on a whole different level.The parallels that are drawn from reality are ambiguous as well. I took care to know as little as possible about Plath’s life before reading this, and that’s good, for there isn’t any Ted Hughes in this story. The burden of antagonism is carried by Esther as well. On an irrelevant note, I suffered the cons. of buying a novel from a thrift store here. The precious copy seems to have been owned by some pseudo-intellectual English major, hence scribbled with notes that resembled a lot from...
 “I shut my eyes and all the world drops dead;I lift my eyes and all is born again.”

Esther is witty, humorous and clever –you might wonder why she is having problems dealing with her surroundings – well, introversion is not due to lack of abilities but due to higher sensitiveness as regards to one’s surroundings:
“ I hate saying anything to a group of people. When I talk to a group of people I always have to single out one and talk to him, and all the while I am talking I feel the others are peering at me and taking unfair advantage.

A philosopher once said something like intellect is directly proportional to aversion for noise – while I do not believe that, I will bet that he was an introvert. The kind of sensitiveness make one want to hide oneself in some quiet place away from everything. Mere solitude is not enough – it runs risk of being destroyed:

“I wanted to be where nobody I knew could ever come.”

The penultimate feeling she seemed to have before losing her mental balance was one of being struck – being struck with a poor family, being truck with a wrong neighbor, a wrong world, wrong sex:

“ A man doesn’t have a worry in the world, while I’ve got a baby hanging over my head like a big stick, to keep me in line.”

And it is consciousness of this feeling that becomes her nemises – that old Dostoveskeyian quote ‘Consiousness is a disease’. In a world requiring conformity to difficult and at times impossible, one-size-fits-all kind of standards, not only as to what one should be doing but also as to what one should be feeling…

I was supposed to be having the time of my life.

…. lying to oneself becomes the only way to survive. But those with higher consciousness will find it more difficult to lie to themselves; and so … I don’t understand the concept of bravery but I strongly believe that people who kill themselves or go mad are the ones who can no longer help being honest with themselves. Perhaps they are the only honest ones.Around the middle of the book, we see Esther coldly speculating over ways of killing herself – and she does so with a humor, which makes whole thing sadder. You must be too used to be thinking about such a sad subject to take it that lightly.

“The trouble about jumping was that if you didn't pick the right number of stories, you might still be alive when you hit bottom.”

 There was a time when I believed, foolish as I’m, that all suicides are instinctive decisions. Of course, now I know how life can be a constant choice for some people, a constant battle with an ever present and seductive imp and the actual act is but a mere coup-de-grace one brings on oneself.

Public Service AnnouncementIf you are seriously depressed or suicidal, I would suggest reading this for another time or different year. 2020 might be a tough year to read this with the isolation of Covid from friends and family!I really did enjoy The Bell Jar even though the content is hard to read. The Bell Jar was written by Sylvia Plath back in 1963 and is set during the 1950s.Esther Greenwood is a young woman trying to figure out what her role is in society and goes to New York City for winning a writing contest. While in NYC, Ester is overwhelmed with the city, the other contest winners and all the questionable men she comes in contact with.As the book progresses, she can't seem to find happiness in her writing, connections or friendships.What Ester doesn't really understand is that she's battling depression and suicidal thoughts.No one during this time period knows how to battle mental health and you see that in the later part of the book.When Ester finally gets some help, you see how the mental health institutions battle depression, suicide and all other types of mental illness. And yeah, they didn't do a good job!Sure, this wasn't an easy book to read.The main character's progression into depression just keeps getting worse and worse. It's a slow and dark slide into this scary abyss.As a reader, you want Ester to find happiness, but she just can't seem to get out of her own way or questionable actions with men and friendships.Was Ester's character in this book a look into the mind and emotions of Sylvia Plath?Definitely read this one if you can handle the content and want to know that answer! I also think this is a good one to knock off the ole classics book list!

I'm really not sure what to say about this book. It was a fascinating read, but I didn't really love it. And yet at times I could really relate to Esther...to almost a scary degree, actually. Early in the book, she seems like the poster child for the so-called quarter life crisis, and (unsurprisingly) that's the part of the book where I really felt like I was over-relating to her. I actually had trouble getting through that section, and I wonder if it's because I found myself recognizing so much of it. There's one scene when she describes herself as sitting in a fig tree and wanting to pick them all, but knowing that as soon as she picks one, another will whither up and fall off. And of course, by not picking any, they all fall off. Later in the book when she's suicidal, I did (thankfully) find it more difficult to relate to her, and I found I could focus on this part of the book much better than the beginning. But that didn't necessarily increase my enjoyment of the book. It's pretty depressing material, only becoming slightly more hopeful by the end of the book. According to the special "PS" section in my edition, Plath intended to write a sequel that showed the world from "the view of health" (or something to that effect). Unfortunately she didn't quite get that far. Really, though, I don't have much to say about this book. It wasn't the best thing I'd ever read, and it wasn't the worst. It just sort of left me feeling numb, much like its narrator. 3 out of 5.
Sylvia Plath makes going crazy sound so rational! I loved Esther (or Plath), I love how she never seems to lose her sense of humour even in the worst time.

3 bis 4 Sterne, die ich hier aus Solidarität mit Esther Greenwood aufrunde, wobei sie mich dafür vermutlich als "klein und hässlich" beschrieben und emotional verletzt hätte. Die Geschichte rast dahin wie auf dem linken Autobahnstreifen, was in meinen Augen vor allem an zwei Besonderheiten des Buchs liegt:- Die Sprache ist frech, forsch, frotzelig. Die Geschichte um die junge Esther Greenwood, die einige Tage in New York verbringt, bis sie, nun zurück in der Heimat, allmählich ihrer Depression verfällt, ist leicht und rasch zu lesen. Um es zu bekennen: Ich hatte im Vorfeld etwas anderes erwartet, der Status einer absoluten Klassikerin ließ mich eine artifizielle Nabelschau mit vielen intelligent-komplizierten Hypotaxen erwarten. Bekommen habe ich frischen Fahrtwind bei offenem Haar; zumindest bis zum Crash.- Plath arbeitet mit einer mir neuen Art des foreshadowing. Ich möchte meiner Entdeckung gerne folgenden Namen geben: "Der mittige, entblößte Streifen", der an den Anfang eines Absatzes gestellt wird. Ein Absatz beginnt also zum Beispiel mit den spannenden Worten: "Es tut weh. Ist es normal, dass es weh tut?" und man ist sofort mittendrin in der Szene. Nun wird aber zunächst der Anfang dieser Szene beschrieben, in deren Mitte dann der Satz vom Anfang noch einmal vorkommt. Somit baut Plath immer wieder Spannung, mitunter auch ironische Brechungen auf. Mir hat dieses Verfahren gut gefallen, es hat fast etwas Filmisches: Als würde die Kamera in einer neuen Einstellung (man denke an die langen Schwarzblenden in alten Filmen) als Nahaufnahme auf einem Detail liegen, das erst allmählich in den größeren Zusammenhang gerückt wird.Allerdings verliert der mittige, entblößte Streifen durch die starke Wiederholung an Reiz, gerade weil er strukturell dominiert und dann auch etwas beliebig wirkt.Auch die Sprache wird mir in Erinnerung bleiben. Plath schreibt sehr bildreich, sie schwelgt in Metaphern, die in meinen Augen sehr stimmig wirken. Der Titel ist freilich eine davon.Bei all diesem Lob komme ich aber nicht ohne einen Verweis auf meine Irritation über die rasche Eskalation der Handlung aus. Denn was tatsächlich als ein rotzig-frecher Großstadtroman einer jungen, begabten Frau beginnt, die ihren Platz in der Gesellschaft noch nicht gefunden hat, aber dank ihres Talents und ihrer Kaltschnäuzigkeit sicher finden wird, verwandelt sich doch recht plötzlich in eine psychische Talfahrt, an deren Ende dann Suizidversuche und auch gesellschaftsanalytische Verallgemeinerungen stehen. Mir ist klar (oder ich vermute), dass gerade dieser zweite Teil zu einem Manifest der feministischen Literatur geworden ist und ich gehe auch voll mit, dass Plath die Szene der versuchten Vergewaltigung drastisch und eindrücklich schildert und dass ihre Esther unter der prüden Doppelmoral der Zeit leidet. Aber psychologisch nachvollziehbar fand ich den Prozess nicht, für mich eskalierte Esthers Selbstvernichtungswunsch allzu stufenlos. Auch die - vermutlich zumeist gefeierten - Verallgemeinerungen Esthers, "eigentlich leben ja alle Frauen unter einer Glasglocke", halte ich für identifikationsstiftend und für einen starken Slogan gegen eine sexistische Gesellschaft. Plausibel finde ich es aber nicht, da Esther verbal recht aggressiv ist, ihre Freundinnen wie Männer schlecht macht, ihre eigenen Schwächen durch Coolness oder Betrug kaschieren möchte und insgesamt äußerst unreif wirkt. Esthers Glasglocke ist sicher eine Spezialanfertigung. Gerade als eher unsichere und einem Ellenbogen-Individualismus verhaftete junge Frau taugt Esther dann nicht recht als Anklägerin sozialer Ungleichheit.Als literarische Figur hat mich Esther nicht komplett gepackt, den historischen Wert der Lektüre schmälert das aber unwesentlich.

Esther Greenwood is smart, I mean the kind of smart where she’s done exceptionally well in school and none of her classes represent that big of a challenge. Her goal is to become a writer and when she’s invited to join a group of young women to be guest editors for a girl’s magazine in New York City, Esther jumps at the opportunity. Unfortunately, the experience falls deeply short of so many expectations, inviting in a level of disillusionment and despair that was elevated when she was later turned down from a college summer writing program that she’d pinned her hopes upon attending. We get her first person narrative point of view of her descent into depression and mental illness. What makes this so compelling is Esther’s brilliant mind. Her thoughts sometimes seemed like a glimpse into madness but her intelligence and insights connected with me in a way that’s hard to define. I understood how her dashed hopes and dreams left her rudderless, making the world seem without luster as she had no visible view of a direction. If you’ve ever been there, you also understand how scary it can be to see it played out through someone else. I can’t remember not knowing of Sylvia Plath and this book. However, I wasn’t aware that this was semi-autographical nor that she died a couple of months after its publication, which she released under a pseudonym and only in the United Kingdom. It’s clear, at least to this reader, that Plath was inviting us into her own mind. If you’ve ever experienced clinical depression or any variation of that, you’ll recognize so much of Esther’s thoughts and feelings, uncomfortably so and the view of the psychiatric community in the early 1960s was troublesome.At the last minute, I opted to listen to the book when the audiobook became available at my library and that was a great decision because the narrator, Maggie Gyllenhaal was magnificent. This is a disturbing piece of genius that’s not easy to absorb but Esther’s wit and humor is peppered throughout her chronicle. The writing is just extraordinary, nothing like I’ve ever read and a sad reminder of the talent we lost too soon.Posted on Blue Mood Café

Deeply depressing.Esther Greenwood is talented and successful. She has decent looks and is in New York on a big fat scholarship. She has her whole life ahead of her. But things go downhill very quickly for Esther. Things get so bad to the point that her doctor recommends shock therapy which traumatizes the poor girl and since her spiraling even further downhill. During her steady decline she tries to commit suicide and is consequently thrown into a mental institution. And that's when things get really serious... or crazy rather 🤔This book dives into the deepest pits of our psyche. It chronicles the dark descent into psychosis. And as the main character is also the narrator we get an inside look at what's going on inside her head. It is almost maddening in itself to read the pages of this book. And it is heartbreaking to watch such a strong successful woman go down so quickly in flames. Very reminiscent of Girl, Interrupted... Or should I say Girl, Interrupted is very reminiscent of The Bell Jar since the latter was written first? The Bell Jar definitely takes place in a decade way before Girl, Interrupted did. However they ended in very much the same way.I devoured this book in one sitting but then again it's not a very large book. This was my first Sylvia Plath book and I have to say I'm glad I gave it a chance. It seems to me that people who have read this book either love it or hate it. To be honest I kind of feel indifferent about it. I didn't adore the book but I didn't loathe it either. Perhaps this is one of those classics that everybody should read once because it acts as a time capsule as well as a look into mental illness and psychosis, both of which it is written beautifully for. With that in mind I would definitely recommend reading this book at least once to take a look into are human past and what may be even more scary, I look into our own human minds.

Plath, in thought: O' how I count the ways of complete emotional and mental destruction; the loss, such great loss of myself, for which I have forgotten and may have never been.Death lies beneath the surface of us all. It is inevitable and consumes the mind of the depressed. How to do it? Why do it? You get there, I get there. We all get there. It all becomes us. Some of us faster than others, but an amalgam of reasons are to blame. Not the one above or down below.Plath yearns for the bell jar. The room she seals up is her bell jar. Thus, the end.
not exactly fun reading a book with gross racist comments every two pages. this book is just the epitome of white feminism so i definitely don't get the hype lol

I remember reading this one on my way to Southampton to be interviewed by professors, I'd applied to the university there, it being as far away from Nottingham as I could conceive in those days. I remember I had ridiculously long hair in those days too. But these things are not relevant. I'm not sure I'm up to reviewing the Bell Jar, much less Ariel, so instead.... here's a review of the movie SYLVIA which I hated and which has a few things to say about the Sylvia and Ted Show.A MOVIE REVIEWThe facts of the matter of Ted and Sylvia are well known, this movie presents them soberly, there are no cranky theories on offer (she may be the only American celebrity the CIA did not murder). On the surface what happened is banal, a marriage which went quickly wrong, and her left with two little kids. Happened all the time and still does. So what. But here's two Giant Poets doing what everyone else does.The genre known as the biopic tends towards the cartoon (Ah, Wilde, let me introduce you to my friend Whistler. I'm sure you'll find him most amusing... So, Oliver Cromwell, we meet at last.) and this portrait of Sylvia Plath in pre-feminist, pre-swinging 60s, pre-rock, pre-nearly everything late 1950s England, trapped like a bird in a house flying bang into the windows time and again trying painfully to escape, veers close to pure caricature.Sample dialogue :Sylvia : How was your walk?Ted: Good. I got a poem. A good one.Sylvia: I'm dried up.Ted: Cause you've got nothing to say.Sylvia: I'm no good.Ted: You make great cakes.Cue great offstage feminist moaning and gnashing. Then Ted says some useful blokeish things, like this. They're talking about writing poetry, they never talk about anything else: "There's no secret to it, you just have to pick a subject and stick your head into it." Sylvia retorts : "You go out for a bike ride and come back with an epic in hexameters - I sit down to write, I get a bake sale." A little later, on their honeymoon, they're in a dinghy rowing in the sea when Ted suddenly realises - he's out of his depth! ("the tide's dragging us out - I can't get us back in... people drown like this...") Heavy handed metaphor? Er, let me think. Okay, I've thought - YES, I think so! And so under waves of risible dialogue like that, the movie slowly sinks whilst the captain stands bravely on deck saluting to the last - that would be Gwyneth Paltrow, who gives a fine Paltrified performance, but what can even she do? Middle aged woman to Ted after his lecture : Mr Hughes, your voice is so.... powerful.Ted : But what did you think of the words?Middle-aged woman (blankly) : ....the words?Cue Sylvia smiling ironically. Cue audience rolling eyes and nudging each other - "I reckon there's Trouble Ahead!" Yes, we get it. Ted's a wow with the ladies. So it seems that these big name high toned poets have relationships which turn on the tedious negotiations of sexual fidelity just like everyone. No, really. And in this grisly movie sexual and creative jealousy is given to us as the whole cause of Sylvia's misery. Her extremely disturbed adolescence is alluded to twice but never examined. So, it was ted. He done it! Just as I thought!Sylvia Plath was a prisoner - of the 1950s and its common or garden sexism, of Ted Hughes, of her own ambition, of her marriage, of her children, and she was in an almost permanent rage. The only time she captured and channelled this rage was in the six month burst of energy in late 62 and early 63 when she wrote the Ariel poems, which collectively form one of the essential documents of the 20th century. This really unnecessary film cannot illuminate what happened. It peers at the photogenic surfaces. What was Ted thinking? What about Sylvia's friends - we only see one, Al Alvarez - had she scared them off? Why did she become suicidal? I mean. depressed, okay, but suicidal? She knew she had a brilliant talent. She knew she would do great things. Was she born a suicide, as some people are born junkies? What the hell was she thinking, with her two little kids in the next room? This was no ordinary despair. Is this movie for those who haven't read Sylvia or those who have? Either group would have many complaints. Avoid the Paltrification of Sylvia Plath, read Ariel.

چقدر این کتاب من بود.آدم‌هایی که در زندگی‌شان دوره‌ای از افسردگی را پشت سر گذاشته‌اند می‌دانند افسرده‌ها چه‌طوری هستند. می‌دانند که افسرده‌ها چه فکرهایی دارند و چه‌طور از هر موضوع ساده‌ای تلخی‌‌ها و تیرگی‌‌ها را بیرون می‌کشند. چه‌طور در میان توهمات بیمارگونه‌شان دست و پا می‌زنند و چه‌طور ساعت‌ها در هیچ غرق می‌شوند. آدم‌های افسرده جدا از زندگی و جدا از دنیای‌اند و به هیچ‌چیز بیش‌تر از مرگ فکر نمی‌کنند. همیشه تکه‌هایی از خودم را در این کتاب و آن کتاب پیدا می‌کردم. اما هرگز تا این اندازه با شخصیتی همذات‌پنداری نکرده بودم، طوری که در انتهای کتاب احساس می‌کردم بازگشته‌ام. بازگشت به آن دوره‌ی یخ‌زده. غم‌انگیز است که آدمی خودش را در این کتاب پیدا کند. دختری که با وجود فرصت‌ها و دستاوردهایش در مُرداب افسردگی فرومی‌رود. خواندن آن‌چه گاهی اوقات در فکرهایم گذشته، آن‌چه باعث شده از دیگران جدا بیفتم، باعث شده از احساس غربت و دل‌زدگی لبریز شوم، در میان صفحات این کتاب، همان اندازه که خوشایند بود، ناخوشایند بود. انگار حجم صلبی و سخت افسردگی من را در میان خودش گرفته بود و می‌فشرد. کاش هیچ‌کس این اندازه که من، با «حباب شیشه» همذات‌پنداری نکند.جدا از تمام این‌ها روایت کتاب و پیش‌روی داستان هر چند خطی اما همراه با فلش‌بک‌هایی است که آدم از ذهن یک راویِ افسرده و درونگرا توقع دارد. هرچند به گمان من ترجمه می‌توانست خیلی بهتر هم باشد.

Esther  era apenas uma moça tentando a sorte  em uma universidade  feminina na costa leste dos EUA, mas com o tempo  ,ela percebeu que não se encaixava na sociedade da época (anos 60)  estava tão assustada, sentia se como que  sendo enfiada cada vez mais fundo num saco escuro, sem ar e sem saída e entrou em uma depressão profunda e vai ter que encontrar  forças para  salvar a própria vida, numa época em que os tratamentos para depressão eram horríveis á base de choques.A temática do livro é pesada, não recomendado para pessoas que não estejam numa fase legal na vida, mas a narrativa é leve, flui maravilhosamente bem. A primeira parte do livro é até divertida,pois  Esther tem um humor refinado, é bem irônica também, mas  depois da metade do livro a tensão toma conta, se torna pesado (não a narrativa) e ficamos perplexos , tentando adivinhar qual será o seu fim… Sylvia Plath, apresenta um retrato convincente da vida adolescente, mas igualmente importante é a abordagem do livro às questões relacionadas à doença mental e o papel e as expectativas colocadas sobre as mulheres na época em que foi escrito.Um ótimo livro.. gostei muito!

J'ai enfin pris le temps de lire The Bell Jar, après des années à le voir passer devant moi sans même en comprendre le titre.C'est un roman d'une tristesse infinie et aussi d'une très grande lumière. J'ai beaucoup ri et aussi, sans vous mentir, j'ai un peu déprimé (surtout arrivée quasiment à la fin, alors que j'étais toute seule chez moi dans le noir à me poser de grandes questions sur le sens de ma vie). Il y avait une grande poésie dans chacune des images évoquées par Sylvia Plath. Une manière inédite (pour moi) de décrire la souffrance psychologique dans toute sa violence et sa solitude. Et une façon si "unapologetic" pour Esther de refuser une vie qui ne lui convient pas : ni mariage ni travail dans lequel elle fanerait, quitte à souffrir de ne pas savoir comment mener sa vie.“The trouble was, I hated the idea of serving men in any way.”Je me sens démunie de faire d'autres commentaires sur une oeuvre qui a manifestement marqué des générations entières de femmes, mais en tout cas je l'ai vraiment beaucoup aimé, et j'ai hâte de le relire en version papier (ma version ebook ayant des défauts de mise en page) pour pouvoir souligner mes passages préférés.

Impactante. No lo recomendaría si estás pasando una mala época. Hay algo que me ha hecho sentir muy cercana a su autora, creo que es su sinceridad y el hablar sin tapujos. Siento la necesidad de decir a Sylvia “eh, te debo una” ❤️

Dupa ce am terminat acest roman mi-au venit in minte doua lucruri: o clepsidra si ganduri despre sufletul de femeie in general. Timpul trece si femeia este pusa in fata unor decizii tumultoase cerandu-i-se adesea sa faca o facultate, sa se specializeze, sa-si ia o slujba, sa se casatoreasca, sa fie mama etc. si poate ca la un moment dat se trezeste ca nu poate sa faca niciunul dintre aceste lucruri, dar nici singura nu poate sa razbeasca si socul o loveste din plin iar nisipul din clepsidra ei s-a scurs...Sylvia Plath s-a remarcat mai ales prin poeziile pe care le-a scris, mai apoi prin prezentul roman. Avand o viata personala agitata, cu mariajul esuat si cu o situatie dificila, in 1963 decide sa se sinucida. In ultima vreme am citit numai carti apartinand unor autori care s-au sinucis si oarecum acest lucru ma afecteaza. Prezentul roman o are in prim plan pe Esther Greenwood, o tanara saraca dar inteligenta si descurcareata din New England. Ea reuseste sa castige o luna de 'internship' la New York in una dintre redactiile unei reviste de moda. Alaturi de alte 12 fete traieste o viata de glamour - petrecerile, orasul, oamenii superficiali si diferitii barbati pe care-i intalneste influentand-o.Dupa ce ajunge acasa "arunca la gunoi" bursa la un colegiu prestigios si refuza sa se casatoreasca cu Buddy Willard care va avea o cariera de medic reusita. Apoi sufera o cadere psihica si incearca sa se sinucida in toate felurile.Prima parte a romanului este foarte distractiva, limbajul este ironic, plin de umor, iar faptele amuzante si ritmul alert vor fi pe placul cititorilor. De asemenea felul de a fi si caracterul eroinei vor incanta.A doua parte a cartii va fi putin mai neplacuta, expunand starea mintala, confuzia si neputinta protagonistei. Poate ca pentru unii cititori, trecerea de la aventurile amuzante ale lui Esther la starea sa depresiva este prea brusca, cel putin asa am perceput-o eu. Am selectat doua situatii care mi s-au parut amuzante. Prima se refera la o reteta cu avocado si suna can asa: "topeam jeleu de struguri intr-o tigaie, il amestecam cu sos frantuzesc si apoi umpleam fructul scobit cu sosul rubiniu." Zau ca as incerca si eu dar nu cred ca gasesc jeleu de struguri iar sos frantuzesc nici atat si atunci mai bine raman la avocado-ul meu obisnuit.Cea de-a doua situatie se refera la bolul cu apa care ti se punea la dispozitie in restaurant si despre care eroina ne povesteste ca atunci cand fusese invitata odata, nu stia ce sa faca cu el, mai ales ca avea tot felul de flori in interior. Crezand ca e vorba despre o supa limpede japoneza a sorbit-o pana la ultima inghititura, cu tot cu florile crocante. In incheiere am ales mai multe citate care reflecta in mare parte personalitatea zbuciumata dar puternica a eroinei:"Si mi-am dat seama ca, indiferent de toti trandafirii si toate saruturile si de toate mesele la restaurant cu care un barbat copleseste o femeie inainte de a se insura cu ea, cand se termina slujba de cununie gandul lui tainuit era ca ea sa i se intinda sub picioare ca presul de bucatarie al doamnei Willard.""De fapt, toate femeile in varsta pe care le-am cunoscut au vrut sa ma invete cate ceva, doar ca, dintr-odata, aveam impresia ca nu prea au ce sa ma invete.""Misoginii erau ca zeii: invulnerabili si plini de putere. Pogorau si apoi dispareau. Nu puteai sa prinzi unul vreodata.""Mi-am dat seama ca Marco era misogin pentru ca [...] in acea seara n-a bagat in seama pe nimeni, in afara de mine. Nu din bunatate, nici macar din curiozitate, ci pentru ca-i fusesem impartita lui ca o carte de joc dintr-un pachet de carti identice.""Avea ceea ce nu avusese niciun barbat american pe care-l intalnise, si anume fler.""Barbatul este o sageata spre viitor, iar femeia este locul din care pleaca sageata.""... descoperisem ca, daca faci la masa ceva ce nu se cade cu anume aroganta, de parca ai sti perfect ca faci ce trebuie, scapi basma curata si nimeni nu-si inchipuie ca n-ai maniere sau ca esti prost-crescut. O sa creada ca esti original si foarte intelept."
Nie jest to zbytnio mój typ literatury ale rozumiem jej fenomen.

I read this with my postwar American novels class and liked it better than I had thought I would, given my memory of it as a first novel published in England under a pseudonym, many publishers turning it down as juvenile and "overwrought", and so on, but it was much better than I recalled. It was very difficult for me to read a book about suicidal depression as I have been a little crazy and depressed myself in the past days, and given some of the struggles one of my sons has with "the monsters" in his head (Re: an Eminem song popular now), so to see the schizophrenic, surreal depression so accurately and frighteningly depicted here was especially anguishing. Plath had herself by this time been hospitalized for a suicide attempt, but she used a book that was popular at the time (that I also had read) called The Snake Pit as a guide to some of the horrors of the psych hospital (where I had also worked with lifelong schizophrenics for years who had endured multiple shock treatments, and had even seen it administered once) to guide her own depiction of a psych hospital. Plath wrote this quite autobiographical novel and in the process hurt almost every single person she had ever known in the process, every single person she had depicted in her novel, and though she is harshest about herself in some ways, she creates an almost sympathetic portrait of herself.In the process of re-reading this book I also re-read Plath's amazing and raw Ariel poems, Ted Hughes' The Birthday Letters and Janet Malcolm's The Silent Woman again and most of the poetry by Plath and Hughes is much better than The Bell Jar, but there are poetic and psychic insights in The Bell Jar I think are great, in spite of the surface meanness in other parts. And in spite of what we already know about how her life ended, we get a hopeful ending to this book, which makes it all so anguishing, to see the struggle. There're also plenty of sardonic humor about a suburban growing-up-middle-class white girl life, and portraits of the NYC fifties publishing scene, that are great. This portrait of Plath is lighter than the one she paints of herself in the raw poetry, but it is really, really worth reading as a tale of growing up female and outsider in American culture then. It's in many ways a strong feminist tale of growing up female in the fifties. It's not perfect, but it's a classic, nevertheless, and haunting.

Sylvia Plath es definitivamente una figura muy importante y reconocida en la literatura, ya sea por su obra o por su trágica vida que ella misma acabó de la peor manera. Siempre me agarra un escalofrío cuando pienso en ello. Tenía mis expectativas muy altas con esta novela y me alegra poder decir que sí que las cumplió, aunque creo que mis sentimientos son muy personales, nada objetivos. Este libro es casi autobiográfico, siendo la protagonista un álter ego de la propia autora. Incluso en la misma historia se hace referencia a esto. Por eso mismo lo considero muy interesante, porque se siente como si estuvieras leyendo el diario íntimo de una persona, o como si te lo estuvieran contando cara a cara. Su prosa es muy directa pero está llena de matices y descripciones muy hermosas. No me sorprende porque Sylvia Plath escribía mas que nada poesía. Hay ciertos pasajes que son icónicos tanto para mí como para todo el mundo y de los que nunca me voy a olvidar. Me gustó mucho que, aparte de la exploración de la salud mental, de la depresión y de las tendencias suicidas, también se hablara de el papel de la mujer y de lo que se espera de ella. Esther, por ejemplo, se podría decir que tenía todo en bandeja para poder convertirse en una persona éxitosa, y que luego se casara y tuviera hijos. Sin embargo, al verse con tantas posibilidades y no creer que era suficientemente buena en algo se estancó por completo, viéndose juzgada por todo el mundo que la consideraba un potencial desperdiciado. Tampoco estaba bien visto en esa época que una mujer se "volviera loca" y los procedimientos para tratar a estas personas eran horribles. Sin duda este libro es muy adelantado a su época en ese aspecto e incluso en la actualidad siento que muchas chicas jóvenes se podrían identificar con la historia.《Si la señora Guinea me hubiese regalado un billete a Europa, o un crucero para dar la vuelta al mundo, me habría dado exactamente igual, porque en cualquier sitio —en la cubierta de un barco o en una cafetería en una calle de París o de Bangkok— estaría debajo de la misma campana de cristal, fermentándome en mi propio aire malsano.》

النفوس المسكينة البائسة الحزينة،واللي بتقدر تنقل مدى بؤسها والحياة المريرة اللي عاشتها عبر سطور مكتوبة في كتاب يكون قادر على الخلود،لا لشئ إلا لإنه بيكون رسالة حيّة تنتقل عبر الزمان والمكان لتتلاقى مع نفوس أخرى تشعر بوحدة قاتمة،ليونس الكتاب تلك الوحدة.نحن أمام رواية من طراز خاص،لأنها من الأعمال الأدبية القليلة التي استطاع كاتبها أن يكتب نفسه،أن يقدم ما يراه ويعيشه ويعانيه،ليس فقط بأسلوب منفرد أناني،بل بأسلوب متفرد يشارك به كل البشر.الرواية مميزة بجوها الأنثوي العظيم،نحن أمام قلم إمرأة لو قُدر له الاستمرار لأذهلنا كما ينبغي للذهول أن يكون،إمرأة استطاعت أن تنقل جزء من تجربتها الحياتية عبر الشئ الأكثر قداسة وهو كتاب،كتاب يُقرأ ويُقرأ إلى أن يرث الله الأرض ومن عليها،وسيجد بشر يقتلهم الحزن،فيشاركهم حياتهم بكل تفاصيلها.الرواية ببساطة عن إمرأة تقتلها الغربة،غربة النفس وغربة المكان وغربة البشر،تلك الغربة السوداء التي تتملك الإنسان ويجد نفسه عاجز على أن يعالجها ويداويها،فتتملكه وتقتله،أو تتركه كيان مهدم لا يصلح لشئ ولاسيما كإنسان.الجو النفسي للرواية مبهر،ونجحت الكاتبة باقتدار في تصوير معاناة بطلتها والأهم أنها نجحت في رسم كافة الشخصيات والظروف لتكون الرواية آلة زمن من الجمال بمكان.الكاتبة انتحرت لتتخلص من مآسي حياتها المتعددة،ومحاولة منها في النجاة من التخلص من ناقوس زجاجي مثّل حياتها ككل،وكانت هي محاصرة تحته ومضغوطة،فلم تجد إلا في الموت خلاص لها.

so conflicted about this book…. i appreciate it for being a classic staple of literature, especially tackling depression at a time where women especially were silenced about mental health…….. yet there are so many aspects of the book that didn’t age well at all and it detracts from plath’s talent as a writer. very in the middle about it.

Deliberately procrastinated on finishing this one, I just didn't want it to end...It's witty, discourteous, creepy, dark, compelling, disturbing and one of the best books I've ever read ! 💫I'm not really well-acquainted with Sylvia the Poet, but I genuinely am in love with Sylvia the Novelist ❤️
Funny, sad, thoughtful and overall good. Very good.

Esther Greenwood es una joven y prometedora pasante editorial en una popular revista femenina en la ciudad de Nueva York. A pesar del potencial de una vida brillante por delante, Esther sigue desanimada y casi intimidada por el futuro. Es una mujer muy independiente y decidida en una época en la que las expectativas sociales para una mujer de su edad son muy diferentes a su forma de pensar. Esta expectativa que se deposita en ella no hace más que aumentar su desánimo en la vida y comienza a tomar forma una profunda depresión.La campana de cristal es un objeto utilizado en experimentos de física para preservar algo, ya que crea un efecto de vacío y las cosas en su interior se sellan herméticamente. La metáfora aquí es que todo lo que se coloca en el interior no se ve afectado por nada que ocurra en el exterior, al igual que los sentimientos de Esther forman una especie de trampa que la contiene. Sus sentimientos de duda y desánimo la superan y es incapaz de ver la razón y ninguna influencia externa puede cambiar eso. Esto normalmente generaría un tono extremadamente deprimente, sin embargo, Esther es un personaje sorprendentemente humorístico, aunque oscuro. "La campana de cristal" es en realidad un recuento de los sucesos de su pasado, por lo que, en esencia, Esther está mirando hacia atrás sobre su vida y se está dando cuenta de la ingenuidad de sus acciones.Sylvia Plath incorpora hábilmente su magnífica prosa en su primera y única novela. El estilo de escritura en sí es extremadamente inteligente y fluido con un narrador algo poco confiable. La historia no se cuenta en orden cronológico, por lo que la historia a menudo es difícil de extrapolar, pero debe recordarse después de que todo esté dicho y hecho. La vida de Esther Greenwood está destinada a ser la semi-autobiografía de la propia Sylvia Plath y si sabes algo sobre su biografía real, eso puede explicar el final críptico que nos dan."La campana de cristal" muestra cuán profunda puede ser la depresión y cuán fuerte puede tener un control sobre uno mismo. Creo que este libro es más una experiencia que una novela. Estamos con Esther desde la primera página hasta la última oración. En mi opinión, Sylvia Plath con su prosa es capaz de captar la desesperanza y la anhedonia que acompañan a la depresión, tan difíciles de explicar a otro ser humano. Sin embargo, lo hace sin problemas, ya que permite que los lectores sean parte de su propio dolor.

4.50 Stars (Rnd ⬆️) — Sylvia Plath masterworks is not a novel I would of even remotely been prepared to read as early as 2-3yrs ago. Both in content & personal readability-level, it would’ve gone right over my simpleton head!However, being a somewhat capable literary reader nowadays, I devoured this brilliantly epic bit of social-commentary-laden-wrapped-fiction in no time. Plath’s prose alone, is well-worth the investment here. “I felt very still and empty, the way the eye of a tornado must feel, moving dully along in the middle of the surrounding hullabaloo.”The thing I found most astonishing whilst absorbing this classic, was how modernised it felt. Sure I knew it was socially relevant today, but the style & the characters inner-dialogue, are so intrinsically well formed, sharp and alluring that it often felt like I was reading something from the NEW FICTION section of my local bookshop.I mean, just READ this:“I saw my life branching out before me like the green fig tree in the story. From the tip of every branch, like a fat purple fig, a wonderful future beckoned and winked. One fig was a husband and a happy home and children, and another fig was a famous poet and another fig was a brilliant professor, and another fig was Ee Gee, the amazing editor, and another fig was Europe and Africa and South America, and another fig was Constantin and Socrates and Attila and a pack of other lovers with queer names and offbeat professions, and another fig was an Olympic lady crew champion, and beyond and above these figs were many more figs I couldn't quite make out. I saw myself sitting in the crotch of this fig tree, starving to death, just because I couldn't make up my mind which of the figs I would choose. I wanted each and every one of them, but choosing one meant losing all the rest, and, as I sat there, unable to decide, the figs began to wrinkle and go black, and, one by one, they plopped to the ground at my feet.”Enough said.So if you’re unsure about this one, don’t be — as you can see above.. Come for the prose — there is absolutely no adult-demographic that this won’t offer at least an ephemeral feeling of literary-effusion 🔥

Όπως καταλαβατε το τελευταίο διήμερο την έχω πάρει λίγο από κοντά την κατάθλιψη. Μια ο Πεσσόα τώρα η Πλαθ ότι καλυτερο για να ξεκινάς το καλοκαίρι σου αισιόδοξα :p. Όχι ορκίζομαι τυχαία η αναγνωση τους το ίδιο χρονικό διάστημα όμως και τα δύο ήταν εξίσου απολαυστικές αναγνωστικές εμπειρίες. Να ευχαριστήσω αρχικά τη φίλη Ρούλα χάρη στην οποία έμαθα την ύπαρξη του συγκεκριμένου βιβλίου. Σας εχω πει ποσο σας αγαπάω όλους εδώ μέσα γιατί χάρη σε εσάς μου χει δοθεί η ευκαιρία να διαβάζω υπέροχα βιβλία και να γίνω και εγηώ η ίδια καλύτερη αναγνώστρια; Να σας το πω λοιπόν. Στο ψητό όμως για να μη σας κουράζω. Πρώτο και μοναδικό μυθιστορηματικό έργο της Πλαθ με ημιαυτοβιογραφικές πινελιές. Μια πραγματικά χαρισματική γυναίκα που ξέρει να σε παρασύρει στο δικό της μαγευτικό κόσμο ακόμα και αν αυτός συνοδεύεται από αυτοκαταστροφικές τάσεις. Μέσα από την ιστορία της Εστέρ μιας γυναίκας που θεωρητικά τα είχε όλα και όμως δε σταματάει να νιώθει ότι ζει γύρω από ένα γυάλινο κώδωνα και δε μπορεί να αναπνεύσει καθαρά η Σύλβια Πλαθ μας παρουσιάζει ένα απολύτως υπέροχο και συνάμα σπαρακτικό έργο με κύριο άξονα του την αυτοκαταστροφή με τον αναγνώστη να γίνεται ένα με την ηρωίδα ζώντας ο ίδιος στο πετσί του τις περιπέτειες της και ψάχνοντας μαζί της απαντήσεις στα υπερξιακά της ερωτήματα. Σκληρό και συνάμα μεθυστικό, μια τολμηρή καταγραφή της προσπάθειας μιας γυναίκας να ξεφύγει από την κενότητα που της δημιουργεί το περιβάλλον της και παρά του γεγονότος ότι αισθάνεται ένα βήμα πίσω να δημιουργήσει από την αρχή έναν νέο διαφορετικό εαυτό όμως ακόμα και τότε δεν είναι σίγουρη ότι τα κατάφερε ‘‘ Μα δεν ήμουν σίγουρη. Καθόλου σίγουρη. Πως ήξερα ότι κάποια μέρα, στο κολέγιο στην Ευρώπη, κάπου, οπουδήποτε, ο γυάλινος κώδωνας, με τις ασφυκτικές του παραμορφώσεις, δεν θα με έκλεινε ξανά μέσα του’’ ; ΥΓ. Μοναδικά συγκλονιστική και ανατριχιαστική η περιγραφή της πρώτης της σεξουαλικής επαφής.

I.JUST.DON'T.GET.IT. The prose was prim, proper, neat, and plain ole' boring. And it was painfully obvious that the material was dated. I just couldn't relate to Esther at all. And her "descent into madness" was too subtle, while painfully, excruciatingly dull, and quite unbelievable. Also, I could care less if The Bell Jar was a semi-autobiography for Ms. Plath; I was bored out of my mind & the ending was just as ambiguous as everything else in this book. I hated Esther. Her white, middle class, privileged-suburban-life "woes" seemed petty. Also, her hatred for men was completely uncalled for. She was bitter, nasty, pathetic & ungrateful. Somehow, I doubt lower-class minorities living in America during her time would've been "depressed" or suicidal if they were in her shoes. So yeah, I guess she was crazy. I just don't get it. What the hell triggered her supposed descent into madness? Her 'scholarship' status? Her straight As? Her virginity/pride? Buddy's fling in the summer? Her honors courses? Her cool job at the magazine? Whether it'd been a culmination of these reasons, or none of these reasons, I sure as hell didn't know. Total waste of time. Lastly, I can attest to Plath's "credibility" and ability as a writer. Her prose is clear, distinct, and practiced; but it's too safe, dull, and a total snooze fest. I completely missed the plot for The Bell Jar. And if there was one, I don't want to know. Not anymore, anyway. Sorry.

There are certain perennial problems associated with adolescents graduating to adulthood: how to align one's aspirations with the expectations of society; how to take control and define oneself anew, when the entirety of one's life has been held in the sway of parental and academic authority. When a person remains within the familiar confines of school and family life, these questions are safely contained, rendered benign by their abstractness. But when that person is freed; when the invisible bell jar is lifted for the first time and they are exposed - as Esther was during her time in New York City - one is forced to confront the realities of the world. Esther is of a certain type for whom this confrontation is particularly difficult. Having been allowed only a narrow window into the world, she was certain of the constancy of her desires and aspirations though never having been granted the space to really explore herself. Despite the privileges of her upbringing and education, she is stifled by society, repressed sexually, and expected to discard her ambitions and adopt those of society: to become a loving wife to a handsome and successful husband, and a mother to a litter of children. During her stay in New York her emotional foundation collapses, and she is left to release pieces of herself, as the contents of her wardrobe, to wheresoever the wind may carry them. She has lost all ambition, and she discards the conventions of society. She drifts from institution to institution, and in her detachment acquiesces to her confinement and her treatments, with her mother all the while imploring her to just be normal again and to fit in, as if it were that simple.What makes Ether's decline so compelling is its complete logic, and her eminent reasonableness and cogency of thought throughout the ordeal. Despite being technically insane, she acts rationally within the framework of her experience. Her dereliction of agency may not be productive, but it is understandable and it is difficult not to be sympathetic. Had she lived in a later time, Esther (and I suppose Sylvia Plath herself) may have found in the world a freedom that did not exist in their own time. Perhaps this freedom would have been enough to allow them each to follow a different path. I hope so. I'd like to think that minds are not simply healthy or sick, but that progress can be made and that people can change and that there is hope.

I don't know.I can enjoy the bleakest of books. Living Dead Girl, for example, is one of the most brutal, unforgiving books I've ever read, and yet I still managed to find a kind of small, sick enjoyment - presumably in flipping the pages in a frenzy, panicking, never knowing what was going to happen next and not being sure if I wanted to know. I am using Living Dead Girl as an example because it's truly one of those helpless books, where a happy ending is just not possible.The Bell Jar is like that but, then again, not. It involved me. It involved me in the worst possible way. While reading it, I felt like I was being slowly dragged under tepid water. There is a heavy inevitability to all that happens to Esther. I began to feel depressed myself, to be affected by Esther's "what's the point?" attitude towards everything. While I am immensely sympathetic to people who suffer from depression, I also think that depression is one of the worst emotions in the world. I hate any kind of involvement in that feeling whatsoever. In spite of Plath's talent, I began to hate reading The Bell Jar. Yet I couldn't stop.Maybe this book should get five stars. Maybe it deserves them. But I can't bring myself to give them. There was no relish in The Bell Jar. There was no enjoyment. That is obviously the point -- Esther is seriously depressed and mentally ill, but still, Plath's depiction of her mental illness was so palpable that I couldn't see a light at the end of the tunnel, even when the quite hopeful ending rolled around. I could write a lot of standard critiques, like "the characters were unlikeable", but I only feel that unlikeability truly counts if we're supposed to sympathise with and love the characters. Obviously not Plath's intention. There were "no driving questions" - true, because it was all to mirror Esther's increasingly lifeless and hopeless outlook.Brief rant: however, I cannot see why this book is called a 'feminist' text. Why, because it revolves around an intellectual woman who isn't sure about getting married and having a family? Seriously, those are the only two components of Esther's character that I could really call 'feminist.' Maybe I have a skewed view of feminism, but to me, a feminist text is one that celebrates or depicts female triumph, success or, failing that, strength. To me, even the bleakest of books can be feminist if they revolve around a woman's strength (the movie Volver is my favourite example of this.) Yes, Sylvia Plath depicts the hypocrisy and incomprehension of men, particularly through Esther's first doctor, to the point where the novel borders on misandry; however, Esther also has a dislike of all people (with the exception of Dr. Nolan, who might be one of my favourite supporting characters ever), which makes it difficult to see this, and Esther's determination not to help herself, although I am well aware that this was probably a feature of Esther's depression and she should not be blamed for it, does undermine the whole "one woman against a corrupt and brutal system" conflict that feminists seem to play out. Also, to me, The Bell Jar is a novel about one woman's fundamental weaknesses and failures. Is it called feminist because it dealt with a very taboo subject? Granted, Plath/Esther (the two blur for me, since The Bell Jar is so blatantly autobiographical) has a horrible time in her first round of the much-reviled electroshock therapy, but her condition seems to improve after the first round. There's no real scathing take on mental institutions here. This isn't a novel about feminism. This is a novel about a woman. And there is nothing wrong with that. Four stars for excellent execution.

“But I wasn't sure. I wasn't sure at all. How did I know that someday―at college, in Europe, somewhere, anywhere―the bell jar, with its stifling distortions, wouldn't descend again?”“To the person in the bell jar, blank and stopped as a dead baby, the world itself is a bad dream.” The main character, Esther Greenwood’s descent into depression and eventual nervous breakdown is made even more tragic by the author’s suicide in 1963. That makes her insights into Esther even more poignant. In ‘The Bell Jar’ after entering a fashion magazine contest, Esther wins, along with eleven other girls, a month in New York. The girls attend parties and are feted, all while writing articles on a deadline. Suddenly the world is tumultuous for Esther, and not in a good way. The Rosenbergs are dominating the news and Esther’s thoughts. ‘The Bell Jar’ descends and Esther feels numb, empty, while her friends are excited and experiencing new adventures with enthusiasm. As the book progresses, Esther has a lot of anxiety about losing her virginity (it needs to be done), children (a maybe boyfriend, Buddy Willard, shows her babies preserved in glass bottles and she observes a childbirth including an episiotomy), and her direction in life (she seems to have lost hers). Plath plots Esther’s descent in a precise cocktail of paranoia and suicidal ideations. It is unnerving to read of two suicide attempts in one day, but in which her body thwarts her manuvers . There are moments of lightness and hilarity, and prose that is poetic. I listened to the audiobook narrated by Maggie Gyllenhaal, and I thought her voice suited the character perfectly. Esther comes across as both an old soul and incredibly immature, but always edgy, smart, many times with a caustic wit. I can understand why “The Bell Jar” has become an American classic. Women can be put in their place (whatever that is) by someone describing them as neurotic. Esther thinks, “If neurotic is wanting two mutually exclusive things at one and the same time, then I’m neurotic as hell.” Esther thinks “I never want to get married,” and “the trouble was, I hated the idea of serving men in any way. I wanted to dictate my own thrilling letters.” How freeing is that? And why shouldn’t Esther? And why shouldn’t we?

The Bell Jar is a novel that has two parts: the first part concerns a career girl striking out in the big city for a fashion magazine. The second half details her mental breakdown and consequent admission into several sanitariums. The novel is legendary among many and considered a modern women’s classic. I’m pretty absent from that camp; in fact I don’t even think it’s a terribly well written book. Part 1 where our hero Esther Greenwood tries to take Manhattan by storm is a fairly dull account of her working for a fashion magazine, a career that should be pretty exciting (especially in 1963), but Sylvia Plath chooses to describe luncheon after luncheon, lovingly describing the grotesque food Esther and her friends gorge on. There’s virtually no mention of fashion whatsoever. Another popular topic is how disgusting all men are, either geeky spineless jellyfish or debonair, rich boys proffering jewels with date rape on their minds. There are tens of thousands of boys in Manhattan and these were the only types she could hook up with? Loser.Part 2 has our hero experiencing her breakdown after losing her job and tossing her clothes over the balcony of her posh dorm apartment. Her breakdown actually happens abruptly with virtually no real rhyme or reason. Her motivation for suicide has no real initiative other than the fact that she had writers block. Welcome to the literary world, Princess. Although she licks her wounds back in her hamlet of Connecticut all of her friends still accept her and even invite her to still hang out with them, which she promptly refuses. She’s not crazy, she’s just a bitch.And a racist bitch at that. Every simile used to describe her disheveled appearance employs ethnic groups, i.e. “I looked like an old Chinese woman”, “I looked in the mirror and saw a fat Indian lady”. Plath’s Caucasian snobbery would make George Orwell and Ernest Hemingway blush. Considering the overindulgence and obnoxious sense of privilege Esther Greenwood had the whole book should make me blush. The best thing to do would be to throw it away.

This book is HEAVY! Sylvia Plath definitely knew how to equate depression to words. Too many painful books in a row for me. I am definitely due for a lighter read. For such a classic novel, it still feels as though the twists and turns of Esther's mind are just as relevant today as they were in the 1960s when this was initially published. It is nearly impossible not to feel empathetic toward Esther throughout the pages. Still, sometimes, the writing method can lead to confusion and needing to go back and re-read specific passages as I feel I missed something. I genuinely think Plath did this purposely, though.Solid 4 Stars

This book did not grip me the way I expected it would. Had I read this when I was younger or when I have not yet read other descent-to-madness books, I would have appreciated it more. Topping the list for me in this kind of sub-genre is Elias Canetti's Auto-da-Fé (4 stars) with a male protagonist or Jean Rhys' Good Morning, Midnight (3 stars) with a female protagonist. I am not an expert on literature because I am a mere reader but I think The Bell Jar is inferior in imparting the exact mood that is an important ingredient in this kind of story.Esther Greenwood (Sylvia Plath since this is a semi-autobio) is a 21-y/o lady from Boston who hates his mother. She wins a summer internship at a popular magazine in New York. Her mother sends her a write up on how she can protect her virginity. Since she resents her mother (we don't know why), she goes around looking for a man to deflower her. She does not find one (right away, though) so she becomes lonely. While she is in New York another opportunity (Harvard scholarship in Plath's real life) comes in and she applies. But she is turned down. So, she becomes lonelier and starts contemplating suicide.I will not tell you the rest of the story because that would be too much of a spoiler. Although I have a feeling that more than half of my GR foreigner friends have already read this thin and easy-to-read book. For me this is just about a young woman who is sick in the head and we have this book because she has a knack on writing. Take one of those and we don't have this book.Plath, better known as a good poet, incorporates many heart-tugging poetic lines like "The silence depressed me. It wasn't the silence of silence. It was my own silence" but I thought they were too few to effect the right mood. I guess it's is also because Esther (Plath) tells you directly that she is sad rather than not talking at all but you feel sad for her. That's what I appreciated that Jean Rhys's work (the female protagonist there just wanders around the hotel alone and you can feel her loneliness) more or even Carson McCuller's masterpiece: The Heart is a Lonely Hunter (4 stars) that for me is still the saddest book of them all. Yet, in those books, no character say outright that he/she is sad but you feel for them. While reading you are the one who becomes sad. A kind of sadness that lingers for several days.That is tricky and it is something that I think only older (having experienced more sadness in life) novelists can do. Wait...Plath was 31 when this book was published. McCullers was what? 23! Oh, maybe it should have said "only more brilliant novelists can do."I think many people loved this book because they take pity on what actually happened to Sylvia Plath. Reading those entries in Wiki really made me sad. However, I am reviewing this book and not Wiki. Well, for one, I think Plath did not intend to publish this. She was hesitant of its literary merit. Only those people who wanted to make money out of her misery.And that for me is even sadder.

There is a biblical anecdote - the heart is deceitful and desperately wicked, who can know it- that makes one wonder, and what of the mind? What of the complexities of consciousness and unconsciousness, the intricacies of intellect and intelligence, of sanity and insanity, otherwise known as the mind? What can one make of the deceitfulness of the mind? "Words, dimly familiar but twisted all awry, like faces in a funhouse mirror, fled past, leaving no impression on the glassy surface of my brain." I don't know where to start or end my thoughts about the poignancy of this book, or how to explain its lyrical synapse and distressing penetration of the human psyche, so I'll simply condense my thoughts.It is confounding to see how Esther's mind betrays her. One moment she is hobnobbing with writers and poets, even entertaining at literary shindigs, and the next moment, she is daft: trying to stop the spiral of her mind, a writer fighting to still the pen on a page, fighting to read a sentence. 
I thought the most beautiful thing in the world must be shadow, the million moving shapes and cul-de-sacs of shadow. There was shadow in bureau drawers and closets and suitcases, and shadow under houses and trees and stones, and shadow at the back of people's eyes and smiles, and shadow, miles and miles of it, on the night side of the earth. 
Shadows: darkness or shelter - which was it to her? Read The Journals of Sylvia Plath and you'll soon realize that Esther is Sylvia and Sylvia is Esther. Hidden, within brief snapshots of this novel, are her signature poetic phrases, for Plath was a genius in binding emotion with lyric (Read Ariel -the restored version- and you see her life in verse). Plath "told another friend that she thought of The Bell Jar 'as an autobiographical apprentice work which I had to write in order to free myself from the past.'" Initially, she even published this book under a pseudonym, because she thought it wasn't "serious literary work." If only she were here to see how far it has come in literature, how far it has come in unveiling the psyche.

2.5 starsIt seemed silly to wash one day when I would only have to wash again the next. It made me tired just to think of it. I wanted to do everything once and for all and be through with it.So I finally came around to reading The Bell Jar. In a sense, this book is timeless, since Esther Greenwood's struggles with her mental health are (and probably will be as long as humans exist) very relatable.Where it loses its relevance is in its blatant racism. I lost count of how many times Plath called an array of non-white ethnicities ugly and worse.And even overlooking this gross fact, aside from the pretty prose, there was no enjoyment to be found within these pages.Plath simplifies depression as a constant low, ignoring the fluidity of the mind and the resulting fluctuating moods humans tend to find themselves in. I'm glad I read it, but the first time will remain the last for me.

This famous and often interesting book by Sylvia Plath is not an easy one to write a review of, since the author committed suicide soon after publishing it and the entire second half of the novel is about Esther's time in hospital due to mental illness. Where does one differentiate between the author's own experience and Esther's.The first half of the book I found most interesting, published in 1963, yet taking place in 1953, when Ms Plath would have been on summer break from University doing a placement at a magazine in NYC, when she attended Smith College otherwise.I have wanted to read this classic for a long time, Ms Plath's feminist viewpoint would have been well before its time. But the second half, regarding mental illness, the uneven treatment Esther received, was a difficult slog for me to read. Very interesting and entertaining first half, hard slog in the last half. A few interesting excerpts from the novel, the first when her supposed boyfriend asked her if she would like to see his penis, where she had never seen one before:‘Well, all right, I guess so,’ I said. I stared at Buddy while he unzipped his chino pants and took them off and laid them on a chair and then took off his underpants that were made of something like nylon fishnet. ‘They’re cool,’ he explained, ‘and my mother says they wash easily.’ Then he just stood there in front of me and I kept on staring at him. The only thing I could think of was turkey neck and turkey gizzards and I felt very depressed.The second was a description of a man from the United Nations she was meeting for the first time:OF COURSE, CONSTANTIN WAS MUCH TOO SHORT, but in his own way he was handsome, with light brown hair and dark blue eyes and a lively, challenging expression. He could almost have been an American, he was so tan and had such good teeth, but I could tell straight away that he wasn’t. He had what no American man I’ve ever met has had, and that’s intuition.The final one was when her mother suggested she needed practical skills, not just a University degree:I didn’t know shorthand either. This meant I couldn’t get a good job after college. My mother kept telling me nobody wanted a plain English major. But an English major who knew shorthand was something else again. Everybody would want her. She would be in demand among all the up-and-coming young men and she would transcribe letter after thrilling letter. The trouble was, I hated the idea of serving men in any way. I wanted to dictate my own thrilling letters.So a most interesting read for the most part, yet only enjoyed in the first half for me. 4 stars first half, 2 stars the second for a 3.5 overall, rounded up as it is a classic.

I expected my mind to be blown by this one, but really there was nothing terribly remarkable about it. I won't deny that it's an excellent book, but I wonder if it would have gained the same notoriety, and the same cult status, had Plath not died so young and so soon after its publication.

It was depressing and uplifting at the same time. Maybe, it’s just me, but the beginning of the book has a very YA feel to it. I just felt like pointing that out. Aside from that, I thought this book captured depression really well. I’m aware Sylvia Path experienced severe depression in her life, which gives ‘The Bell Jar’ more credibility in the subject.I think a majority of people expect depression to derive from some traumatic event or accident, but for many it’s subtle before it descends upon the person with full force. Sylvia Path didn’t fully make it clear on what made Esther so gloomy. For me, I think Esther simply begins to question aspects of her life, and essentially, her entire existence, and founds herself unsatisfied with her present and all the types of futures which she imagines for herself. A lot people may say, ‘oh she’s so selfish. Doesn’t she know others have it worse than her?’ Sylvia Path addresses this train of thought in the book. Although Esther knew other people had it worse than her, it never soothed her depression. I think Esther simply finds her life to be hollow, meaningless, repetitive, planned out (getting married and having children). There was no sense of a solid purpose to her life. I think this strong realisation must have slowly propelled her to depression and insanity. That’s how I interpret the novel anyway. I understand that people find Esther to be quite self-centred. After all, she is a middle class, straight-A student from a good home. However, I don’t see how that leaves her out from experiencing depression. I believe depression is universal. It doesn’t have to be triggered by the loss of someone or some terrible accident or event. It can be triggered by hopelessness, uncertainty and range of other emotions. This was even apparent in Hamlet by Shakespeare, which I read recently. Although some might argue that Hamlet’s desire for suicide may stem solely from his father’s death, it is evident throughout the play that it’s the little purpose which Hamlet feels in his life that drives his depression and insanity just as much. I also like how this book doesn’t overdramatise Esther’s descent into depression and insanity like so many movies and books do with their characters. All in all, I found it very enjoyable and interesting.

Роман заканчивается благополучно, хотя истинная судьба писательницы и поэтессы была трагическая, через несколько месяцев месяцев после его выхода, она покончила с собой, и это ужасает. Что послужило триггером для проявления психического заболевания у героини романа? Неудачи в творчестве, непризнание публики, неполучение стипендии, необходимость постоянно быть первой и получать высшие оценки? Можно ли было предотвратить такой трагический конец? Почему вообще люди добровольно уходят из жизни? С чем они не могут справиться самостоятельно, и может ли общество и окружающие им помочь?Книга ценна тем, что она основана на реальных переживаниях реального человека, ценна, как для психиатров, психологов, так и просто людей, которые не совсем понимают, в чем проблема – это то реальное отображение проблем души (именно отображение, а не понимание, ибо сама Плат так не нашла выхода в мучившем ее состоянии, и в книге нет понимания, есть просто описание, и довольно сумбурное), здоровым это нужно, для того, чтобы понять и принять. Она поднимает проблему стигматизации людей с ментальным здоровьем. Ее героиня не хочет говорить своему ухажеру, что она лечится в клинике. Для 1950-х ее феминистские идеи о том, что место женщины не ограничивается домашним очагом, о добрачных сексуальных отношениях, были вызовом, поэтому тоже можно отметить, как достижение.Стеклянный колпак – очень удачная метафора, это не только относится к психиатрии, но и к концепции восприятия себя во взаимодействии с миром и гармонизируется с понятием «стеклянный потолок», то невидимое препятствие, которое не дает возможности расти и двигаться в полную мощь твоих сил.Сам роман довольно прост, безыскусен и даже где-то примитивен, особенно в первой части, там, где развлечения, показы мехов и прочие элементы массовой культуры и культуры потребительского общества.К сожалению, я не знала, кто такая Сильвия Плат – на постсоветском пространстве она не так популярна и известна. Большую помощь мне оказал обзор Petra https://www.goodreads.com/review/show... , за что я ей благодарна. Я нашла два варианта русского перевода стихотворения «Папуля»/»Папа», посвященное ее отцу, который имеет непозволительные метафоры.

The Bell Jar by Sylvia Plath is a book that I had on my real life shelf for a long time and finally got around to reading it. I really found this novel a dramatic and touching read. The book follows the in depth struggle of a young woman called Esther Greenwood. Esther Greenwood, the protagonist of the story, is a mentally unstable young woman and she gradually slips into a dark depression while living in New York. She is tormented with the idea of death and tries to commit suicide, believing that death is freedom.I found the prose style deceptively simple. The novel is written using a series of flashbacks that show up parts of Esther's past which makes the reader connect very easily with this story. The Character of Esther is really well drawn and her experiences were real and meaningful.I am glad to have finally read The Bell Jar and I feel that it gave me a little perspective on mental illness that I had previously lacked.A four star read.
