such an essential read!!

I really wish I had read this book back in college when I could have related so much more to Esther's character. Scenes like where she fed her clothes out to the wind or pondered moving out to Chicago with nothing but a fake identity or more than anything stood invisible in the shadows as she watched her neighbor cross her house, I could see myself (feel myself) in her at that age. If I had read this when I was in college, I would have seen myself in Esther and wondered if I had the potential to go mad. I connected to the immensity of Esther's young, somewhat selfish, poignantly observant, and fatalistically driven character. What struck me as odd and yet familiar was the almost obsessive randomness of her actions--rituals that held no emotional attachment but she followed through to attach herself to something as if it made her look normal. At one point Esther mentioned in passing something about her childhood and it felt so honest and real that I felt that she were real, or that Plath were sharing a part of herself with me. It's what makes Esther's character so three-dimensional and I don't know that I can separate Esther and Plath. I loved the eloquent description and her fabulous metaphors. I wish I had marked them because they happened in the beginning when Esther was lucid and by the end I had forgotten them. The strongest is the image of depression (or mental illness) being like looking at the world through a distorted, suffocating bell jar, very powerful. I took this route with Esther as all hope and ambition failed her and she hung all her self esteem on an acceptance letter and when that failed, she had nothing else holding her up. I could relate to that, to postponing depression to a fixed event.I was almost disappointed with the second half because I wanted to feel the madness in Esther, but it wasn't crazy, it was depression, cold, languid, mind-numbing depression. Plath stops describing the the backdrop to the scenes, stops analyzing, stops telling us how Esther feels. I felt gypped, that I had connected with Esther and then she didn't feel real to me anymore, until I realized that just like Esther quit showering and changing her clothes, she quit describing her world to me. And when she started feeling again, I knew she would be alright. I love the unknown at the end. I don't need to know what Esther does because Plath already showed me that she was seeing the world again, without the bell jar.It's a beautifully written novel. I know I love psychology and would have loved it anyway, but that part was so quiet, it was the poetic description and a very real Esther that made me like the book—or maybe the fact that I like to read about crazy people. I tried not to think about Plath committing suicide as I read the book, but it was there, not because it made the book morbidly fascinating, but because it made it raw. I can see Plath writing this novel as her own therapy with Esther as a thinly veiled version of herself. I just don't know what to do with the unemotional description of depression and the hope for recovery other than believe Plath wanted to be better, to be happy and maybe through Esther she could see that for herself even if she never got there.

Qual animal amestrado, num circo ou jardim zoológico, também o ser humano, pensando ser livre no seu quotidiano, se vê aprisionado entre normas e políticas, que orientam - ou restringem - os seus passos. E, ao contrário de uma gaiola, cujas frestas permitem a passagem de um ar renovado - na medida do possível -, em muitos casos, esta prisão é tão asfixiante como uma redoma, invisível como o vidro. É possível vislumbrar o presente ao redor - e até ficar maravilhado com isso - mas, a determinando momento, o colapso desce sobre os réus, fruto de um sufoco letal. Inicia-se então um estado de obnubilação. Esther parecia fascinada com a sua existência de boneca. Uma educação à medida do estatuto de "boa senhora", divertimento ajustado a esta condição e um mar de sonhos, em que poderia navegar à deriva. No entanto, esta bolha fascinante, de tão frágil, acaba por rebentar e o naufrágio esperado ocorre por fim, antecedendo a destruição previsível. Como um copo antes da queda, é notória a quebra que a narrativa sofre a meio, quando o leitor assume o papel de fiel testemunha de uma descida aos infernos, num vórtex que o impede de sublinhar frases - passa a pairar nos pensamentos alheios. Assiste, pois, ao desmoronar de uma vida de leilão, desvirtuada de personalização, que vai passando de mão em mão, sem nunca se manter naquelas em que deveria - as da própria. De uma mente conturbada, não se espera mais que um fluxo de consciência emaranhado, sem princípio nem fim. Numa fuga de ideias, são esmiuçados alguns assuntos prementes que merecem discussão: a misoginia, a insatisfação, o derrotismo, o suicídio. Sorvendo as gotas rubras de um enredo familiar à própria autora, este é um romance (biográfico!?) que faz brotar uma empatia tenebrosa, suscitando angústia a cada folhear. Um sufoco passível de ser transformado em novo fôlego quando o idílico fino cristal se quebra - e uma brisa revigorante afaga o corpo mutilado."Se ser neurótica é querer duas coisas que se excluem mutuamente, então sou uma neurótica acabada. Vou passar o resto dos meus dias a voar de uma coisa para outra."

For the past five years I've been reading through all the classics in chronological order, and one of the exciting things that's happened as I get closer to today is that for some more recent authors, their echoes are really loud and clear. A guy like Odysseus, he echoes all over the place but the echoes are all changed and weird because it's been a while. But Plath was writing recently enough, and her voice is powerful enough, that you still hear her distinctly through people like Lena Dunham or the mighty Allie Brosh. Her attitude, her bleak humor, her mannerisms have all been transmitted through and you can feel it in a sort of tangible way that's really fun to pick up on.I know the whole echo discussion gets a little wonky because it's not like Sylvia Plath isn't borrowing from Dorothy Parker, who was probably borrowing from Edith Wharton, and so on. I don't mean to imply that she's standing around being depressed all by herself. But I do think that once in a while someone comes along whose voice is so distinctive that it changes the way people talk for a while. David Foster Wallace is an example, and Sylvia Plath is another one, and this book is great.

This book is very dated but is actually more interesting because of it. This story takes place 65 years ago and is a little time capsule of horrors. I’m old enough to have caught a whiff of the 50’s and suffered through the required (for girls) high school shorthand and Home Economics classes (Home Ec being the only class I ever skipped, which should tell you something about me) and sadly, I did know some older girls who went to college to “catch” husbands. For the most part, though, I’m very much a product of the 60’s and 70’s and the rise of feminism and self-determination. The very thought of being condescended to or being subservient to a man makes me bristle. This book is actually an acute and merciless portrait of a young woman’s descent into depression (the airless “bell jar” of the title) but I kept getting snagged on all of the socio-economic things going on in the periphery. We have a long way to go for sure on changing the stigma around mental illnesses, but after reading this book, I am reminded how far we have already come in those 65 years. I feel strongly that Sylvia Plath might be alive today had she had access to an appropriate diagnosis and the treatments available now for depression. It makes me sick to think about how she must have suffered.So, modern young ladies of the 21st century, read this and be amazed. The world has changed in many dark and evil ways, but it has also changed for the better. This book reminded me of that, and although it really pissed me off at times, I am so glad I read it.Oh, and by the way, this book is beautifully written. Plath is first and foremost a poet, and the writing is very strong. Esther Greenwood's narration is keenly observant and as sharp as a skewer – of course, Sylvia Plath IS Esther Greenwood, but still.I can’t say I loved it – it’s not a book to love – but it sure got under my skin. Read it and weep.

4.5/5Depresija turi tiek veidų, kiek yra ja sergančiųjų. Vieni iš jų guli lovoje. Verkia į pagalvę. Negali tinkamai funkcionuoti, o milžinišku darbu tampa plaukų išsišukavimas, ką jau bekalbėti apie jų išsiplovimą. Kiti eina į vakarėlius. Ir ne tik į juos. Dar ir į universitetą, draugų susibūrimus, pasibuvimus su tėvais. Jie nešasi depresiją su savimi visur, kur tik eina, ją slepia už šypsenos. Ar net garsaus juoko. Gerų pažymių ir kitų pasiekimų. Jie susipažįsta su merginomis. Ar vaikinais. Ar tiesiog tais, kurie jiems įdomūs. Jie nesiskundžia apetitu (ar nesiskundžia apskritai), gal net visai neblogai miega. Nori sukurti santykius. Arba jų paniškai bijo, bet tuo pat metu baimę bando nugalėti nerdami į draugystes – romantines, platoniškas ir tokias, ant kurių tiesiog negalima užklijuoti jokios etiketės. Sylvia Plath parodo, kad depresija gali būti visokia. Ir kiek reikalinga suprasti tuos pirmuosius, tiek pat reikalinga suprasti ir tuos, kurių skausmas ne visada akivaizdus, ne visada savaime aiškus. Nes nors kančios ir neįmanoma pamatuoti, ją lengva, per lengva pražiūrėti. Ypač jei vadovaujiesi tik nuogirdomis ir stereotipais.Viena įdomiausių šios knygos dalių man tapo tai, jog Plath rašo taip, kaip žmogus rašytų sau, dienoraštyje, kurio niekas neperskaitys - nebandydama apsimesti protingesne, įdomesne, gilesne nei kad yra iš tiesų. Prieš save ir skaitytoją ji stovi nuoga – o tai tikriausiai vienintelis būdas bent kiek arčiau priartėti prie sergančiojo. Tuo pat metu autorė atskleidžia aplinkos dviveidiškumą – tariamų draugų, gydytojų, artimųjų, netgi pačios Amerikos. Nes jeigu gydome sergančiuosius tuo pačiu būdu, kuriuo žudome šalies išdavikus, tik šiek tiek sumažindami elektros srovę, apie kokią pažangą iš tiesų galime kalbėti? Plath parodo, kad dažnai sergančiajam tenka susidurti ne tik su savo paties stiklo gaubtu, slegiančiu pečius, bet ir padėti nešti naštą aplinkiniams – tiems, kurie prisidengę rūpesčiu, iš tiesų tiesiog bando išsiaiškinti kokia yra tikimybė, jog savo vardą pamatys savižudžio raštelyje. Vietoje to, kad ieškotų pagalbos, dažnas tiesiog ieško tiesos – ką padariau ne taip, kad artimasis taip kenčia? Vis dėlto, su sau įprasta, kiek ciniška šypsena, Sylvia tarp eilučių palieka atsakymą susirasti pačiam skaitytojui – ar toks klausimas kyla iš noro padėti? Suprasti? Ar tiesiog pačiam miegoti ramiau?„Stiklo gaubtu“ mėgautis sunku, tačiau perskaityti – ypač reikalinga. Ypač tiems, kurie kitose knygose apie depresiją, tokiose kaip „Prozako karta“, „Girl, Interrupted“, „Atskalūno laiškai“, „Aštrūs pjūviai“ šimtuose, tūkstančiuose kitų, jautėsi kiek atstumti – neaprašyti, nereprezentuoti, neatskleisti. Klausimų dėl to, ar „Stiklo gaubtas“ yra apie depresiją, tikriausiai nekyla absoliučiai niekam. Tačiau džiaugiuosi galėdama joje rasti šiek tiek daugiau tokios depresijos, kurią tiek metų pažįstu aš. Galbūt Sylvios sukurta Estera dažnai veidrodyje ir nuotraukose neatpažino savęs, tačiau save atpažinau aš. Ir dėl to jaučiuosi beprotiškai dėkinga.

مرة أخرى، ننزلق إلى البئر المظلمة التي يسمونها الاكتئاب. نحن كقراء ننزل ونحن متشبثون بحبل أمان، بمجرد أن نرغب بالخروج منها فإننا نغلق ��لكتاب لنعود إلى الهواء الطلق، ننعم بضوء الشمس. ولكن ماذا عن الذين سقطوا في البئر في حياتهم الواقعية والله وحده يعلم كم سيلبثون فيها؟هذه المرة مع سيلفيا بلاث، رواية منسوجة حول سيرتها الذاتية ومعاناتها مع الاكتئاب وربما متلازمة ثنائية القطب. نظرياً تنقسم الرواية إلى قسمين، الأول يصف حياة الشابة إستر وهي في الهواء الطلق، تمارس حياة عادية مليئة بردود الأفعال والطموحات والمخاوف المعتادة. يتسم القسم الأول بتعدد المشاهد والشخصيات المرسومة بنبرة ساخرة لا غبار عليها. أجواء لطيفة يعيشها القارئ بين مجموعة من الفتيات اللواتي يتدربن في إحدى مجلات الأزياء، و ما تلك المقدمة إلا أرضية زلقة تهوي بك في الحفرة القادمة قبل أن تستعد.لأسباب مفهومة وغير مفهومة، تصاب الفتاة باكتئاب حاد، يعرفه من جربه أو رافق أحد المصابين به. ذلك القفص غير المرئي، قضبانه الحزن واللامبالاة والتشوش والخوف. يسجننا الكتاب في الزنزانة الفردية مع إستر التي تحاول أن تجد مخرجاً سريعاً من حياتها، ونتنقل معها في أروقة مستشفيات الأمراض النفسية، نزور مختلف الأطباء ونتعرض للصدمات الكهربائية.مثل "الظلام المرئي"، نجد أن الكاتبة هنا قد فصّلت مسيرتها العلاجية، بين ما أفادها وما ألحق بها الضرر. من الجيد أن الرواية قدمت العلاج الكهربائي لمثل هذه الحالات بصورة واقعية، بعيدًا عن الطرح الخرافي الذي تتحفنا به السينما والتلفزيون.كونها شاعرة ومصابة بالاكتئاب –في الحقيقة انتحرت بعد صدور الكتاب بشهر – فقد توقعت كتابًا أكثر دقة في الوصف وأعمق تأثيرًا. يظل الكتاب شمعة مضيئة لمن يبحثون عن مخرج، فربما أعطى لهم قبساً من أمل في قعر ذلك البئر السحيق.

Even though Sylvia Plath is an incredible poet, this novel is melodramatic in the worst way. Esther Greenwood pretends to be artistic and eccentric and cynical and macabre but she really isn't. She's just a normal girl who's irrationally bored. Not even depressed. Just too white, too privileged, doesn't know what to do with herself bored. Ironically pre-housewife housewife bummed out, as she fears will happen if she becomes a housewife. And this novel is a huge snooze fest. Other than a very minor inner/psychological conflict, nothing happens in this book. She's a great student and earns an all-expenses paid internship at a fashion magazine in fucking Manhattan, eats caviar and crab and cream cheese-filled avocados, goes to clubs, can't bring herself to just fuck someone and lose her virginity, throws all her clothes out of her hotel room window and goes to her mother's big house in Connecticut where she has a nervous breakdown and sees a therapist. She's like a mopey, boring version of Gatsby. This was so sedentary and predictable and earned absolutely no empathy from me. I have never been so disappointed in a novel. And it's her only one.

Not so much of a review, just a note to confirm that after years of trying, I give up. I can see that The Bell Jar is an intelligent and, for its time, courageous venture into issues of relationship, the perception of women in western society, the taboo of mental health, the medieval treatment of mental health issues, the classification of non-conformist identity as mental illness, and other topics that clearly needed to be discussed at the time when Plath wrote the book - and still need to be discussed.  No, my issues are not with the book as a work of social record. What I am giving up on after years of trying different samples of her work is Plath's writing - it does nothing for me and I found it a bit of a tedious slog to finally finish the book based on one of the whiniest characters in history.

Increíblemente perturbador y realista. Y solo el hecho de pensar que es autobiográfico me pone los pelos de punta. El libro nos narra el deterioro de la autoestima de Esther. Esther, obtiene una beca para una estancia de un mes en Nueva York. Decepcionada y asustada por la vida que se suponía una mujer debía llevar, en aquella época, reniega de esta. Cae en una terrible depresión huyendo de estas convenciones sociales tan disparatas y fuera de sus deseos. Lo dicho, me ha impactado muchísimo. Y cuando conoces la historia de la autora posterior al libro, más aún. Lástima que sea su única novela.

‘I knew I should feel grateful…only I couldn’t feel a thing….a ticket to Europe, or a round-the-world cruise, it wouldn’t have made one scrap of difference to me, because wherever I sat - on the deck of a ship or at a street cafe in Paris or Bangkok - I would be sitting under the same glass bell jar, stewing in my own sour air.’Plath’s life and art are irreparably fused and revisiting ‘The Bell Jar’ after forty years leads me straight to her inner core - claustrophobic, unsparing, relentless. Her sole (surviving) full-length work of fiction will flare and fuel the Plath myth for the generations ahead and is a crucial key to her poems and journals.

2015: The Year of Reading Women

США, 1950-ті. Після 40-х, коли чоловіки пішли на війну, й тому жінки отримали доступ до багатьох недосяжних їм доти сфер (від університетських аудиторій до заводських цехів), пішов відкат, аби звільнити ці робочі місця назад, і виникає дуже прескриптивна у порівнянні навіть з попередніми десятиліттями модель фемінності. І от на цьому тлі є головна героїня - їй 19, вона хоче стати письменницею, вона отримує особисту стипендію у престижному коледжі й виграє "золотий квиток" - літнє стажування при модних журналах у Нью-Йорку. Здавалося б, історія успіху, американська мрія, оце от усе. Але американська мрія ніяк не конфігурує із тими жіночими долями, які винесено на перший план у тому десятилітті, бодай для головної героїні. Для неї це або/або - або творчість, або родина, і т.д., постійно наголошується її неготовність обирати, адже будь-який вибір є відмовою від нескінченності інших альтернатив, і тому замість обрати якесь одне життя - менше, ніж множина потенційних життів, але більше, ніж небуття - вона обирає таки небуття, сповзає все глибше в депресію і спроби самогубства. (Хоча насправді не беруся робити ставки, що первинне, а що вторинне - депресія чи нездатність знайти собі нішу між прескриптивних моделей, бо жіночі історії успіху на фоні є, і то в доволі різних конфігураціях, що не виключають ворк-лайф балансу, від заміжньої редактори успішного журналу до лесбійської пари поетки й професорки). В кінці героїня нібито виходить із психлікарні, але умовність цього геппі-енду підкреслена не лише нашими позатекстовими знаннями про біографію Сильвії Плат, а й мимохідною фразою при початку, єдиною, здається, всередині тексту вказівкою на те, що розповідь ретроспективна - головна героїня бере сувенір із того стажування, яке мало стати початком її історії успіху як мисткині, і відламує від нього зірку на іграшку дитині. (Про жіночу творчість там є ще один стрьомний епізод: мати бойфренда головної героїні довго і старанно виплітає красивий килимок, але він не стає арт-об'єктом, а лягає під ноги на кухні, де його ніхто не помічає і швидко затоптують, з тим же успіхом килимок можна було купити дешево в магазині й не морочитися. Цей епізод із відламаною зіркою вказує, що творча біографія головної героїні пішла якимось таким же руслом).З одного боку, я розумію, чому у книжки культовий статус: вона однією з перших артикулює цей пласт жіночого досвіду не як ідилію, а як трагедію. І від того, як багато лишилося, mutatis mutandis, актуальним і зараз, жаскувато. Але суб'єктивно я цей роман не люблю (це вже вдруге перечитую, вперше читала років вісім тому в універі) - це все настільки близько і впізнавано, що виглядає банальним, ми з цим текстом на тій дистанції, яка не дозволяє бачити в цьому естетичний, а не документальний артефакт. А українське видання просто казкове! По-перше, дуже добрий переклад Ольги Любарської, по-друге, пекельно прекрасні ілюстрації, які створюють чимало доданої вартості (Анастасія Стефурак про оформлення книжки) - тиранія рожевеньких радісних кольорів, головна героїня як порожній силует і т.д., казково.А рецензія пера Ганни Улюри - найкраще, що я читала про цей текст.

Sigurno ste iskusili da vam se prostor kojim putujete stopi sa knjigom koju ste tokom putovanja čitali. Sasvim neobični spojevi nisu tu ni retkost ni iznenađenje, pa mene, eto, čitanje Silvije Plat vezuje za Mirijevo, gde sam, igrom slučaja, pre nekoliko meseci išao gotovo svake nedelje. Moj kindl je bio dovoljno ljubazan da me sasvim fino služi u tom kretanju koje je podrazumevalo promenu čak tri autobusa do odredišta. Prošlo je, bogami, oko tri meseca od kad sam knjigu pročitao i moj sadašnji komentar je skoro pa eksperiment jer, ukoliko nešto želim da napišem ovde, to uradim najbrže što mogu, dok se utisci ne ohlade. Odugovlačio sam zato što sam shvatio da želim da kažem nešto novo, važno i lepo, pa sam se, razmišljajući o perspektivi, usporio, što je izbrisalo mnoge detalje koje sam hteo da istaknem. Ali ono što i sad ječi su superiorne rečenice – jednostavne, oštre i lirski gipke i jedna jezivo ubedljiva teskoba koja poručuje da depresija nije nasilna izbezumljenost, nego gašenje. Pitanje je da li postoji išta strašnije od toga – osećaj potpunog nedostatka volje, tonjenja, besmislenosti, omašenosti. Osećaj da je neko manji od nule, utvare, ljušture. Osećaj da nema više čak da se ljušti, da se usitnjava, raščlanjuje, sve je gotovo i sve je splaslo, ravno, mučno ravno. Beznadežno je. A iako je muka beskrajna, dodatan očaj izaziva što nema čak ni anksioznosti. Život postaje privremeni i nestalni dogovor sa disanjem, koji svakom prilikom može da bude prekinut, gde ni bol ne može pomoći. Imati makar i trunčicu ovakvog raspoloženja može biti razarajuće, a onaj ko se nađe u njemu preplavljen, često i ne ispliva. I ta okolnost nije vezana samo za kontekst nečijeg života, iako je on svakako važan, već za neku unutrašnju osetljivost koja je teško objašnjiva. Preživljavali su ljudi najgore košmare, pa je ipak volja za samoodržanjem pobedila, dok su neki ljudi sa relativno povoljnim ili sasvim povoljnim životnim uslovima bili beskrajno nesrećni. Ester Grinvud nije isplivala. Silvija Plat nije isplivala.Složenost mogućih razloga potonuća čini ovu knjigu klasikom američke književnosti. Ništa, zapravo, nije moglo da bude izbegnuto, koliko god delovalo da je izlaz moguć. Trenutno mi bubnji u glavi predstavljanje tela u romanu, pogotovo ženskog tela i delikatan odnos između Ester i Badija, koji je oličenje onoga što bi se od muškarca poželeti moglo u onovremenoj Americi. A želelo se, i tada i danas, licemerje i plivanje po površini. Lepa, ugodna fasada, u kojoj vlada lom i džiklja korov. Ester je zarobljena u staklenom zvonu ne iz kakve prezaštićenosti, komfora, nego iz nemogućnosti da zaista dopre do bilo koga. I mada može zvučati prefinjeno, stakleno zvono je surovo, čvrsto i neko ko je u njemu nema kiseonika. Izolujući, gnječi.Ali nakon svega, pitanje koje se nameće je koliko „Stakleno zvono”, nakon više meseci čitanja, i dalje ječi, a koliko bih ja voleo da je to tako. Bez obzira na sve, voleo bih da verujem u gorki talog koji je ostao, kao što često nakon čitanja, kroz filter vremena, ostaju samo neodređeni i opšti utisci.

Going into The Bell Jar I expected immediate immersion into a world of gloom followed by the incessant whining that often accompanies that world. Those of you who have read Prozac Nation know exactly what I mean. What else should I have expected from a woman who committed suicide by putting her head in an oven?Perhaps that is why I put it off reading this classic for so long. Yet to my pleasant surprise, the novel opens on a high note describing a young Esther Greenwood in the midst of a summer internship working for a fashion magazine in New York City. We find Esther to be extremely intelligent and analytical if somewhat detached. Plath endears us to Esther through her wit—she takes very little at face value and her whimsical cynicism is strangely charming.Through the first third of the novel, I couldn’t help but imagine her as Capote’s Holly Golightly before she became a top-shelf prostitute (forgetting, of course, all that we learn about Golightly’s past later in the novel). Smart in looks and mind, she maintains an air of fetching naiveté and entitlement, and I fell for her just like Plath wanted me to.It is only after Esther has our affection and sympathy that Plath sends her into the downward spiral that she herself experienced. We track Esther’s illness as she contends with a boyfriend she despises, superficial friends, mental institutions and an obsession to lose her virginity. I found this to be a very real depiction of depression, no doubt due to the autobiographical nature of the novel. Often people associate depression with sadness or some upsetting external issue. Yet as we learn through Esther’s descent, apathy and fatigue are very real culprits and are often seen instead as character defects.The Bell Jar gives us insight into Plath’s particular brand of depression as well as any biography on her could. It is not a cheerful read but has several moments of humor and levity that make it bearable to one not inclined to read a book on this subject.

In case anybody wonders why no stars: Firstly, it is extremely hard to assign "stars" to a work of fiction this idolized and a heroine this iconicized. I have always thought that reviews tell you a LOT more than 'stars' do, because in a simplistic system like that of Goodreads, who knows what the person assigned the stars for.I have various reasons to reject this text on a personal level, but also various reasons to commend it on a public level.The good thing that this novel did, was to highlight how women were still being trivialized in spite of pro-feminist window dressing, such as sending women to "special" all-girl schools where the work they did was trivial compared to a man's share.The novel also highlights how dysfunctional family relationships were at the time, and how inadequate mental care was.Also, as pointed out by a friend who lived in a similar era as the author did, there was great societal stigma attached to any kind of mental illness including depression, and it therefore took some bravery for the author to have published this - I suppose some see bravery and some see victimhood - who am I to judge, though? Whatever the case may be, the novel does illustrate why this was/is a problem....so since there are certainly quite a few things I would commend this novel for, then why the reluctance to assign stars? Well, the thing is that there is a Sylvia Plath admiration club cult out there, and I do not want to identify as one of them.Personal reasons for that are discussed with GR friends in the comments section.

Such a talented young woman lost too soon. Sylvia gives us the birds eye view into the depths of madness, underneath the Bell Jar. At times funny. And more times shattered with doubt and with her view of the sexual inequality between men and women. It’s amazing that she lasted as long as she did considering her thoughts about and attempts at suicide. The Bell Jar is her legacy as well as her poems. An amazing read!

Her voice was whinny and I didn't like the way she did the characters' voices nor the way she read the dialog. Her reading of this was very choppy. I got the feeling that she didn't enjoy doing it. 3.5This edition contains a foreword written by Frances McCullough, one of the early champions of Plath’s writings at Harper. In the foreword, McCullough details the publishing history of this novel and how, and why, as to the when, it finally came to be published in the U.S. The “biographical note” about Plath, written by Lois Ames, concentrates on Plath’s life, instead of on her death, which I appreciated.As soon as I started reading this (it’s a reread but I barely remembered it), I thought of Shirley Jackson, especially her less famous Hangsaman*, with its doubling and search for individuation. Though Jackson was significantly older, she and Plath seem to be writing about (or during) the same time period, and their themes share similarities: the conflicting desires and messages a young woman has and receives from convention, dictated in the form of mothers, or mother-figures; how these can develop into anxieties, neuroses, and breakdowns, both mental and physical. Both Jackson and Plath can be (maybe surprisingly) very funny, though the humor dwindles, appropriately, as their stories continue. Both writers refused to look away from the consequences of topics that were taboo during their times, including the double-standard surrounding sex and the shame of mental illness. The latter, as related to marriage, the ultimate goal even for someone like Esther, who was driven and accomplished at a young age, is broached in the final pages.As soon as I finished the book, I didn’t want to leave the time period and its issues, and I immediately started reading a biography of Shirley Jackson*. As soon as I came upon the name of Sylvia Plath in its introduction, I had to reread the sentence, thinking I must’ve conjured it into being.**Addendum (added 4/28/20)From Shirley Jackson: A Rather Haunted Life by Ruth Franklin, Chapter 2; an endnote credits Linda Wagner-Martin's Sylvia Plath: A Biography, page 97 for this information:Sylvia Plath--whose novel The Bell Jar, which also depicts a young woman's breakdown, was likely influenced by Hangsaman...(Plath who also struggled with her relationship with a domineering mother, admired Jackson and hoped to meet her during a summer internship at Mademoiselle in 1953.)

They call it a breakdown. "'We'll act as if all this were a bad dream.'A bad dream.To the person in the bell jar, blank and stopped as a dead baby, the world itself is a bad dream." It's a story like any other one in many ways. It has a main character (not really a hero), there are some anecdotes told, some feelings elaborated on, some other characters described. But unlike many stories out there, it's not really about cherishing life and its pleasures. Through the eyes of the writer, anything people might consider romantic or beautiful seem to be gloomy or meaningless. And it appears that she tries hard to sound indifferent but I don't think this is the case. She describes her surroundings in so much detail and judges everything and everyone through the profuse use of adjectives. In a way, she feels like a lonely outsider, a stranger to what keeps others going. But she's very conscious of these others and takes a stance on them.So all in all, it neither discourages you from ending your life nor gives any answers as to why we should continue breathing. It's a well-told account of a sad being's life. And it has a touch of it could also happen to you. At least I felt that way.

This is a poem by Sylvia Plath included after the bookMad Girl's Love SongA villanelleI shut my eyes and all the world drops dead;I lift my lids and all is born again.(I think I made you up inside my head.)The stars go waltzing out in blue and red,And arbitrary blackness gallops in:I shut my eyes and all the world drops dead.I dreamed that you bewitched me into bedAnd sung me moon-struck, kissed me quite insane.(I think I made you up inside my head.)God topples from the sky, hell's fires fade:Exit seraphim and Satan's men:I shut my eyes and all the world drops dead.I fancied you'd return the way you said,But I grow old and I forget your name.(I think I made you up inside my head.)I should have loved a thunderbird instead;At least then spring comes they roar back again.I shut my eyes and all the world drops dead.(I think I made you up inside my head.)

Um romance, um poema, onde, através da personagem Esther Greenwood, Sylvia Plath nos revela a sua alma. Um livro que tem tanto de belo como de triste, que me quebrou e esmagou o coração de tristeza pela menina, presa nas sombras da depressão e da loucura: “Não consigo comer, não consigo dormir, não consigo ler”. “Para a pessoa dentro da campânula, vazia e imóvel como um bébé morto, o próprio mundo não passa de um sonho mau.” Quisera poder acarinhá-la, consolá-la e fazê-la acreditar que há sempre um modo de quebrar a campânula...Doeu “sentir” a dor de Esther/Sylvia, mas sinto-me privilegiada por fazer parte dos que receberam o presente de “conhecer” uma pessoa tão extraordinária.Enquanto não desenredar o nó que tenho na garganta, não poderei tocar em qualquer outro livro.Sylvia Plath suicidou-se em Fevereiro de 1963, com 31 anos, um mês depois da publicação de “The Bell Jar”.

3.5 stars.This is hard to review, because I read this at a time in my life when I really related to Esther Greenwood, particularly her thoughts at the beginning of the novel. It wasn’t an easy read at all - it’s incredibly bleak, personal and raw in its portrayal of Esther’s decent into depression, and feels (given the author’s history) very real. At times the text feels disjointed, starting at Esther’s time trying to become a successful writer, before quickly descending into abject misery with hospitals and electric shock therapy. You can feel Esther loosing control of her life, her will to live and her ability to care about what happens to her. She’s self destructive, and unlikeable and does questionable things that I could relate to in her quest to try and feel anything. It’s a story I glad I read, and I appreciate the text for everything it had to offer, but I’m not sure it’s one I would ever want to read again. It hits a bit too close to the bone at times.

See, this book is hailed as a feminist classic and yet the feeling I got while reading it this time was very antifeminist, the way she wrote it gave me the indication that women are weak and break easily under pressure. I completely forgot about that girl who majored in physics and her fate in the later part of the book, and I was foolishly rooting for her - a girl who wasn't scared of science, in the 50s, how refreshing! Yay! Nay... (At one point when she was very depressed, she was thinking about what it would be like to become Catholic or even a nun, so you won't have to make any choices ever and you life would be micromanaged. I understand why she was thinking that at that point of deterioration and yet it does have ugly implications.)And the funny thing was that this main girl encountered older! women who did have wisdom, skills, professional successes, oh how I wanted to be reading about them and not this whiny hateful girl. The New York part was the better one and yet it was not very good (it had Gilmore Girls energy), but the second part would interest only people who are curious about white middle class women's asylums in the 50s America and it's just a very specific interest I don't posses. I keep seeing people praising the writing and for a famous woman-poet – and I won't lie that I understand poetry – it was so surprisingly plainly written. The language is pretty basic, but it makes for a very quick read at least. This book did nothing for me on any level.

This book was heavy going. I'm still ruminating on it and will probably do so for a while. Not only does the Bell Jar deal with mental illnes, it is also a semi-autobiographical novel based on the author's tragic life which adds an extra layer of authenticity and darkness to the story. The portrayal of the descent into mental illness of the main protagonist felt insanely real and depressing."But when it came right down to it, the skin of my wrist looked so white and defensless that I couldn't do it. It was as if what I wanted to kill wasn't in that skin or the thin blue pulse that jumped under my thumb, but somewhere else, deeper, more secret, and a whole lot harder to get.""Death must be so beautiful. To lie in the soft brown earth, with the grasses waving above one’s head, and listen to silence. To have no yesterday, and no tomorrow. To forget time, to forgive life, to be at peace.”I listened to the audiobook narrated by Maggie Gylenhaal who did an amazing job, her husky voice was perfect for the character of Esther Greenwood.
If anyone has ever suffered from poor mental health this book is a must-read. Poignant, relatable, and beautifully written. Up there as one of the best books I’ve ever read.

"-¿Tienes frío?- preguntó la enfermera rudamente.-Sí- respondí, alejándome por el vestíbulo-. Estoy congelada."  Frío, frío, frío. Me gusta el frío. Hay algo oscuro en las sensaciones que provoca. Te entumece, te enferma, te congela, te eriza la piel; es como si tu cuerpo lo rechazara, la interacción entre ambos no es precisamente amistosa. Pero también hay algo reconfortante en como el frío te invade. El invierno puede ser duro para algunos, pero para otros puede representar una zona de confort; hace que todas esas sensaciones oscuras no parezcan fuera de lugar, no porque las oculte, todo lo contrario, sino que hace que convivir con ellas no se sienta fatal y ajeno. Hay veces que el invierno dura más de lo que debería, lo suficiente para creer que uno es uno con él, lo suficiente para dejar de creer en que las estaciones cambian. Lo suficiente para que los rayos de sol ya no sean un consuelo, sino una molestia. Si, La Campana de Cristal es brillante, pero también fría. Muy fría. "El silencio me deprimía. No era realmente el silencio. Era mi propio silencio."Becada, en Nueva York, restaurantes lujosos, ropa costosa y un círculo social compatible con esta realidad, cualquiera diría que Esther sería exitosa. Cualquiera diría que Esther era feliz. Cualquiera envidiaría y desearía un estilo de vida como tal. Sin embargo, las superficialidades de la nueva vida neoyorquina de la protagonista si no la decepcionan, la mantienen indiferente. Es como si con su crecimiento se hubiera dado cuenta que, de alguna forma, no perteneciera al estilo de vida que se suponía que quería llevar, aunque todos indicasen lo contrario. "...todos los pequeños éxitos tan alegremente acumulados en el colegio se apagaban hasta quedar reducidos a nada (...) Se suponía que lo estaba pasando de maravilla." Desde esta perspectiva, ¿qué tan emocionante puede ser la vida? La simple existencia se vuelve una carga, y encontrarle un sentido a algo tan estúpido y decepcionante como la rutina no lo hace mas llevadero (mas cuando te das cuenta que tu entorno no es mucho menos estúpido y decepcionante como tu vida).En efecto, la soledad y el desinterés empiezan a ejercer lentamente presión sobre Esther, y con el pasar de las páginas vemos cómo se va desatando esta crisis mental que empieza a deteriorarla. Ella entra en las rutas del autodesconocimiento, su mente la consume, y, entonces, el camino la lleva a una profunda desconexión."Nueva York se está disolviendo, todo se está disolviendo y se está alejando y nada, ninguno de ellos importa ya." Y cuando nada emociona, nada importa. Ni siquiera su vida. Ni mucho menos su futuro, que una vez pareció ser tan fructífero y ahora se extiende ante ella tan incierto y poco fiable; la idea de que este depende ella no la logra consolar, no cuando apenas puede lidiar con su presente. Se convierte en una carga de la que ella solo quiere librarse. A sus ojos:"Vi mi vida extendiendo sus ramas frente a mí como la higuera verde del cuento De la punta de cada rama, como si de un grueso higo morado se tratara, pendía un maravilloso futuro, señalado y rutilante (...) Me vi a mí misma sentada en la bifurcación de ese árbol de higos, muriéndome de hambre sólo porque no podía decidir cuál de los higos escoger. Quería todos y cada uno de ellos, pero elegir uno significaba perder el resto, y, mientras yo estaba allí sentada, incapaz de decidirme, los higos empezaron a arrugarse y a tornarse negros y, uno por uno, cayeron al suelo, a mis pies.“Podría parecer lo contrario, pero ella no está cegada, perdida quizá, pero inconsciente no. La conciencia de su estado no la hace sentir mejor, lo empeora, la convierte en una testigo de su propio final. Ella identifica esta "campana de cristal" que la encierra, la asfixia y la acompaña a donde sea que vaya. Percibe su presencia inhibidora constantemente, y no sabe cómo librarse. Mucho peor: el resto parece favorecer este estado.  Lo describe:"(...)porque donde quiera queestuviera sentada —en la cubierta de un barco o en la terraza de un café en París o enBangkok— estaría sentada bajo la misma campana de cristal, agitándome en mipropio aire viciado."El dualismo entre la mente y el cuerpo es realmente insostenible. Si bien es lo que nos hace lo que somos, nuestra existencia misma, se comportan como dimensiones diferentes, casi opuestas. Y Esther sabe que hay un problema en su mente; pero esto no es una mera batalla interna, no se resume a un "somos nuestro peor enemigo". A veces solo necesitamos un pensamiento positivo lo suficientemente fuerte. A veces esto no es suficiente. Hay algo frío y oscuro allá afuera también a considerar.No estoy a la altura ni es mi intención analizar esto, no le haría justicia, por lo menos, no en mi primera lectura, pero cuando vemos cómo estos personajes y entidades impactan en la vida de Esther, es como si dejaramos de verla como una loca o demente, y la empezaramos a entender como un producto. Una consecuencia de una serie de presiones y convenciones sociales. Efectivamente, hay algo desmoralizante en el trato que los hombres ponen en ella y la posición sexual/cultura a la que nota que es sometida. También en las expectativas del resto sobre su futuro y su cuerpo, muchas provenientes de su propia madre. O también podríamos mencionar esa posición que toma la mayor parte de su círculo de confianza, que finge que todo está bien y no hay nada diferente en Esther, intentando intoxicar el aire con falso optimismo. Ni hablar del juego con la salud mental y los dudosos tratamientos que un poco reflejan el contexto histórico en el que fue escrito el libro.Expresado lo anterior, sería por lo tanto insultante reducir la historia como un mero libro depresivo. La campana de cristal es una obra oscura y triste, así tanto como intelectual y satírica. La autora inserta una (a veces no tan) leve ironía que, bajo el decaimiento de Esther, forman una tenaz crítica hacia los modelos y prejuicios sociales."Casi toda la gente que conocí en Nueva York estaba tratando de adelgazar.""Cuanto más incurable se vuelve, más lejos lo esconden a uno."y cómo ignorar el trato hacia la virginidad y toda la carga cultural que esa "pureza" implica. Hay algo hasta gracioso en la decepción que Esther siente al ver un pene por primera vez. "Cuando yo tenía 19 años la pureza era un gran tema. El mundo estaba dividido entre católicos y protestantes, o entre republicanos o demócratas o entre blancos y negros, o aun entre hombres y mujeres, yo lo veía dividido entre la gente que se había acostado con alguien y la gente que no lo había hecho, y ésta parecía ser la única diferencia verdaderamente significativa entre una persona y otra.“Pero puff, con muchas más citas que comentarios propios, pareciera que el libro tuviera más que decir de mi, que yo de él. Y quizá sea así.Si, la campana de cristal es una novela fría, pero yo sentí calidez. Las experiencias y sensaciones son únicas, no comparables, hay algo hermoso y tétrico en cómo la autora narra su versión, así como valiente y poderoso; pero me sorprendí viendome reflejado en más de una línea, sintiéndome casi desnudo por la precisión de la narración de tal o cual sentimiento. No, no había nada que romantizar ni enorgullecer, pero esto solo hace que La Campana de Cristal se siente una obra importante solo por el trato de su premisa tan delicada. Por último, el redescubrimiento, la luz, que no son ajenos a la novela. Últimamente todo ha sido muy cerebral y frío para mí, ¿cuántos días tienen que pasar para que deje de ser un mal día y sea algo más? Ya casi alcanzando los 20, el concepto de años dorados es tan falso como opresor así como el futuro tan caótico como incierto. Es tan abstracto como mis pensamientos; pero reconocerlo, ponerlo en palabras, no solo puede sentirse sanador, sino también empoderante. Y ahí es donde para mí reside el poder de la novela, después de todo, ¿qué es la luz sin la oscuridad? "Yo lo recordaba todo (...) Quizás el olvido, como una bondadosa nieve, los entumeciera y los cubriera. Pero eran parte de mí. Eran mi paisaje."

2.5 ☆ rounded up I've interrupted my streak of reading Cold War espionage novels in order to read The Bell Jar, featured as one of my groups' BOTMs. I realized that Sylvia Plath's semi-autobiographical novel was also a Cold War story, not just because it was set in 1953 but because there was a cold and silent war between the sexes. My analogy may initially seem like an unlikely comparison, except that this dynamic triggered the protagonist's mental health crisis with life-and-death consequences. Esther Greenwood was a 19 year old college student, courtesy of a scholarship providing what couldn't otherwise be afforded on her widowed mother's income. Her writing talent landed her a well-regarded summer internship at a ladies' magazine in New York City, which is when The Bell Jar  began. In short, Esther looked like a young woman with a promising future ahead of her. 

I saw my life branching out before me like the green fig tree in the story. From the tip of every branch, like a fat purple fig, a wonderful future beckoned and winked. One fig was a husband and a happy home and children, and another fig was a famous poet and another fig was a brilliant professor, and another fig was E.G., the amazing editor, and another fig was Europe and Africa and South America, and another fig was Constantin and Socrates and Attila and a pack of other lovers with queer names and offbeat professions, and another fig was an Olympic lady crew champion, and beyond and above these figs were many more figs I couldn't quite make out. 

But a casual question about her future revealed to Esther that she didn't know which path to choose. 

I saw myself sitting in the crotch of this fig tree, starving to death, just because I couldn't make up my mind which of the figs I would choose. I wanted each and every one of them, but choosing one meant losing all the rest, and, as I sat there, unable to decide, the figs began to wrinkle and go black, and, one by one, they plopped to the ground at my feet. 

Like many other people at that age, Esther was trying to find herself, except that she tripped into full-blown existential despair. The societally-imposed restrictions of the 1950s limited her options and she wasn't able to see a way to forge a unique path appropriate for her. Concepts like equal opportunity for women, discrimination on the basis of sex, and sexual liberation (due to the 1960 FDA approval of the birth control pill) were yet to be acknowledged. 

If neurotic is wanting two mutually exclusive things at one and the same time, then I'm neurotic as hell. I'll be flying back and forth between one mutually exclusive thing and another for the rest of my days. 

Cultural norms encouraged young women to pursue marriage, but Esther noticed what she would forfeit. Esther did not like that at all. 

And I knew that in spite of all the roses and kisses and restaurant dinners a man showered on a woman before he married her, what he secretly wanted when the wedding service ended was for her to flatten out underneath his feet like Mrs. Willard's kitchen mat...I also remembered Buddy Willard saying in a sinister, knowing way that after I had children I would feel differently, I wouldn't want to write poems any more.So I began to think maybe it was true that when you were married and had children it was like being brainwashed, and afterward you went about numb as a slave in some private, totalitarian state. 

In this respect, The Bell Jar was an exceedingly feminist novel. Esther believed that her choices were binary and thus mutually exclusive. She chafed against all of it, including sexual expression. Her fellow acquaintances, good-girl Betsy and the more brazen Doreen, embodied her only two potential examples.

I couldn't stand the idea of a woman having to have a single pure life and a man being able to have a double life, one pure and one not.

On an intellectual level, I understood Esther and why she descended into a terrible depressive fugue. Because even half a century later, women still face double standards and discrimination in the workplace. Some images of women in the 1950s look glamorous with their Christian Door "New Look," white gloves, and decorative hats, but they were the pretty camouflage of the gilded cage. We now know that many mental disorders have a neurological basis. So women who had the seeds of mental illness would be more vulnerable during this period of gender suppression. I don't believe that it was a coincidence that the prescriptions of sedatives were so prevalent among suburban women during the 1950s.

...it wouldn't have made one scrap of difference to me, because wherever I sat - on the deck of a ship or at a street café in Paris or Bangkok - I would be sitting under the same glass bell jar, stewing in my own sour air.To the person in the bell jar, blank and stopped as a dead baby, the world itself is the bad dream.

I can easily see why The Bell Jar  would be regarded as an important component of American literature. Given its plotline and themes, many of which were socially taboo, Plath's book readily lends itself to deconstruction and analysis. But I never connected emotionally with Esther. This was true from the beginning, hence my star rating. The first half of the book revived faint but negative memories of Holden Caulfield of The Catcher in the Rye. Esther seemed like a slightly older, female version, but without the swearing. I had considered abandoning this book, but I persisted because I was curious how Plath would end it. I had listened to the audiobook, performed by Maggie Gyllenhaal, and I'm likelier to finish books in this format. I should also confess that I'm far from Gyllenhaal's biggest fan, which may have contributed to my lackluster emotional reaction. Or it could have been due to Esther reeking of white privilege, despite her humble socioeconomic situation. This is not a book I would want to revisit in the future. The second half of The Bell Jar  is not for anybody susceptible to triggers  because there's a suicide.

Death must be so beautiful. To lie in the soft brown earth, with the grasses waving above one’s head, and listen to silence. To have no yesterday, and no tomorrow. To forget time, to forgive life, to be at peace.

Back in college, I had been a big fan of poetry and Plath's poetry in particular. It mirrored my own distorted perceptions of reality and my own clinical depression, but beyond that, it was honest, vibrant, and hinted at a kind of transcendence that only people who suffer under a huge weight can truly appreciate.This novel, published under another name in 1963, was close to autobiographical, and beyond that, comes extremely close to matching The Catcher in the Rye and One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest in feel and in a few other ways, subject as well. Fun fact, this novel was published only a year after Kesey's. In my personal opinion, The Bell Jar is superior to Kesey's novel.Why? Because when I compare Sylvia Plath and the character she portrayed to just about anyone alive, she's NOT crazy. Depressed, certainly, and her circumstances, cultural expectations, and hypocrisies of our society did nothing to help her. Indeed, when she tried to help herself, she always found ways to conflate freedom or excitement with self-destruction, and there's little about this that we aren't all acutely aware of. Our own lives are full of them. It doesn't have to be suicide to mean something similar. Plath's writing is gorgeous. I may not have particularly approved of many of her choices, but I can absolutely put myself in her (or her character's) shoes throughout the entire novel. The Bell Jar, like its namesake, is the feeling of being stifled like a hothouse flower, constrained, even crushed. I'm sure a feminist argument can be made in support of this novel, but I don't really care. This speaks to everyone, male or female or any flavor of human at all. It manages to satirize even as it is brutally honest and revealing and heartbreaking. It DOES do a very good job with all kinds of double-standards without making grand statements unless you consider deep honesty and truth a grand statement. And perhaps I do.At all times as I was reading this, I felt very deeply about the book. I was shivering and horrified and I recognized the nearly blasé outlook on life, the weariness that mixed fully with the hope and the yearning even as all roads were slowly rejected, one realization at a time.This is depression, after all. The gradual shutting down of options. The borders and boundaries creeping in. The claustrophobia of our lives.It may not be everyone's definition, of course, but it is definitely a good one, and this novel is one of the very best that tackles it.Warning. Both the character and the author work out their feelings of suicide. If this triggers you, I won't say you should avoid this work. Indeed, I think it's necessary to face all kinds of truth. Including the fact that Sylvia Plath committed suicide when she was only 31.On that note, some Fight Club:"You're not dying.""Sorry?""In the Tibetan philosophy, Sylvia Plath sense of the word,""I know we're all-- we're all dying, all right?""But you're not dying the way Chloe back there is dying."Indeed. Context and perspective are everything.

Io sono. Io sono. Io sono.Anni sessanta.Sei brava, sei intelligente, sei sensibile, sei brillante, sei precisa. Ma non importa, la società ha già definito il ruolo per te. Devi essere sana, moglie devota, brava madre, brava casalinga, magari stupida, simpatica e ben vestita.Se non sei conforme al modello, non sei adeguata per la vita che ti attende.Ma questo ruolo ti sta stretto. Ti senti come in una "campana di vetro", bloccata, senza spazio vitale, senz'aria."Vidi la mia vita protendere i suoi rami come il verde albero di fico del racconto. Dalla cima di ogni ramo ammiccava e occhieggiava un futuro meraviglioso. Un fico simboleggiava un marito con una casa felice e dei bambini, un altro un celebre poeta, un altro un brillante professore universitario, un altro uno straordinario redattore, un altro ancora rappresentava l'Europa, l'Africa e il Sud America e uno era Constantin, Socrate, Attila e una schiera di altri innamorati dai nomi strani e dalle professioni eccentriche, un altro era una popolare campionessa olimpionica, e, al di là e al di sopra di tutti questi fichi, molti altri fichi c'erano che non potevo neppure scorgere. Mi vidi seduta sulla biforcazione di un ramo di questo albero, mentre morivo di fame, solo perché non sapevo decidermi a fare la mia scelta. Avrei voluto poterli scegliere tutti; ma scegliere voleva dire perdere tutti gli altri e, mentre sedevo là, incapace di decidermi, i fichi si raggrinzirono, diventarono neri e, l'uno dopo l'altro, caddero a terra ai miei piedi."Sylvia Plath sente che tra quello che lei è e ciò che ci si aspetta che sia c'è incompatibilità e, forse grazie a una depressione, tenta la fuga, il suicidio, già a vent'anni. Seguiranno tanti altri tentativi, fino al compimento della sua volontà, a 31 anni.Il romanzo, autobiografico, dove Sylvia descrive la vita di una ragazza, Esther, suo alter ego, mi ha colpito innanzitutto per lo stile. Mi aspettavo un clima cupo, deprimente, opprimente, senza speranza. L'ho trovato invece coinvolgente, asciutto, non disperato, tranquillo, pacato, quasi rassegnato. L'atmosfera non è alienata, nonostante la malattia mentale. Non c'è chiusura in sé stessa, bensì apertura, ironia, cinismo.Parlando per bocca di Esther, Sylvia racconta i suoi incubi, i rapporti con la madre, il sesso, la sua prima volta, l'esperienza in ospedale psichiatrico, l'elettroshock, le riflessioni sul suicidio, la depressione, la poesia, l’invidia. Parla di sé, Sylvia Plath. Ma il suo discorso acquisisce valenza assolutamente universale e attuale. Ed è questo che fa di questo libro un vero gioiello.L'interrogarsi di Sylvia sul senso della vita e sulle sue costrizioni diventa, lentamente e inevitabilmente, il nostro.

"I was supposed to be having the time of my life"   Some claimed that it was boring, others found it too depressing, which is kind of ironic. What did they expect from a book which is about a young girl’s mental breakdown? Flowers and butterflies? What did they expect from Sylvia Plath? Rainbows and cotton candy? Since it is semi-autobiographical, one should keep in mind that The bell jar is dark, melancholic and depressing. The Bell Jar follows the story of Esther, who gets a summer internship at a magazine but it certainly is so much more. It’s the journey towards Esther’s depression.  The writing is excellent, sharp and authentic. Plath knows exactly what words to use and how to perfectly describe some heart breaking scenes. Therefore, it’s kind of inevitable to feel empathy for Esther. What a tortured, poor soul she was.. (don’t let me get started on her brutal treatment) Plath’s writing is honest, she doesn't sugarcoat anything.  The Bell jar is more than just a story about a girl who slowly corrupts. It shows Esther’s struggles and even though it’s not cheeky (it doesn't have to be tbh) it’s perfect. (and I am in no way glamorizing mental illness) Plath leads you and lets you get a glimpse of a trouble girl’s mind. Her words, her writing, she managed to get under your skin. Unfortunately, it is the only novel she wrote and I can’t help but wish that she had written more..  Anyway, I consider this book one of my top 5 favorites and I recommend it to everyone. And like this beautiful quote says:  “Some books you read. Some books you enjoy. But some books just swallow you up, heart and soul.”  I couldn't have described that feeling while reading this book in a better way..

Two things to note briefly, having finished rereading The Bell Jar:1. I’d like to read (and if one doesn’t exist, maybe to think about doing) a systematic study of poets’ novels. There’s something impossibly satisfying about a novel-sized idea processed through the language and sensibility of a poet. For perhaps good reason, because there’s certainly something of this in the book’s narration, I remembered The Bell Jar as mainly sort of flat and affectless, but in fact it’s astonishingly rich and vivid.2. These two novels couldn’t be more different in every other way—but the feeling I’m left with here is the same mixture of aesthetic satisfaction and melancholy that I get from John Kennedy Toole’s A Confederacy of Dunces. Just imagine the books that Sylvia Plath could have produced in the autumn years of a long lifetime.

Horrifying beautiful!The novel is disturbing, depressing and brutal. However, it also reads beautifully, almost as if a poem and a novel had had a love child. It’s such a petty that this novel is so full of teenage self-loathing; it could have been a great manifestation of girl-power – this could have become a great manifesto for educated women who don’t want to follow the norms of society by getting married and leaving all behind to serve a man. The first few lines are so captivating and beautiful that it is difficult to stop reading. The narration alone – not that there is a lot of dialogue – is very morbid and scary in a captivating way. I doubt that there is a novel that expresses the feeling of a woman that doesn’t belong better than this story. Perhaps this is one of the best novels written from a female point of view but sadly, it feels so overshadowed by the author’s life and her suicide that at times, while reading, it feels difficult to separate fact from fiction. Furthermore, the biggest shame is that the author decided to end her own life before making more horrifyingly beautiful novels like this one. I wish I could give this novel five stars but I can’t. It has to be four. It is, however, a very enjoyable read – you, the reader, just have to learn to enjoy reading this novel. It should be viewed as a warning to prevent suicide by mental illness.For a full review click on the link below:https://medium.com/@michel.narvaez.08...

The Bell Jar is simultaneously very affecting and very scary. Mental illness ain’t no beanbag. Start with a young woman who seems to have all the luck. Good looks, height, a sense of style, intelligent, articulate, enviable job as a writer in New York etc and experience as she slowly succumbs to depression. It’s all very matter of fact. There is no real trigger within her life that one could point and say, here’s why it happened. I think therein lies the brilliance of the novel. Plath is allowing you inside the mind of a person losing a grasp on reality. Many believe it to be somewhat autobiographical with Plath committing suicide in the year this book was published. Esther Greenwood’s illness is never formally diagnosed, but she has attempted suicide several times and seems to be lost between reality and fantasy. In fact her relationship to what is happening in the real world is somewhat tepid. She dips in and out of fantasy and the real world with a rather emotionally detached persona. She is in and out of several asylums where the prescribed treatment is electroshock therapy. Plath’s descriptions are horrific. The patients are literally coerced into acting sane or else more shock treatment. Esther wonders how one Doctor (Nolan) can possibly know if the shock treatment she administers is done correctly compare with what she had experienced earlier. “Did the doctor ever undergo shock therapy?”, she wonders. She makes what appears to be improvement over the years where she is granted additional privileges and keeps meeting up with friends and people from the past. In this book Esther is an extremely unreliable narrator. It is hard to discern what is real. The book ends cryptically with her going to see a board about getting released from the asylum. Was it a hopeful note or one of repeated never ending tedium a sentence to live out a fantasy life with no real hope of any new real life experiences? This was an extremely melancholy book and in my view a very important one. Esther’s sense of befuddlement, anger, confusion, disorientation, emotional disconnection was all too real. There is an emptiness or void of emotion that seems to come with depression. What I think Plath has accomplished in this book was to impose empathy and some semblance to comprehension for people to begin to see the suffering and isolation and emotional detachment etc, that seems to accompany the illness. This book was masterful in its portrayal of depression. The treatment for mental illness still requires urgent attention and action some 50 years later. It still seems woefully inadequate these days though treatment of choice seems to be drugs rather than electroshock therapy with similarly disparate outcomes. But depression is a condition that is still wrongly associated with poor judgement, shame, a lack of self-control, weak willed and/or personal failing etc. Novels like this shine a light on a huge amount of suffering affecting more people than is comfortable to contemplate. Also, aside from an occasional ham-handed remark about people of color, which I ascribe to the times that this book was written; it is timeless. A very difficult and sad novel that stands up well to the test of time.4.5 Stars

Sylvia Plath virgin until this read. My not being a huge fan of poetry had foolishly kept me away. Obviously I had never taken the time to see that she actually wrote something else, so to make amends I will give her poetry an equal shot in the near future. To willingly dive into the murky poetry pool, that’s how much I loved this book.ANYWAYI am choosing to fill my little white box with a story instead of a review because that’s where this book left me. Here is where you should jump ship if you are a book synopsis review kind of person. Although let’s be honest, I don’t typically offer that kind of service anyway.Ready? Here we go:There was a small flea market down the road from my grandmother’s growing up. Giving us a few dollars and letting us pick out a random treasure was always a special treat when grandma took us down there. My top two picks, a white model horse toy and two pinned butterflies on display under a little glass dome. The latter had a foam seal around the base so you could take the dome on and off whenever you liked. With a little sister sharing the same roof, I would rarely do so and only in the privacy of my top bunk sanctuary. For around fifteen years I would not allow anyone to touch or hold my little butterfly treasure and I kept it shelved high, safe from curious hands. One split second of anger out of my first child when she was a toddler brought an end to my little dome of wonders and I bawled my eyes out when it happened. It was one of those moments when the realities of all that was and is come crashing together and you can’t even catch your breath to comprehend it all.That is what this book reminded me of. Those memories entwined forever in one moment. See I like to hold and capture good memories and live under them, almost in a fog. I tie these little mental stories to items or songs and replay the shit out of them to maintain an even keel. My daughter shattering that particular portkey woke me the hell up. It wasn’t too long after that the white model horse toy I had stashed away all those years before was placed into her hands. The dome was off.

برخلاف انتظاری که داشتم، کتابی کاملا معمولی بود.توصیف جزئیات و اتفاقات با دقت خوبی صورت گرفته بود و سرعت پیشروی داستان مناسب بود. بعد از مشخص شدن هدف و خط سیر اصلی داستان، روند داستان کاملا معمولی، گاهی کسل کننده و بدون هیچ هیجانی، پیش رفت.نویسنده به دقت و با شفاف سازی کامل، شرایط کلیشه ای و سخت زندگی زنان آن دوره زمانی را نشان میدهد. اینکه چطور زندگی همه آنها در نهایت به ازدواج، بچه دار شدن، خانه داری و کار برای شوهرشان ختم می شود. اینکه چطور هیچ آزادی ای ندارند و اینکه این مساله شخصیت اصلی داستان را چقدر آزار میدهد و باعث میشود او احساس خفگی کند. اما سوالی که دارم این است که چرا شخصیت اصلی داستان برای شرایط بهتر در آینده، هیچ تلاشی نکرده است و خود را صرفا قربانی شرایط و زمان میداند؟ چطور این همه آزار میبیند اما صرفا فقط وجود دارد و هیچ تلاشی برای آزادی خود نمیکند. در بخشی از داستان بعضی از اساتید زن دانشکده را ذکر میکند که چطور دو زن اند، و با هم زندگی میکنند، اینکه چطور آزاد اند و به آنچه دوست داشته اند، رسیده اند. با اینکه ممکن است بعضی از مردم پشت سرشان حرف بزنند، اما آنها به زندگی خودشان ادامه میدهند و آنگونه که دوست دارند زندگی می کنند. اما شخصیت اصلی به طور مکرر ذکر میکند که چگونه انواع فعالیت ها برای او احمقانه، کسل کننده، بی معنی و روزمره اند و او حتی نمیتواند تصور کند که حتی یک روز هم به انجام آنها کار ها بپردازد. اما در جای دیگر ذکر میکند که، وقتی کنار یک مترجم چند زبانه نشسته است، چطور احساس میکند که کاملا بی مقدار و سبک است و هیچ چیز برای عرضه در مقابل این افراد ندارد. با وجود اینکه این حس را داشت، اما با این حال به جستجو برای انجام کاری که به آن علاقه داشته باشد نمی پردازد و صرفا خود را قربانی شرایط می داند و هیچ تلاشی برای پیروزی نمیکند در حالی به وضوح نشان داده شده که افرادی با شرایط او وجود دارند که کاملا موفق شده اند.نکته دیگری که باید ذکر کنم، ویراستاری ضعیف این اثر است. تعداد بالایی غلط های املایی و دستوری در متن کتاب وجود دارد، بطوری که در بعضی قسمت ها، تجربه خواندن آسان را، با چندین اشتباه مکرر، از بین میبرد.

The 1950s were not a great time for women (not even white women, unlike what fetishists and Lana Del Rey may like to believe). The sheen of optimism that enveloped America in the post-war years was what made it more of a Man's world: an ideal that compensated for the gloom and danger of the world wars with renewed conservatism. It was thus even less of a good time for ambitious women — and Sylvia Plath was one of them.  The Bell Jar,  her sole novel published mere weeks before her suicide, lays bare with lacerating honesty the struggles of a woman growing up in a time that wanted its women to shrink. Thus, the semi-autobiographical world of  The Bell Jar  opens into a world of opportunities for the protagonist Esther Greenwood, who wins a highly-competitive and coveted internship at a fashion magazine in New York. But as she notes early in the book, everyone around her is trying to reduce, while her aspirations are to  broaden  her horizons and take up her own place in the world. In many senses of the word, this is an intensely feminist book (in context of its own time, of course), where the protagonist often confronts and states her own yearning to be on an equal footing with men while also negotiating with the 'feminine goals' she has been brought up to believe. Esther, as Plath herself, is often found to observe and contemplate the control exerted on the female body: be it observing sexual relations, motherhood, or the dominant medical attitudes towards childbirth and general female complaints of illness (Buddy, the medical student she dates, asserts that her sinus issues are most definitely psychosomatic), or even the facts of being housed in a supervised, women-only hotel for her internship. In fact, as it says in the 2018 BBC documentary  Inside The Bell Jar,  it is probably the idea of being relegated to the literary equivalent of women's work (an idea that she despises) at the fashion magazine, along with the overwhelming personal pressures she felt, that push Esther into a spiral of despair and depression. At the heart of it,  The Bell Jar  is an brutal, immersive story of depression and mental illness; a painfully honest account of the descent, dehumanisation, and stigma of it that leaves nothing to romanticise. Mental illness in the 50s  was  dehumanisation, and this book portrays this vicious aspect of psychiatric treatment with chilling, unflinching honesty, for this was a time when electroshock was unjudiciously and unthinkingly prescribed as a curative for everything, be it treason or depression, even though it did, in effect, more harm than good. Plath's writing comes from experiencing psychiatric treatment at a time when it was a source of shame, something to be hidden — "The more hopeless you were the further away they hid you." But as in the case of some, like Esther, Joan, and Plath herself, mental illness was often itself hidden, existing behind happy-looking and often successful faces. I also found it quite telling that it is Philomela Guinea, the successful woman writer who funds Esther's scholarship, who shifts Esther to the care of a better doctor. Guinea herself had been at an asylum in her youth, and understands, while even Esther's own mother can not. It is widely known that  The Bell Jar  is highly autobiographical, based on Plath's own experiences at the age of 19, but there is this portion in the book, right before Esther finally takes the sleeping pills, where she decides that she will spend the summer working on a novel:   "My heroine would be myself, only in disguise. She would be called Elaine. Elaine. I counted the letters on my fingers. There were six letters in Esther, too. It seemed a lucky thing."   This quote, most of all, makes the story even most real to me: the name Sylvia has six letters, too. At another point, later in the novel, Esther thinks to herself that if 'it' ever gets that bad again, she would not subject herself to living through it again. This is the only point where I allow myself to think of the tragedy of the author's eventual death by suicide. I also allow myself a brief moment thinking about how 'it' was there again: the personal pressures, the relegation to a lesser literary ghetto that denied her the recognition she felt she deserved (The Guardian had called the book, then published under the pseudonym of Victoria Lucas, "a sprightly little tale." When the book was reissued after her death, of course, the cult of Plath had taken shape and the reviews changed shape, too). Today,  The Bell Jar  is recognised by most for the literary landmark it is — thoughtful, dark, even funny — the mark of a fine writer who wrote her own painful experience into something that has proven cathartic for millions of readers. Despite carrying the signs of its time, both good and bad, it is also a timeless tale of struggle, aspiration and humanness.  Cover Story The 1950s were not a great time for women, and so even though I can not excuse them I understand and contextualise the lukewarm reviews and the sexism of publishers. But this edition was published in 2013, and I have a major bone to pick with Faber & Faber about it. If you pick up this edition not knowing much about Plath and/or what  The Bell Jar  is about, you would probably think it belongs to what a lot of people call the 'chick-lit' genre, and you would think it is juvenile. That's because Faber & Faber seem to have deliberately made it look that way — what else explains the glamourised image on the cover or the blurb at the back which makes the book sound like something it really is not? Absolutely nothing on the cover tells you about the intensity of this story, and how it deals with mental illness and suicide. Now, Faber & Faber have a long history of giving The Bell Jar  these stupid, sexist covers, but I expected better for the 50th Anniversary Edition — better than a lousy image of a woman with a compact and a small blob stating the fact that this is an anniversary edition, at any rate. I would expect, for instance, a proper introduction to be included with the book — you know, the way it would be done for a book of similar magnitude had it been written by a man. But no. Nothing. What's worse is that the irony of all this seems to be lost on the publishers.

3,75Volim kad mi se desi da me knjiga izazove i natera na razmisljanje i istrazivanje. Dopala mi se ili ne - volim da izazove neki utisak. A Silvija Plat definitivno to jeste ucinila. Nakon normal people, verovatno je ovo knjiga koja mi je izazvala jedina takvu kolicinu pomesanih emocija. Ostavila me je blago zbunjenom, trazila sam informacije o njenom zivotu jer je bilo tesko citati knjigu, a ne razmisljati o paralelama, s obzirom na to da ima nekih istinitih momenata, a autorka se ubila mesec dana nakon objavljivanja knjige. Ocekivala sam da se ja licno vise povezem, ali nekako nisam uspela. Neke recenice, poput one sa staklenim zvonom ili one o zeni poput luka i strele su mi se dopale bas, ali opet, falilo mi je nesto. To nesto bi bili opisi osecanja, jer je knjiga samo prepricala dozivljaje glavne junakinje Ester Grinvud, kao da pratimo dnevnik. Smetalo mi je i jer su neki delovi nepovezani. Recimo imamo jednu scenu, a onda bez prelaska na novo poglavlje, bez razmaka, prebacuje se na drugu scenu. Ipak, citala sam da je muz unistio neke delove njenih rukopisa, kao i da je ona to pisala bez nekih ispravki, s obzirom na to kako se osecala, mogu da razumem da ima propusta. Stilski mi je bila vrlo zanimljiva. Nikada u zivotu nisam citala knjigu a uspevala da sve zamislim toliko detaljno kao da gledam i film, tacno su se stvarale slike pred mojim ocima. Ester kao lik bila mi je simpaticna ipak kada se sve sabere i oduzme. Ali sam ocekivala vise unutrasnjih emocija, manje opisa okruzenja i svega drugog, poput onih zurki, Njujorka u pocetku, neki delovi su mi malo i nerealni, ali sve u svemu drago mi je sto sam je procitala. Nisam preodusevljena da bih dala 5 jer mi je tesko da ocenim nesto samo na osnovu tezine teme, imam taj trenutak gde mi neke stvari kvare utisak, ali opet je nesto sto me je zaintrigiralo i sto ce mi ostati u secanju nakon nekog vremena.

This book hooked me with its talons and did not let go. I was reading it foregoing breakfast, lunch and even dinner if my mother allowed it. I only stopped for that and my evening walk as I consider that part of my daily routine essential for my mental well being. First of all I want to apologize to Ms. Slyvia Plath for allowing this book to grow old on my bookshelf for decades. I should truly be hit on the head with a large bat for it. This book felt personal and struck a chord in me I never thought it will.Esther Greenwood felt to me like a soul sister, a reflection of myself for I have never related to a character as I have as to her. Yes, I know the implications that sentence brings, and I mean each one of it. Maybe many did feel that connection to her, or someone felt as an outsider looking at the personal downward spiral of hers, like watching a linear movie in the theater. It was like getting sucked into the vortex of a tornado called Esther Greenwood. One where I did not have a single thought of escaping. I rather enjoyed being carried away by its gale. I never sympathized with Esther and I did not understand why few people even pitied her. There seem to be nothing to be pitied. There was something always vulnerable in her but it was nothing to be pitied. We all know that the book did reflect in some instances to that of Plath herself and many know how her journey came to an end. So in a way we can truly comprehend what would have been the end of Esther herself.As I came closer and closer to the end, I did not want to finish it. I could have easily finished the book in a day but I kept it aside while I had the last two chapters left and picked it up again after a good 12 hours or more. I needed to arrange my thoughts and felt as if I was saying goodbye to an old and dear freind. I wanted to bury my head in the pages and cry and wallow. No, not a single tear actually escaped me as I read the book yet my heart was always thrumming as I felt the familiarity with her as if one of my own darkest deepest secrets have been laid bare on the pages. Will I read it again? Yes but not any time soon. As I told my best friend in a call as I gushed on and on about the book, I do not think it is healthy for me to reread it so soon. I can almost feel it becoming an obsession, a part I want to hold on tightly and not let go.

This is Exhibit A of why reading a novel 20 years later in life may as well be reading a completely different book. I love how a Reader's filters change over time (hopefully for the better) and leads to a completely different experience with the exact same text. What will I think of this book when I read it at 65 years?And but I really enjoyed the novel in my '20s; I just at that point hadn't had three people in my life suffer through and lose their lives to crippling depression. Plath's protagonist provided me an inner monologue that might have sounded similar to what these people experienced, and it was only re-reading the novel that made me realize my interaction with these tortured friends/family was one of satellite orbit to their malady. I could never inhabit that inner space with them, to provide them meaningful comfort - despite my thinking at the time I was perhaps doing so. Esther's bell jar is the right metaphor; I'm not getting in, and they couldn't discern how to get out.If for nothing else, reading this novel alongside all of you wise and wonderful GREATreaders proves to me, yet again, how fantastic this website is. I learned so much from all the comments on the discussion feeds - and saw parts of the text in ways I didn't see at all (e.g. the lesbianism). So thank you, all of you, that took the time to share your thoughts and perspectives on the book.
