Oh wow. I've never read anything by Sylvia Plath but I'm told her poetry is deeply moving and gorgeous. For some reason, I decided not to start with that but with this novel instead.The MC, Esther, is 19 years old and has won an internship at a fashion magazine in the beginning. She's pretty, supposedly smart (though I didn’t get that impression, frankly), talented and now also regarded as successful. The only problem is that she sees her own life quite differently and keeps sabotaging herself. Because Esther, slowly but surely, is having a mental breakdown (total spiral into a deeeeep depression).Interestingly, this novel is semi-autobiographical. Sylvia Plath herself interned at a fashion magazine, suffered a mental breakdown, and even tried to kill herself. That gives the musings in this story a special kind of gravitas.The writing was lyrical and started off with a bang, only intensifying from there. However, I also found there to be too much melodrama, or at least melodramatic behavior from the MC, and I usually have a problem with people who have a good life but keep wanting more and expecting everything to just fall into their laps (it seems ungrateful to me). I’m also not one for gossip - it not only bores but even annoys me - and can’t muster sympathy for self-destructive behavior, especially when the same self-destructive people then style themselves as the victims of circumstances that are out of their hands.As such, I just couldn't get into Esther's musings on her fading teint and rolled my eyes frequently about her superficial inner monologue. I mean, a woman who makes fun of the colour of other people’s outfits (refusing to getting to know them if they wear this or that colour) and who proclaims to be collecting men with interesting names? Give me a break!Which is not to say that a young woman going over the mental edge like that (or what happened to her along the way) left me entirely cold. We’re talking about a time when shock treatments were normal. But at the same time I couldn’t help but growing more and more exasperated at her continuously provoking terrible situations.And yes, the social norms from back in those days are infuriating to many modern people, myself included. Nobody gets to tell me what to do or who to be (if I have to marry, whom, that I need to give birth constantly etc). But every generation has problems with their respective society’s norms and it’s just no excuse.I guess I just couldn’t warm to Esther and it does make me wonder if I would have liked Plath herself or, indeed, will like her other work.The writing style was what stood out for me most. It was actually superb! Such an odd contrast, not liking the protagonist at all but almost falling in love with how the story of said protagonist was written. Thus, the writing was the best thing about this novel, along with the merciless reckoning with society. Just the fact that the book talks about mental health issues, and in such detail, and even critiquing the outwardly presented perfect facade and social norms back then does indeed justify this being a classic.My rating: 3.5 stars and I have no idea if I'll round up or down.

Da anni aspettavo di leggere "La campana di vetro" e mi sembrava che non fosse mai il momento giusto. Sicuramente, per assorbire un romanzo come questo, bisogna avere la pazienza di riflettere su temi molto dolorosi. E' uno dei romanzi più dolorosi che io abbia mai letto, per via del racconto della malattia mentale della protagonista. Questo racconto è di una brutalità particolare, poiché la maggior parte dei romanzi che ho letto, con temi simili, hanno narratori che non sono essi stessi i malati. Qui invece Esther è la narratrice e la malata. Ho trovato sincero e calzante il paragone che viene fatto con la malattia: quando una persona è malata, il mondo esterno è una campana che la copre. E quindi soffoca. Ecco spiegato il titolo.Aldilà dei temi trattati - e di come vengono trattati in modo secondo me magistrale - mi è piaciuta anche la prosa; lo stile di scrittura denota una autrice di grande talento. Mi è piaciuto il personaggio, il suo sarcasmo iniziale, e poi la discesa nella malattia. Ho apprezzato la costruzione del romanzo, il modo spietato in cui è raccontato tutto. Alla fine la protagonista sembra risalire la china della malattia, sembra essere pronta ad uscire dall'ospedale psichiatrico e ritornare alla vita. Sarà così? Il libro si chiude prima che possiamo esserne certi. Mi sembra una ottima conclusione, con un pizzico di speranza ma anche piena di incertezza. Ma la vita reale è così. Mi rendo conto che si tratta di un romanzo fortemente autobiografico; quella lucentezza e precisione nel descrivere la malattia, in prima persona, lo dobbiamo alla reale esperienza di Sylvia Plath la quale, purtroppo, morirà dopo un mese dalla pubblicazione di questo romanzo indimenticabile."Feci un profondo respiro e ascoltai il mio cuore ripetere l'antica vanteria. Io sono, io sono, io sono."

“I felt my lungs inflate with the onrush of scenery—air, mountains, trees, people. I thought, "This is what it is to be happy.” I love many of the poems that Sylvia Plath created, and in The Bell Jar she carried her elegant writing style to the form of the novel. This is the only book that Sylvia Plath wrote, and in my opinion, and many others, it is fantastic. For a book released in 1963, it is so progressive, with Sylvia Plath engaging with taboo subjects in a way that seems so natural, exploring these themes and ideas through characters that feel so real.On that topic, the characters are fantastic, as Sylvia Plath portrays life in all its randomness, with realistic humour, moments of severity and the full exploration of the effects of depression and pressure. The characters each have their own motivations, and Sylvia Plath shows how, perhaps engaging with a cynical outlook. Everyone is looking out for themselves.“If you expect nothing from somebody you are never disappointed.” The prose is absolutely beautiful. In my opinion it makes sure not to be too indulgent, but hits that balance of beauty whilst being sharp and making sure to keep the story, themes and setting at the core. The prose is really used wonderfully to build on these, and does a fantastic job with the tone and atmosphere, especially in a book where these shift so dramatically at times.“The silence depressed me. It wasn't the silence of silence. It was my own silence.” The Bell Jar has become a classic, and I really see why. It is an expertly crafted story that engages with themes so well, both shocking the reader, but also exploring these ideas in a subtle way at the same time. A fantastic look into the effects of pressures of society, isolation and depression.5/5 STARS

۵/۵بل جار یا اونطوری که تو ایران ترجمه شده «حباب شیشه‌ای»، تنها رمان سیلویا پلث، یکی از شاعرای مشهور آمریکاست. نویسنده فقط چند هفته بعد از انتشار کتاب، تو سن ۳۰ سالگی خودکشی می‌کنه و از دنیا می‌ره. کتاب تقریبا زندگی نامه خودشه، و از اون کتابهاییه که خوندنش «لذت بخش» نیست. برعکس ممکنه حس معذب و ناراحت کننده ای به آدم بده، اما از اون کتابهاییه که با آدم عمیقأ حرف میزنن. پلث شدیداً استانداردهای دوگانه و جنسیت زده زمان خودش رو (که خیلی شبیه حرفاییه که دوستای مسلمونمون و خانم جلسه ای ها میزنن) مخصوصا در مورد سکس، نقد می‌کنه، و از نقش سنتی که جامعه براش (و برای بقیه زن‌ها) می‌بینه گریزونه. هر چی به سمت آخرای کتاب میریم کاراکتر اصلی بیشتر و بیشتر توی افسردگی شدید فرو می‌ره و پلث خیلی درست و زیبا بر اساس تجربیات خودش چهره واقعی افسردگی رو بهمون نشون میده. کتاب رو با ناتور دشت مقایسه می‌کنن. من ناتور دشت رو چند سال پیش شروع کردم اما نصفه گذاشتمش، با این حال به نظرم اومد که از جهت پوچی که هر دو این کاراکترها دارن و روایت عجیبشون واقعا شبیه همه. این باعث میشه حتما برگردم و ناتور دشت رو هم دوباره بخونم.

Mientras se lee 'La campana de cristal', es inevitable pensar en su autora, Sylvia Plath. Las similitudes entre su protagonista, Esther Greenwood, y la propia Sylvia están muy presentes. Porque a través de 'La campana de cristal', Sylvia nos muestra su alma, llena de miedos y como caminando sobre el borde de una abismo desde el que caer y hacerse añicos.Sylvia Plath fue conocida sobre todo por su obra poética, convirtiéndose en una de las poetas norteamericanas más importantes del pasado siglo. Sus poemas y su única novela, contienen una gran carga autobiográfica. La lectura de 'La campana de cristal' me ha dejado un sabor agridulce. Por una parte, he conocido a una chica, apenas salida de la adolescencia, inteligente y con talento, brillante, con un gran futuro, y esto me ha gustado. Pero por otra, está esa Esther (o Sylvia, porque ya no sé quién es quién) que camina por un hilo muy fino, que puede romperse en cualquier momento y hacerla caer en la locura, a la que querría ayudar de alguna manera, algo lógicamente imposible, porque no me gusta verla así.Esta chica, Esther, tiene diecinueve años, y nos cuenta cómo fue su periplo en Nueva York, el mes que pasó allí tras ganar una beca que consiste en trabajar durante un mes en una revista. En esta primera parte de la novela, conocemos parte de su pasado, la muerte de su padre cuando ella tenía nueve años, sus dudas frente al amor y sus reticencias hacia el sexo, sus esperanzas para el futuro próximo, su relación con Buddy Willard, alguien que marcará su vida para bien o para mal, todo ello bajo el telón de fondo de ese Nueva York lleno de boato y fiestas de lujo.Y después entramos en la segunda parte de la novela, mucho más dura, donde nos encontramos a una Esther de regreso a su antigua vida, donde despertará su miedo atávico a la vida, a qué será de ella a partir de ahora, a cómo conducir su vida. Como ella dice, "para la persona encerrada en la campana de cristal, vacía y detenida como un bebé muerto, el mundo mismo es la pesadilla". Crisis nerviosas, no come, no puede ni leer ni escribir, depresión... Dolor, dolor, dolor. Esta parte de la novela es desgarradora.Sylvia Plath, con 'La campana de cristal', nos hace un hermoso regalo, nos muestra cómo es ella a través de una novela poética, bella, desnuda, que nos atraviesa mente y corazón, y que es difícil de olvidar.

La campana de cristal es una novela de inspiración biográfica en que su autora, Sylvia Plath, repasa los pormenores de ser mujer, escritora y paciente psiquiátrica en pleno siglo XX.La novela funciona como un slice of life: los eventos que transcurren en la vida de Esther, su protagonista, siguen un orden más cronológico que tramático. Por lo mismo, el ánimo de avanzar en la lectura está fundamentado en el interés por las experiencias de su personaje - o, también, en una fijación por la autora - más que por la calidad estructural de su narrativa.Pese a esto, no me sorprende que La campana de cristal sobreviva en el tiempo como un artefacto de culto, especialmente entre las lectoras. Creo que representa súper bien - y acá me cuelgo de lo que me han dicho porque evidentemente no he pasado por esto - las problemáticas de la existencia femenina en Occidente: la obligación de convertirse en madre de familia y las consecuencias psíquicas que dicha tradición conlleva. Además, la depresión como tópico de la posmodernidad sigue tan vigente en ese entonces como ahora.Me gustó leer la novela en este momento de mi vida. Cuando era adolescente intenté acercármele, pero no empaticé tanto. Esta vez, imagino que mediado por mi propia experiencia escritural, me sentí mucho más cercano a la desazón de la personaje.TL;DR: Somos esa.

This is sobering read, made more so by its brutally honest style with matter-of-fact tone. This tone becomes chilling when sharp insights are delivered with wit. The infamy of this novel makes it hard not to see this as a tragic tale. Esther Greenwood, in her late teens, is admitted to a psychiatric ward when she attempts to kill herself. Esther shares with us her story, she shows how it led up to this and the events that follow. This is an unsettling read because of Sylvia Plath’s realistic portrait of a person who is coping with the things that most of us would take for granted. It’s world where there is more darkness than light. However, the story does not ask to pity Esther Greenwood, neither does it give a spotlight to her courage. When the story ends it’s on a small glimmer of hope. The Bell Jar’s crisp writing, and its modest telling of a heroic tale, is what keeps bringing me back to read this again.

« Dovunque mi fossi trovata, sul ponte di una nave o in un caffè di Parigi o a Bangkok, sarei stata sotto la stessa campana di vetro, a respirare la mia aria mefitica. »Ci sono dei libri che sono stati scritti non dico da gente come noi, ma da gente che pensava come noi. Le curve del pensiero, sovrapposte, per lo più combacerebbero con le nostre e soltanto qualche sbavatura qua e là dimostrerebbe che, dopotutto, non si tratta della stessa curva. Quando un libro lo ha scritto una persona che pensava come te, tu non puoi far niente: tentare di opporre resistenza è inutile. Tentare di non lasciarsi ammaliare, inutile. Tentare di mantenere una distanza critica, inutile. Un canto di sirena si dipana fino a te dalla pagina. A mettere i tappi di cera non hai neanche provato. Ascolti. Caschi contento nel gorgo. Qualcuno ha pensato bene di paragonare ‘La campana di vetro’ a ‘Il giovane Holden’, chiamando la protagonista, Esther, la sua controparte femminile. I romanzi, in realtà, non si somigliano molto. Lo sguardo di Holden è fresco, è uno sguardo di chi si può ancora salvare. Lo sguardo di Esther è allucinato, uno sguardo che ti trascina sul fondo. A Holden accarezzeresti la testa: tu non sei Holden, sei con Holden. A Esther la testa non la puoi accarezzare, a meno che appoggiarti la mano sulla nuca non ti sembri un gesto comunissimo. Davanti a entrambi, a Holden come a Esther, si snoda un gomitolo di dolori e di strade, di ricordi, di scene e colori che non riescono a dimenticare. Ma Holden lo guardiamo e facciamo il tifo per lui, siamo tutti lì a urlare che è giovane, che si può tirar fuori, che può essere felice. Con Esther il pensiero non ci sfiora nemmeno: essere felice, per lei, sarebbe un tradimento. Quando la conosciamo, Esther è una diciannovenne molto fortunata. Ha vinto uno stage presso una prestigiosa rivista di moda, dopo una carriera scolastica costellata tutta di borse di studio e voti altissimi. È fidanzata con un bel ragazzo destinato a diventare un brillante dottore. È abbastanza graziosa, troppo intelligente e scrive poesie. No, non scrive poesie, è un poeta. La qualifica di poeta è la sola che Esther si dia autonomamente, la sola che sembri riconoscere, la sola che conti qualcosa. Ed è solo e proprio nel momento in cui scopre di non essere più un poeta – quando si mette alla macchina da scrivere e non le viene fuori niente, quando le lettere tracciate sul foglio di carta le restituiscono una grafia distorta e infantile – che qualcosa dentro di lei si spacca con un fracasso infernale. Fino a quel momento, Esther era sì consapevole di avere davanti delle difficoltà, consapevole che le sue capacità mentali si stavano pian piano sfilacciando, ma mai il terrore la aveva invasa fino a paralizzarla, a spingerla a risoluzioni estreme quali il suicidio, i suicidi, i mille piccoli tentativi di annientarsi disposti qua e là lungo tutta la narrazione e destinati a scattare a vuoto come trappole per topi mal congegnate. Uccidendosi, Esther non ucciderebbe niente di più che un involucro. Il soffio vitale è già fuori di lei. È uscito, si è perduto, esploso al contatto con la vita e i suoi meccanismi di produzione e distruzione. Eppure, anche se Esther è già morta, anche se la sola Esther che conti è già morta, tutti si affaccendano intorno al suo cadavere per far sì che l’involucro non muoia. Coccolano il suo scheletro, ci parlano, lo ingozzano di insulina. « Capii allora che il mio corpo conosceva un’infinità di trucchetti, tipo togliere la forza alle mie mani nel momento cruciale, che gli avrebbe salvato ogni volta la vita, mentre, se fosse dipeso solo da me, in un attimo l’avrei fatta finita. Dunque dovevo tendergli un’imboscata con quel po’ di intelligenza che mi rimaneva, altrimenti quello mi avrebbe tenuta intrappolata nella sua stupida gabbia per altri cinquant’anni di ebetudine ». Ma il corpo non è l’unica gabbia contro cui Esther deve dibattersi. Il corpo è soltanto la gabbia più superficiale, quella che aderisce strettamente allo spirito. Sopra il corpo tutta un’altra serie di pinnacoli e di guglie si innalza, e questa è la campana di vetro. La campana di vetro è la matrioska multistrato in cui sei immerso dacché sei nato. Nella matrioska più piccola c’è la tua famiglia, in quella poco sopra la famiglia che ti formerai, poi la scuola, il lavoro, le istituzioni, le consuetudini, i sistemi di pensiero, le religioni. A volerla sfogliare tutta come una cipolla, la campana di vetro ha la forma del cosmo. Tutto il cosmo in ogni sua parte è una campana di vetro. Essendo grande, la campana non pesa su tutti allo stesso modo. In qualche punto, anzi, si respira abbastanza bene. Ma a seconda delle circostanze, del sesso, dell’educazione la campana ti preme un po’ di più o un po’ di meno. Se sei una donna come Esther, nell’America degli anni Cinquanta, la campana di vetro ti pesa addosso un bel po’. Innanzitutto, o ti sposi o sei poeta. Qualunque persona sana di mente vedrà che sono impossibili insieme. Secondo, o ti sposi e rimani vergine per tuo marito (mentre tuo marito, beninteso, non rimane vergine per te) o hai una vita sessuale franca e schietta e allora subisci le conseguenze a tuo carico (vedi gravidanze indesiderate e scandali). A dirla tutta, la società perbenista e maschilista nella quale Esther è immersa è quella che di più appesantisce la campana di vetro. Per Esther gli uomini sono creature grottesche, tra le quali si muove con circospezione, e che si dividono in ‘uomini che potresti sposare e che quindi ti trasformerebbero in una moglie-zombie accondiscendente’ e ‘uomini che potresti scopare e quindi usare per assumere il controllo sul tuo corpo, sulle tue emozioni, sui tuoi cicli’. « Era sempre la stessa storia: adocchiavo un ragazzo e da lontano sembrava perfetto, ma non appena si faceva più vicino, scoprivo che non mi piaceva più. Era uno dei motivi per cui non intendevo sposarmi. L’ultima cosa che desideravo era la sicurezza assoluta ed essere il punto da cui scocca la freccia dell’uomo. Io volevo novità ed esperienze esaltanti, volevo essere io una freccia che vola in tutte le direzioni, come le scintille multicolori dei razzi il 4 luglio». Il fantasma del matrimonio e l’incubo della verginità – l’amore non è tra le alternative – pendono sulla testa di Esther come una solida spada di Damocle. Lei si sposta un po’ da una parte e un po’ dall’altra. Ma nel centro, nell’oscillazione è la follia. Altro sonoro rintocco sulla campana di vetro è il din-don della religione. Cattolicesimo, unitarianesimo, puritanesimo sono tutte uguali, tutte ugualmente pronte a incasellarti nei loro schemi rigidi, quegli schemi comodi come linee rette nei quali non c’è alcun bisogno di pensare. « Gli avevo detto che credevo nell’inferno, e che certe persone, io per esempio, erano condannate a vivere all’inferno durante la vita, per compensare il fatto di non andarci dopo morte, visto che non credevano nell’aldilà, e che dopo la morte a ciascuno succede quello in cui aveva creduto ». Poi ci sono i genitori, che ti vogliono sana, stupida e felice. Poi gli amici, che ti vogliono simpatica e vestita bene. Poi i dottori, che vogliono sapere perché stai male. E infine ci sei te, il nocciolo duro della campana di vetro, la punta di diamante che ruota e strilla e strepita ma non crepa. La campana non si rompe. Se si incrina, la aggiusteranno per te. Non potrai mai fuggire. Io credo che questo libro fiero, crudo, spietato sarebbe molto più noto di quanto già non sia se solo in copertina non ci fosse quel nome di donna che fa storcere il naso ai maschietti, se chi l’ha scritto non si fosse suicidato, attirandosi quei sospetti di ‘cianfrusaglia deprimente scritta da una persona disturbata’. Io credo che un libro che scava così tanto nella malattia e nel suicidio, un libro che ci fa entrare nelle vasche da bagno e nelle cliniche dove ti addomesticano con l’elettroshock, acquisti una validità ancora più assoluta per il fatto – ovvio, brutale – che Sylvia Plath ha effettivamente vissuto quel che racconta, che ha portato la merenda ai suoi bambini e ha infilato la testa in un forno e nessuno, nessuno l’ha trovata prima che fosse troppo tardi. Io credo che questo libro non dica ‘La vita fa schifo, perché non ce la togliamo tutti?’. Anzi, io credo che questo libro voglia dire o almeno dica a me, ‘Ecco, qui sta il problema, qui, proprio qui, dietro l’orecchio destro, e adesso che io te l’ho circoscritto e definito, sta a te vedere come puoi estirparlo. Se puoi estirparlo. Se vuoi estirparlo.’Io credo e lo dico sinceramente che perdere Sylvia Plath sia stata una gran perdita. E avrei preferito che rimanesse con me, che scrivesse altri tre, altri quattro libri come questo, invece che scriverne uno solo e suggellarlo col più definitivo, col più puro atto di potenza.

4 StarsSome books are just hard to review… and this is one of them. Because how do you review something that feels so personal? First published in 1963, I understand why Plath’s semi-autobiographical is still so widely read. This is raw and unapologetic. The narrator, Esther walks us through a year in her life as her depression becomes overwhelming, she encounters ECT, and navigates mental health in the 1950s. It’s rarely pretty, and sometimes felt so ugly and personal it almost felt wrong to read. But it’s more than just a journal, as Plath’s lyrical writing portrays Esther’s struggles in a mesmerizing manner, the surreal merges with the relatable. One of my favorite examples is the passage where Eleanor envisions all of her possible futures each as a separate fig on a large tree. And then relays feeling paralyzed by the decision and losing all the other possibilities.
”I saw myself sitting in the crotch of this fig tree, starving to death, just because I couldn't make up my mind which of the figs I would choose. I wanted each and every one of them, but choosing one meant losing all the rest, and, as I sat there, unable to decide, the figs began to wrinkle and go black, and, one by one, they plopped to the ground at my feet.” 
 Plath’s beautiful and metaphorical writing manages to describe big-isolating feelings. Being able to name and express an emotion like that felt so powerful.  I think there are times the narrative revels in these moments, and borders romanization in places—though through the lens of a narrator who is mentally ill, so it’s a weird critique. Which brings me back to how hard this is to review. Because as a reader, the ending feels abrupt and Esther’s relationship with her therapist difficult to track. But I also understand Plath was trying to write an ending to something she was still going through.Overall:This is an uncomfortable read. It’s absurdly personal as a woman navigates through the overwhelming aspects of mental illness. It attempts to define the ill defined, and sometimes it succeeds, sometimes it really succeeds, and sometimes it doesn't.

3.5 starsOh, boy. This is a book that went a little bit over my head. I felt like I should have been reading it for class, like I missed several important details that would have been pointed out to me had a professor been instructing me through it. I finished it feeling like a dummy, which is one of my pet peeves as a reader. I'm gonna go read a summary of this book and then come back to publish final thoughts before I post a really ignorant review. (later)Okay. I think my overall afterthought about this book is that it did not turn out how I would have expected it to, which is frustrating. I thought it would be this dark and grotesque story about a woman struggling with depression, which is was, but the ending unsettled me. I was so disoriented by it that I actually, as you saw, had to google why Esther made the decisions she did. This is the only thing that sits wrongly with me.On the other hand, I adored this story. The way that the writing reflects Esther state of mind is genius and marvelous. The subtle social commentaries about sexuality and the patriarchy and conformity are very valid fears to have, and I found myself especially relating to them as a fellow college student. I've never had depression or suicidal thoughts, so I think this book might elicit more emotion and empathy from a person who has gone through the same ordeal (although hopefully nobody will have undergone the same disgusting treatments that Esther was forced through). Esther seemed like such a complacent character, and her disdain toward societal norms like having to get married and have kids was very apparent, but the shift from her disappointment to actually attempting suicide was a bit sudden to me. It may have been because I read this book over the course of a month-- way longer than I would typically take to read a book-- so the timeline of events could have been distorted in my own perception. I would recommend this book if you're someone who would like to read a book about the uncensored inner thoughts of troubled woman. It was really interesting, and though I wish I'd better comprehended the storyline, Esther was oddly relatable.

Έβλεπε τον κόσμο μέσα από τα μάτια ενός ανθρώπου που προσπαθούσε διαρκώς να δώσει απαντήσεις σε αυτό που η κοινωνία πρόσταζε γι’ αυτήν και σε αυτό που η ίδια πραγματικά επιθυμούσε για να είναι ευτυχισμένη. Και με αυτόν ακριβώς τον τρόπο η Σύλβια Πλαθ μας άνοιξε την ψυχούλα της και μίλησε για την αδυναμία της να το επιτύχει. 	Σε μια ζωή όπου η μετάβαση από την εφηβική στην ενήλικη ζωή απαιτεί κατά βάση να διαμορφώνουμε τη ζωή μ��ς βάσει των κοινωνικών προσδοκιών αδιαφορώντας για ό,τι προσφέρει στον καθένα προσωπικά την ευτυχία ορισμένοι νιώθουν εγκλωβισμένοι σε ένα αδιέξοδο όπου αδυνατούν να υποστηρίξουν τις πραγματικές τους επιθυμίες (κάτι που ίσχυε μάλιστα σε μεγαλύτερο βαθμό σε προγενέστερες εποχές). Οι περισσότεροι εντέλει συμβιβάζονται και ενίοτε νιώθουν ευτυχισμένοι υιοθετώντας τελικά το μοντέλο ευτυχίας που οι άλλοι κατασκεύασαν γι’ αυτούς. Η Πλαθ προσπάθησε, όμως δεν τα κατάφερε. Ο γυάλινος Κώδων κατάφερε τελικά να την κλείσει μέσα του και να την οδηγήσει στην αυτοχειρία ως μοναδική διέξοδο στις αναζητήσεις της. Στο βιβλίο της, από την άλλη, μας αφήνει με την ελπίδα.. 	Προσωπικά, μέσα από περιγραφές που μου έκοβαν την ανάσα μου η συγγραφέας μου έδωσε αυτό ακριβώς που είχα ανάγκη ως αναγνώστρια: να βυθιστώ στον κόσμο και στην ψυχή της και να προσπαθήσω να δώσω τις δικές μου απαντήσεις. Εύχομαι να γνώριζε ότι δεν είναι η μόνη. Εύχομαι να ήξερε ότι καθημερινά πολλοί προσπαθούν να κάνουν ακριβώς το ίδιο. Before Sylvia Plath, I had never found anyone so capable of describing mental illness.Published in 1963, a month before the author's suicide, The Bell Jar is the only novel by Sylvia Plath. She talks about herself and her speech is absolutely universal and current. Maybe that's why the book turns out to be a real gem. The author's question about the meaning of life and its constraints becomes, slowly and inevitably, ours! In a hotel in New York for only women, Esther, nineteen, brilliant schoolgirl, winner of a stay offered by a fashion magazine, begins to feel "like a racehorse in a world without tracks". Around her, above her is the ruthless, bourgeois and mccarthyist America of the 50s. An alienated world, a real bell jar that crushes the protagonist under the weight of its protection, gradually removing the air. The alternative will be to indulge in the sweet charm of death or be invaded by the blue waves of electric shock. Sylvia was a most unique rose with the toughest of thorns, a rose no one should have ever dared to gather without the softest velvety gloves.That no one should have ever dared to gather at all.I wish I could have known her. Speak to her. Just once. About the writing. About love. About that hole she knows too well. That I know too well. Esther. Sylvia. She was, she was, she was. And she is, she is, she is. 🥀https://www.instagram.com/p/BwmfRveHy...

The book really spoke to me because the lockdown actually gave me too much time to analyze problems that I didn't really have. I took a deep breath and listened to the old brag of my heart : I am, I am, I am (alive). Esther's bell jar is our bubble. Esther was trapped in a bell jar of confusion and it got in the way of the success she had perceived for herself.  The Bell Jar is the story of Esther's descent into depression told from her perspective and is thus, harrowing.But it's wonderful how Sylvia Plath made Ester go lyrical even in such a vulnerable state of being. The book is an interplay of emotions and norms presented using analogies that gave me a lot to reflect on. Nothing that Esther achieved mattered to her because she wasn't content within and her toxic productivity dragged her into depression. The Bell Jar is an important work of feminist literature and was banned just because the protagonist couldn't reason with the necessity to fit into the roles society had dictated for women. The Bell Jar is a coming of age story of a young woman burdened with more than her fair share of anguish. Parts of it read like a mental health memoir and because the author's own depression and death shadowed this work, it felt like her last cry for help.

The Bell Jar by Sylvia Plath chronicles the psychological crack-up of Esther Greenwood: brilliant, beautiful, enormously talented, and successful, but slowly going under—maybe for the last time. Sylvia Plath masterfully draws the reader into Esther's breakdown with such intensity that Esther's insanity becomes completely real and even rational, as probable and accessible an experience as going to the movies. Such deep penetration into the dark and harrowing corners of the psyche is an extraordinary accomplishment and has made The Bell Jar a haunting American classic. Some reviewers have stated that the story is somewhat autobiographical in that the author had been going through similar things in her life.

This only novel by Sylvia Plath is semi biographical. It tells the story of Esther Greenwood who in the 1950s wins an internship with several other girls at a New York magazine. Esther unable to sleep has a mental breakdown questioning her decisions in life, relationships and what she wants to do in her lifeEsther through black humor descends further into depression and try’s to commit suicide. She is sent to an asylum where thanks to an enlightened psychiatrist has the bell jar lifted. the beach scene where she contemplated suicide is very powerful in imagery for me. The novel talks about the treatment of mentally ill people in the 1950s and the use of electric therapy

The girls that get it, get it and the girls that don't, don't.Aside from the racist comments this has become a new favorite for me.I loved the way Plath wrote about depression, it almost felt like she had scooped out a part of my brain and put it on paper.

I don’t think I have ever read a book so short yet so powerful! I am honestly blown away and that is a rare and precious find in a book. I connected with the main character fast and at an intensity it almost hurt. The only other times I’ve felt this is with ‘a little life’ and ‘the goldfinch’. I must admit I do have a love of dark academia prose. Something about them connects so deeply with my soul. It almost frightens me, although in a sense it could be said I have a dark side to my complex and damaged mind. There’s something that spending almost a year in a mental hospital does to a person…anyhow I cannot praise this book enough. It had all the harrowing of ‘a little life’ but squeezed into 244 pages; now that takes talent! Don’t get me wrong I utterly LOVE both books but it is incredible the way different authors work to portray similar outcomes. There is so much to be gained from this book but I will share just one piece of the wisdom that stood out to me:“I saw my life branching out before me like the green fig-tree in the story. From the tip of every branch, like a fat purple fig, a wonderful future beckoned and winked. One fig was a husband and a happy home and children, and another fig was a famous poet and another fig was a brilliant professor….(the list goes on)….and beyond and above these figs were many more figs I couldn’t quite make out. I saw myself sitting in the crotch of this fig-tree, starving to death, just because I couldn’t make up my mind which of the figs to choose. I wanted each and every one of them, but choosing one meant losing all the rest, and, as I sat there, unable to decide, the figs began to wrinkle and go black and one by one, they plopped to the ground at my feet.”So powerful and poetic!I read on and on and it was so engaging, so intriguing and intense and then…it ended. 😭 I was so not ready. I’m still not ready. I need more.

I took a deep breath and listened to the old brag of my heart. I am, I am, I am.Sylvia Plath is one of the doyens of confessional poetry –The Bell Jar, her semi-autobiographical novel, falls into the same category. It's written with an emotional honesty that makes one gasp. Plath wrote it "in order to free (herself)from the past" & to show"how isolated a person feels when he is suffering a break down."To the person in the bell jar, blank and stopped as a dead baby, the world itself is a bad dream. It's never easy to read about mental illness- how tortuous then to write about it!DFW took recourse to high irony in The Depressed Person- Plath describes her character's ordeal with a light touch, airily, matter-of-factly with wry humour as if it were nothing- but the long drawn out, sad spectacle of self pity & suicide attempts left me exhausted, emotionally wrung out.The very opening page with its ominous reference to the Rosenberg executions, not only sets the time frame but also the major theme – the lurking build up of Esther Greenwood's nervous breakdown behind the glamarous facade of a month-long New York stint as a student guest editor in a fashion magzine:It was my first big chance, but here I was, sitting back and letting it run through my fingers like so much water.Yet it's hard to pin down the reason for this sudden unravelling:The one thing I was good at was winning scholarships and prizes, and that era was coming to an end.Is it the pressure that every high achiever feels- to consistently deliver the goods?Again DFW's parallel comes to mind- as a student he suffered the same  breakdowns, suicide attempts, and hospitalizations & yet passed his double honours summa cum laude, ditto with Plath. One often wonders, whether their brilliance/creativity came from the same dark place as the suffering!But Bell Jar is not just a memoir of mental illness, it is also a social commentary on the 1950s America: the expected gender roles that Esther finds so stifling; the limited choice of being a wife & mother & an English major with knowledge of shorthand & typing!That’s one of the reasons I never wanted to get married. The last thing I wanted was infinite security and to be the place an arrow shoots off from. I wanted change and excitement and to shoot off in all directions myself, like the colored arrows from a Fourth of July rocket.The sexual revolution of the sixties was far off, yet "fitted out" Esther feels like her own woman! The whole dating scene & the pressure to (ahem ahem) lose virginity sound so quaint in today's America but these ideas still find resonance in traditional society like an Indian one.After finishing the book, I read her Ariel poems again & was struck by how many ideas & images from The Bell Jar find expression there! Do read those poems to fully appreciate Sylvia's beautiful though tortured mind.The myth of the Sylvia Suicide Doll:I had seen 'Sylvia' when it came out & liked it (if 'liked' is the right word here), with an earnest Gwyneth Paltrow & a then lesser known Daniel Craig as Ted Hughes (dark & brooding in a Byronic fashion), & I wasn't any clear to the source of her sorrow then as now - here was a woman, desirable in every way - bright as a penny, creative, good-looking & yet suffering from such insecurity & low self-esteem that she was continually harsh on herself & consequently on others as well.Yes there were reasons - post-partum depression, her fragile mental & physical health, the breakup of her marriage, the alleged ( but never proven) sexual abuse in her childhood, the pressure of not only being a single mother but also a writer/poet.Says Lois Ames :  The conflict between the life style of a poet/intellectual and that of a wife and mother became a central preoccupation, and she wrote "...it's quite amazing how I've gone around for most of my life as in the rarefied atmosphere under a bell jar.I leave you with these lines from Lady Lazarus that never fail to move me:"Dying Is an art, like everything else. I do it exceptionally well. I do it so it feels like hell. I do it so it feels real. I guess you could say I've a call. It's easy enough to do it in a cell. It's easy enough to do it and stay put. It's the theatrical Comeback in broad day To the same place, the same face, the same brute Amused shout: 'A miracle!' That knocks me out. There is a charge For the eyeing my scars, there is a charge For the hearing of my heart--- It really goes. And there is a charge, a very large charge For a word or a touch Or a bit of blood Or a piece of my hair on my clothes. So, so, Herr Doktor. So, Herr Enemy. I am your opus, I am your valuable, The pure gold baby That melts to a shriek. I turn and burn. Do not think I underestimate your great concern. Ash, ash--- You poke and stir. Flesh, bone, there is nothing there---- A cake of soap, A wedding ring, A gold filling. Herr God, Herr Lucifer Beware Beware. Out of the ash I rise with my red hair And I eat men like air."And 50 years from her death, I still say what a waste, what a waste! Last time I felt that for Amy Winehouse.

3.5 Stars. I liked this book. It was an interesting perspective at what it was like to have depression in the 50's and I enjoyed the writing a lot. The best thing about this book is Esther herself. She seemed very real (which isn't surprising seeing as how the book is semi-autobiographical) and she was a likeable & relatable character. I liked her sense of humour and her overall disposition too. The other characters weren't really that fleshed out but I didn't mind because this book is about Esther. The next best thing about the book was the writing. I really enjoyed it. I thought she had some amazing imagery, similes and metaphors. I have such a hard time describing how I feel and when someone compares their feelings to something so accurately, it blows me away. I found a lot of Esther's inner-monologue relatable and the bits that weren't relatable, were extremely interesting. I felt like the story got lost a bit in the middle and it lost me a little bit. Things were sort of muddled and all over the place. What's interesting though is when I have my big depressive episodes, things get muddled and all over the place too. While I was reading it, I wasn't really enjoying it as much as I was enjoying it at the start but then when I thought about it, I realised that it was actually very accurate and it just shows how real this book is. Plus Esther herself was all muddled in the middle too. Overall, I did enjoy this. I'm not completely satisfied giving this a 3.5 star rating but I think it's the closest to satisfied that I will get. This one is a hard one to rate. I would recommend this and I would read other works by Sylvia Plath. ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~“(I felt very still and very empty, the way the eye of a tornado must feel, moving dully along in the middle of the surrounding hullabaloo.)”“It was my first big chance, but here I was, sitting back and letting it run through my fingers like so much water.”“It’s like watching Paris from an express caboose heading in the opposite direction—every second the city gets smaller and smaller, only you feel it’s really you getting smaller and smaller and lonelier and lonelier, rushing away from all those lights and that excitement at about a million miles an hour.”“I wondered why I couldn’t go the whole way doing what I should any more. This made me sad and tired. Then I wondered why I couldn’t go the whole way doing what I shouldn’t, the way Doreen did, and this made me even sadder and more tired.”“For the first time in my life... I felt dreadfully inadequate. The trouble was, I had been inadequate all along, I simply hadn’t thought about it.”“I saw myself sitting in the crotch of this fig tree, starving to death, just because I couldn’t make up my mind which of the figs I would choose. I wanted each and every one of them, but choosing one meant losing all the rest, and, as I sat there, unable to decide, the figs began to wrinkle and go black, and, one by one, they plopped to the ground at my feet.”“As the houses grew more familiar, I slunk still lower.I felt it was very important not to be recognized.”“Inertia oozed like molasses through Elaine’s limbs. That’s what it must feel like to have malaria, she thought.”“But when it came right down to it, the skin of my wrist looked so white and defenseless that I couldn’t do it. It was as if what I wanted to kill wasn’t in that skin or the thin blue pulse that jumped under my thumb, but somewhere else, deeper, more secret, and a whole lot harder to get at.”“I wanted to tell her that if only something were wrong with my body it would be fine, I would rather have anything wrong with my body than something wrong with my head,”“If Mrs. Guinea had given me a ticket to Europe, or a round-the-world cruise, it wouldn’t have made one scrap of difference to me, because wherever I sat—on the deck of a ship or at a street café in Paris or Bangkok—I would be sitting under the same glass bell jar, stewing in my own sour air.”“I hated these visits, because I kept feeling the visitors measuring my fat and stringy hair against what I had been and what they wanted me to be, and I knew they went away utterly confounded.”
Maybe someday I will be able to articulate my complicated thoughts, but today is not that day.

This has probably been the most surreal experience I've ever had while reading a novel. I cannot begin to explain how I feel about it. I am extremely confused.Sylvia Plath has been my undisputed literary muse eversince my eyes first took in her words. Reading her journals was like reading about all that I felt and experienced told through the words of the most eloquent writer I had ever had the pleasure to read. That made me so anxious! I revered those quotes, I knew that Sylvia like I knew mylself, what if I read her actual published work and didn't like it? It seemed so important.So I started with her poetry, and read Ariel, was blown away, and confirmed my love for her.But for some reason I always felt anxiety over The Bell Jar, I don't know why. Now that I finally decided to read it, I don't really know how to review it. Was it good? Yup. Special? Sure. But was it mind-blowing like the other stuff I read by her? No...There were a couple of things that bothered me. Her vivid characterization was there, but not all the way through. There was a character indicated merely as "The Negro" in a chapter, and that would have been bad enough, had she not hammered it into oblivion, announcing him as "The Negro" a total of nine times in the span of two measly pages.I thought there would be a clear before and after The Bell Jar in my life. That's how anticipated this book was for me. However, I still don't know why people tattoo the quote "I am, I am, I am," on their skin. I thought after reading the book I'd be in on the secret. But I still don't get it. Because to me it felt like her heartbeat mocked her while it sounded "I am, I am, I am!", and in the end it still did not seem like she wanted it to continue sounding its assurances. Maybe I missed something, and maybe I’m just being a pessimist, but that's how it translated to me.Overall, Sylvia did not let me down, of course. I still adore her. I guess she's just a bit more human now.

Esther Greenwood is a brilliant writer, a student at Smith College, who is spending a month interning at a fashion magazine in New York City in the 1950s. At the beginning of this coming-of-age book, she suffers from depression, unhappy with any of the choices she has to make in life, but is still functioning. When she returns home to Massachusetts, she spirals into despair and depression, unable to sleep or write or eat. While on the outside it might look like Esther has everything going for her in life, inside she feels like a bell jar had descended over her, she has a nervous breakdown, and attempts to end her life. Her experiences at various mental hospitals, when psychiatry was not very advanced, are related to us.The book is known to be a semi-autobiographical account of Sylvia Plath's own life. She absolutely sucks the reader into her world with her account of what it is like going through a mental breakdown. Amazingly, she is able to make her account occasionally witty while writing about the scariness of mental illness. Perhaps Sylvia Plath's emotional makeup led her to feel and reflect about life much more deeply than the average person. While that gave beauty and genius to her writing, it also drove her to despair.This book ends with the author's release from the mental hospital. In thinking what lay ahead she says, "All I could see were question marks." That sent chills through me because she did eventually commit suicide in 1963.

this book definitely took me a while to get into, but once i was invested enough i finished the rest in about one sitting. i studied some of sylvia plath’s poetry in school and enjoyed it, which was why i’ve wanted to read the bell jar for years. the writing in this book only makes it more evident that sylvia plath was a gifted writer, her use of language is lyrical and honest. the depiction of a young woman struggling to fit into constrictive feminine social roles, unsure of whether she can be maternal, sexual and intellectual at once, was a struggle that i think is still very relatable to women decades later. i also found that throughout reading, i could tell that many modern books have taken inspiration from this, which just provides more evidence that sylvia plath was ahead of her time with this book.

3.5 starsI never thought I would be reading as much from Sylvia Plath as I am reading now. I was introduced to her through the Confessional Poetry unit that summed up my American Literature II class and she was certainly over the top with the way she conveyed herself. I did not like her poems "Daddy" and Lady Lazarus" by any means, for I felt that she was taking sympathy from people that were in far worse situations than hers. I have expressed my distaste for both of these poems on Literary Gladiators against the opposing views of the others on the panel and, sure enough, these episodes received strong viewership. This led me to incorporate a Sylvia Plath work on each season and I have realized that "Cut" and "Tulips" were quite fascinating in their nature, especially with how "Tulips" presents the point of view of being in an institution. It has also been cited as the point where Plath's writing became dark and what Ted Hughes described as what "was the first sign of what was on its way" (from a biographical note by Lois Ames).Then I decided to approach The Bell Jar. This is the only novel that Sylvia Plath has written and is deemed as one of the closest views we can get of Plath's very own struggles and this, perhaps, would help us learn more about why she was the way she was. While the struggles of Esther Greenwood run a few parallels to Plath's very own life, this is still a work of fiction that takes a different direction to some capacity. Esther starts out in New York City engaged in a summer internship at Ladies Day magazine. She is also involved in plenty of evening festivities that she does not seem to enjoy as much as the others, not to mention a more "off the beaten path" outlook of her surroundings. She also looks back on her relationship with Buddy Willard, who wants to become a doctor and marry a woman that will take on traditional, womanly attributes and duties (which Esther does not possess), but life's circumstances cause Buddy to change his course and this creates a strain between Esther and Buddy's relationship.Upon returning to Massachusetts to stay with her mother and engage in the opportunities that await while she is there, things begin to fall through for Esther and she begins to enter a state of depression that turns into a loss of her sanity that requires medical care. Throughout the novel, we follow Esther through her inconsistent state of affairs and how one moment things are calm and sound and in the next, things start to tick and she is required to stay at an even more restricted institution. With the story being told from Esther's first person account, we follow her along through the moments of her life and the struggles that take place within this life of hers.The Bell Jar was a somewhat complicated reading experience, which I feel it is supposed to be. Esther is not the most reliable narrator to say the very least in where she leaves out specific details regarding how she gets from one point to the next, which I feel is primarily intended, though it leaves us with an execution that creates a slight strain on me the reader. The execution in general can be a bit burdensome in my and other people's experience in reading this novel. There are also plenty of moments that lead me to think, "why the heck did she just do THAT?" Some of the inconsistencies come with the deterioration of one's mental state, but the way in which it was conveyed could have been a little less blurry. HOWEVER, I think that this is a novel that I will continue to think about and there is a lot to explore and talk about within the text. It is challenging to pinpoint technicalities within this text, for I feel it was not Plath's priority in putting forth this novel that was essentially telling her story on a fictional canvas. I think that if Plath's intent was to make you think beyond the text for any given reason, then I think she succeeded. If you want to learn more about mental conditions, insanity, the deterioration of the mind, and are looking for something different, this is a book for you. If you want something organized, consistent, and reliable, this is by no means the book you should be reading. This definitely tied my brain up in a few knots, but I would not expect any less from Sylvia Plath.You can find the Literary Gladiators discussion about this book (containing spoilers) here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=clJWq...

সিলভিয়া প্লাথ এই একটাই উপন্যাস লিখেছিলেন। এর পাতায় পাতায় বিষন্নতার ছাপ, কেমন শ্বাসরোধ করা জীবনের গল্প। নামটাও তেমন শ্বাসরোধী- The Bell Jar. কিন্তু পড়তে ভালো লাগে। কারণ লেখিকার সততা, কাহিনীর বাস্তবতা, প্রাসঙ্গিকতা; এছাড়া লেখার ধরণটাও চমৎকার। মৃত্যুচিন্তা নিয়ে সিলভিয়ার অস্বাস্থ্যকর অবসেশন ছিল। একবারে প্রথম লাইন থেকেই শুরু হয়েছে মৃত্যুর আলাপ। তবে শুরুটা খুব ভালোলেগেছে, আমেরিকার ইতিহাসের একটা অস্থির সময়কে নির্দেশ করেছেন বলে, আর চমৎকার ভাষায় উপন্যাসের মূল গল্পটার একটা আভাস দিয়ে দিয়েছেন।প্রথম প্যারাগ্রাফটা:It was a queer, sultry summer, the summer they electrocuted the Rosenbergs, and I didn't know what I was doing in New York. I'm stupid about executions. The idea of being electrocuted makes me sick, and that's all there was to read about in the papers—goggle-eyed headlines staring up at me on every street corner and at the fusty, peanut-smelling mouth of every subway. It had nothing to do with me, but I couldn't help wondering what it would be like, being burned alive all along your nerves.জুন, ১৯৫৩। জুলিয়াস রোজেনবার্গ ও ইথেল রোজেনবার্গ, সোভিয়েতের হয়ে গুপ্তচরবৃত্তির অভিযোগে যাদের মৃত্যুদণ্ড হয়। তবে সে ভিন্ন আলাপ। উপন্যাসের সাথে সম্পর্কযুক্ত না।এটা semi-autobiographcal উপন্যাস। মূল চরিত্রের নাম এস্থার গ্রিনউড। স্বভাবতই এস্থার মেধাবী, অহংকারী, খিটখিটে মেজাজের, মাত্রাতিরিক্ত সংবেদনশীল, অকপট, সৎ, সাহসী, এবং তিনি ডিপ্রেশনে আক্রান্ত, আত্মহত্যাপ্রবণ। যারা দীর্ঘদিন ধরে ডিপ্রেশনে ভুগছেন, বা যারা ডিপ্রেশনে ভোগা মানুষদের সাথে ওঠাবসা করেন নিয়মিত; তাদের মনে রেখাপাত করার মত অনেক কিছু আছে The Bell Jar -এ। কিছু মানুষ খুবই ভাবপ্রবণ, বাস্তবের চাইতে কল্পনাই তাদের মনের বেশিরভাগ জুড়ে থাকে। বিষন্নতা এই ধরণের মানুষকে বায়ু সংক্রামক ভাইরাসের মত আক্রমণ করে। দার্শনিক সেনেকার একটা কথা আছে- আমরা বাস্তবে যে পরিমাণ যন্ত্রণাভোগ করি, কল্পনায় করি তার থেকেও বেশি। বড়বেলায় এসে স্বাপ্নিক যখন আবিষ্কার করে ছোটবেলার রঙিন স্বপ্নগুলো মরিচীকা(বেশিরভাগের জীবনেই তাই), একটা বড় ধাক্কা খায়। একদল ধাক্কাটা সামলে ওঠে, বাস্তবতা মেনে নেয়; অপরদল ব্যাপারটা মেনে নিতে চায় না। তারা ভাবে - এমন পৃথিবীতে তো আমি আসতে চাইনি! এই উপন্যাসের এস্থার গ্রিনউড মানুষের সীমাবদ্ধতা না মেনে নেওয়াদের দলে, এস্থার হতে চেয়েছেন সবকিছু। সিলভিয়া প্লাথ অন্য এক জায়গায় লিখেছেন:I want to live and feel all the shades, tones and variations of mental and physical experience possible in my life. And I am horribly limited.সব সীমাবদ্ধতা যে মানুষ হয়ে জন্মাবার জন্যই, ব্যাপারটা তেমনও নয়। কিছু সীমাবদ্ধতা নারী হয়ে জন্মাবার কারণে, এক্ষেত্রে পুরুষের অবস্থান তুলনাম��লক সুবিধাজনক। ১৯৫০ এর দশকে আমেরিকার একজন মধ্যবিত্ত পরিবারের নারীর পক্ষে সংসার ও ক্যারিয়ার একই সাথে সামলানো সহজ ছিল না, কারণ তারা অনেকেই স্বামীর সমর্থন পেতেন না।এই নারীবাদ সম্পর্কিত অংশটা উপন্যাসের সবচেয়ে গুরুত্বপূর্ণ বিষয়বস্তুর একটি।The Bell Jar -এর আকর্ষণীয় দিক লেখিকার অকপট সততা। তার ছায়াচরিত্র এস্থার গ্রিনউড কোন প্রেরণাদায়ী নারী নন, মানসিকভাবে বিপর্যস্ত খটমটে মেজাজের এক���ন নারী; কিন্তু তবুও তিনি সহানুভূতির উদ্রেক করেন। তার সমস্যাগুলি রিলেটেবল বলে, আমাদের চেনাশোনা কিছু মানুষদের কথাও মনে পড়ে যায়, তাদের প্রতিও মমতা জাগে।

Sepultada por un millón de sentimientos, asfixiantes y corrosivos, termino de leer a Plath. Esa autora de la que siempre he oído hablar; esa mujer de la que supe antes sobre su muerte que sobre su vida. Esa mujer, que con su escritura ha inspirado a tantas otras mujeres. Desconfiada y anhelante, decidí empezar por “La campana de crista”, una obra que me era desconocida más allá del hedor lúgubre que la sociedad ha creado entorno a este libro, entorno a ella. Y no sé qué habría pensando al leerlo a los dieciséis años; probablemente habría encontrado entre sus páginas a una compañera de viaje en una época oscura, depresiva y difícil de mi vida. Lo que sí sé es la gran lectura que he podido padecer y disfrutar estos días, dándole la mano, cálida entre este gélido ambiente, a Sylvia Plath.“La campana de cristal” es una obra semiautobiográfica en la que conocemos a Esther Greenwood, el alter ego de la propia Plath, que no está dividida en dos partes y que sin embargo yo me empeño en dividir. En la primera mitad conocemos a una mujer en cierta forma independiente, que no anhela una vida matrimonial, sino la libertad; y con su ironía y gracia veremos la vida de una mujer en los años cincuenta muy entretenida, bien narrada, y con un toque de humor muy característico. A partir de la segunda mitad todo cambia, su sueño de ser escritora, truncado por la negativa a entrar un curso en la universidad, la hacen sumirse en una situación que muchas de nosotras hemos podido vivir; ¿qué hago con mi vida? ¿A dónde voy? ¿Quién soy? Volcada sobre todas estas reflexiones, y dejada por la depresión que ya habitaba en ella, termina interna en un hospital psiquiátrico donde todo se oscurece y se pudre.Esta obra narra, con asombrosa sinceridad, el proceso por el cual pasa una persona que tiene pulsiones suicidas. El pensar constante de como hacerlo para que sea final, perfecto. Esa obsesión con no dejar resquicios a la vida. La tranquilidad para engañar y planificar cada uno de los pasos, o la simple idea tranquilizadora de pensar en ellos. “La campana de cristal” es un libro ejemplar para tratar, sin trabas, mitos o tabús algo que se tiene tan silenciado como son los impulsos suicidas, que pasan, que están ahí. Siempre digo que no hablar sobre algo, silenciarlo, no hace que ese algo deje de existir. Y esto es aplicable a las personas con pulsiones suicidas; se podrán superar, o no, con el tiempo, pero evitar hablar de ello no es bueno para nadie. Plath habla también de la terrible “terapia” de electroshocks a la que la sometieron y las consecuencias de la misma, el miedo paralizante, el no entendimiento del maltrato a un cuerpo. Todas aquellas cosas que sabemos que han pasado dentro de centros destinados a la curación de la salud.Sylvia Plath me ha parecido una escritora magnífica, pero sobre todo una mujer muy interesante. No tardaré en leer sus diarios, sus cartas… todo aquello que caiga en mis manos.

Θα σου πω τι σκεφτόμουν με αυτό το βιβλίο, που το άκουγα σε όντιο στο διάδρομο του γυμναστηρίου. Σκεφτόμουν λοιπόν πόσο διαφορετικά διαβάζουμε τα βιβλία σε κάθε ηλικιακή μας περίοδο. Και θα εξηγήσω γιατί. Η ηρωίδα είναι μια νεαρή ταλαντούχα ύπαρξη που πέφτει σε βαθιά και βαρι�� κατάθλιψη ουσιαστικά όταν έρχεται αντιμέτωπη με την πραγματικότητα, με τη ζωή γενικά, αλλά και τη ζωή πιο ειδικά ως γυναίκα που ήταν και είναι κάποια τσικ πιο πολύπλοκα δύσκολη. Θεωρώ ότι πολλοί άνθρωποι μπορούμε να ταυτιστούμε με αυτό, γιατί οι περισσότεροι αν όχι όλοι έχουμε αυτή την ανάγκη να διαφέρουμε, να αναγνωριστούμε, κάποιος να μας ξεχωρίζει και να μας πει πόσο έξυπνοι, όμορφοι, ιδιαίτεροι, λαμπεροί, ταλαντούχοι είμαστε. Αλλά. Εδώ μου σκάει και αυτή η φοβερή φράση του Φράνζεν στην Ελευθερία: "nothing disturbs the feeling of specialness like the presence of other human beings feeling identically special". Αυτό όμως, σας αίσθηση, σαν γνώση, είναι κάτι που το αποκτάς μεγαλώνοντας, διαβάζοντας, εξελίσσοντας τον εαυτό σου. Όταν λοιπόν πρωτοδιάβασα αυτό το βιβλίο στα 23 μου, είχα νιώσει τόση ταύτιση, που ένιωσα καταραμένη χαραμισμένη ύπαρξη που θα σβήσει και θα μείνει ένα πουφ μέσα στον χωροχρόνο και όλο αυτό μου προκαλούσε πόνο. Πλησιάζοντας τα 40, γνωρίζοντας πολύ καλά ότι ξυπνήσω δεν ξυπνήσω ο κόσμος θα γυρίσει, ζώντας βέβαια και κάποιες δεκαετίες αργότερα όπου η γυναίκα αρχίζει να επιβάλλει τη δυναμική της, συμπονώ την Έσθερ, θέλω να της κάνω πατ πατ και να της πω ότι όχι, τίποτα δεν θα πάει καλύτερα, απλά εσύ πρέπει να βρεις τρόπους να ξεχνιέσαι, όλα καλά, κάποια στιγμή όλοι πεθαίνουμε, ιτσοκέι. Αστειεύομαι. Φυσικά. Ή και όχι.

Znate ono kad vas pozovu na neki rođendan, kazavši vam da će biti samo neobavezna sedeljka, vi pođete, ponevši neku sitnicu i puno srdačnosti, a kad počnu da pristižu uparađene zvanice, ozarene iza skupocenih poklon kutija, bude vam veoma neprijatno, pa niste sigurni da li da se osećate nevaspitano ili izigrano. To je otprilike osećaj sa kojim komentarišem Stakleno zvono.Ako odvajamo piščev život od njegovog dela, a jedino tako je, mislim, pravično, ovaj roman Silvije Plat je tek korektan. Naprosto, u malo šta je uspela da me uveri. Pre-opisala je, kao kad glumac preglumi ulogu, i tako istinski užas štreberski svela na gole činjenice, na intrigante, ali ipak faktografske podatke u filigranskom povezu. Izvesno joj je veoma stalo da bude shvaćena ali je, previše se trudeći da to osigura, previše uglancala, nekako previše namotala, previše išmirglala agoniju. Podgrevala je santu jeze naivnom slikovitošću – u nameri da zaštiti čitaoca, hajde da verujemo – i postigla utisak tek bezazlenog kondenza, jedva barice. Bez ostatka mi je jasno da (najmanje) takav i jeste odnos jedne krhke duše pred mukama ove magnitude i da su joj borbeni izgledi upravo takvi, ali Silvija to saopštava nekako deklamatorski, kao da je više guši trema od javnog nastupa nego ono zbog čega je stala na binu. U kontekstu potonjih događaja – šah mat, ali, koliko god bezdušna ova izjava bila, smatram da taj kontekst nije bitan, osim ako se ne želi raspravljati pro i contra suicida, preko genetskog kodiranja takvih ideja, sve do pitanja neumitnosti sudbine. Stakleno zvono je lako prohodno, ne smara i ne muči, ali, samostalno, ničim ne impresionira. Taman za trojku.

I only found about this classic from "The Gilmore Girls" TV show because Rory was reading it and I was curious enough to Google it. I'm glad I did because I probably wouldn't have picked it up then.A coming of age story about a woman who sheds the usual expectations of womanhood. She rejects having to marry and turns to her ambitious career. That is until she descends rapidly into severe depression. Her struggles are thought-provoking and intense. I loved that Esther felt out of place. Where one feels like they can't fit in, they always think there is something wrong with themselves. I couldn't help but relate to Esther in this way. I also love how she is independent and rejects men who seem like they're virgins and are good on paper when in truth they're not.I would have loved to read this in high school but I'm glad I didn't get to miss out on this classic.
