Hello, my name is Becky and I suck at reading (again). I've fallen back into a slump, and things that I start are taking me AGES to actually finish. I started listening to this audiobook during my drive back from July's bookclub meeting, but wasn't actually intending to read the book then... it was just on my Audible app and something to listen to at the time. So I didn't even add it to my Currently Reading shelf, which is my MUST-DO process for tracking my reads. Anyway, so it wasn't officially something I was reading, but I made it through a big chunk of it... and then during August's (and coincidentally my last) book club meeting that wasn't (sigh) drive, I finished listening to it. And afterward, I realized that it's a book in two parts, and with all of the other wrongness regarding how I approached and consumed this book, I realized after finishing that I had unintentionally split my drive-reads along the fault line in the book, which would be impressive skill, had I actually tried to do it that way. That's a weird opening to this review, and probably doesn't even make sense. Nothing I do makes sense anymore. OK. Let me back up. I have had The Bell Jar on my TBR for... over a decade. But I never got around to it. I didn't know anything about Sylvia Plath except that she wrote poetry and had killed herself. I'm no poetry fan, so that didn't exactly have me beating down the bookstore doors to get my hands on her work, and the suicide was... I dunno. Not unimportant, but just... I didn't really know how it was relevant to her writing. Well, of course, NOW I do. Because that's what reading is for! Wait... still getting ahead of myself. So I have had this on my "One-Day-I-Should-Read-This" shelf for years and years, but with no real plan of reading it, until I signed up for a reading challenge that offered bonus points for blowing the dust off of one's ancient TBR books and actually reading them. So, when I got some Audible cred (I'm so cool), I picked it up, and figured that I could probably do a bit worse than listening to Maggie Gyllenhaal read to me for a while, instead of reading the kindle version which would probably languish on my night table for the next decade. So, going into this without really knowing anything about what this not-poetry novel would be about, other than a vague "mental illness" theme, I was initially not loving it. AT ALL. In fact, I was ready to shut it down and return it to Audible and delete it from the kindle and leave a gaping crater where the file once was after less than an hour of listening... but the ONLY reason I stuck with it was because I was stuck in the car already and didn't feel like stopping the car just to find something else to take up space in the silence. (I have music, yes, but if I'm in the car alone for more than an hour, it's audiobook time. Otherwise I feel like I've wasted that time.)So, why was I ready to set fire to my kindle and suchlike? Read on! But, umm, probably spoilery shit ahead. Be warned. The book opens with young (18-19 year old?) Esther and her friend Doreen going out to an event with some friends that they obviously think they are too cool for, then ditching their lame plans for a RANDOM STRANGER WHO WALKS UP TO THEIR TAXI IN TRAFFIC AND INVITES THEM FOR DRINKS. Esther decides to call herself "Elly", and Doreen goes along with it, because sure, why not? Then they go back to RANDOM TRAFFIC PICK UP ARTIST'S house, where Esther's friend proceeds to get drunk and all sorta frisky with RANDOM TRAFFIC PICK UP ARTIST STRANGER THAT THEY DON'T KNOW ISN'T A RAPIST MURDERER... and then Esther gets bored and ghosts her friend, leaving Doreen alone with the MAYBE RAPIST MURDERER GUY. THEN, because of course there's a THEN, when Doreen is brought back to E's dorm at 3am or 4am or whatever, blackout drunk and needing help, Esther does the bare minimum, and essentially ghosts her again afterward. She has moved on from Doreen, and that's all there is to it. And I was like... And I immediately did not like Esther Greenwood. Because, sure, her friend is probably fake and backstabby and catty, but seriously, what. the. fuck. That is NOT okay.But then that is just... it. The book, Esther and her friend, continue on as normal. Friendo even starts DATING the guy. So all's well and good in the free and easy 60s, I guess. But my modern Woman Safety Internal Alarm System was ringing like crazy, and it made me anxious and uncomfortable and on edge for a good chunk of the book, because I was waiting for the other shoe to drop, for the repercussions of that night to come about. But it never did. It simply never came up again. This book, via Esther, exists entirely in its own present. It doesn't dwell or reflect on the past. It just is what it is at the moment. Characters move in and out of the story, and when they are relevant, they are there, and when they are not, they just no longer exist. Decisions are made, dreams and aspirations are vitally important one minute, but cast aside the next for a newer, shinier, more glamorous something. It's self-exploratory, in a kind of way that lacks insight, but is insightful despite that. It just is what it is. (Read that not in the trite, dismissive way that people use the phrase "it is what it is", but as a statement of fact. OK thanks!) The slide into the mental illness part of this book was startling in its subtlety. It was there from the very beginning, but it's only in hindsight that one can see it. Take for instance the previously mentioned WTF scene I outlined. That's obviously fucked up and completely unsafe and abnormal (and don't tell me it's not) and sure, one could argue that the 60s were a new era of feminism and freedom for women, and that there was probably no reason to expect that the guy was unsafe. But throughout history, we have known men, and feared them. And the fact that Esther's only thought was for her own lack of fun at this "party" should have been a tip off to me that she was living in a different reality inside her own head. It could be, simply, that she imagined that the identity she had assumed that night, Elly, wasn't the type to hang around if she was bored, and so she didn't. Who knows? Certainly not me. Maybe not even Esther. We live in E's head, and we're along for the ride with her, but that doesn't mean we know where she's going. We're just there to witness her struggle to reconcile who she is with who she thinks she is and who she wants to be, while she tries to make a place for herself, when she tries to remake herself to fit into a place she thinks exists, or should exist, or she thinks that people think she should exist in, even if it's diametrically opposed to the life she envisions for herself, whatever that is from moment to moment. We are with her when she asserts herself, when she is consistent, when she's anything but, when she has moments of clarity and self-inspection, and when she fails at everything, even giving up. I initially did not like the 60s intern-slash-party girl stuff. Her work - the superficialness of it, her fakeness, her way of being different with different people grated on my nerves. But then, after she really starts falling apart, and we get into her complete lethargy and withdrawal and her inability to see the point in anything that must be repeatedly done for upkeep and maintenance of life, it was such a drastic change, that I found myself, shitty as it is, wanting her to just TRY. And yet, at the same time, really identifying with the ideas and thoughts themselves. And then realizing that that's exactly the point. Mental illness doesn't come with instructions or specifics or check-boxes. It affects us all differently, and while I may be able to have these kinds of futility thoughts and still function (mostly) normally, someone else may be completely thwarted by them. I was quite disturbed by the sexism and misogyny displayed in this book, particularly when it came to E's treatment for her mental illness. It reminded me quite strongly of the portrayal of "care" depicted in Requiem For A Dream, which I believe took place (at least if one assumes that it is supposed to be contemporary to when it was published) nearly 2 decades later. We can make leaps and bounds of progress in science and technology, but to get humans to see other, slightly different humans as just ALSO human, progress is sluggish. I didn't realize that this book was a sort of fictionalized auto-biography. I thought it was a straight up novel in which the author writes from experience, but the writing itself is a complete fiction. Now knowing (from the afterword) that it was not JUST that, it adds a depth and urgency to the book that I don't think it would have had otherwise. The ending, the title, everything gains new meaning. Also, there's a bit of a meta quality, which I liked, wherein the author wrote about a fictionalized version of herself writing a fictionalized version of HERself. Though in the end, that was just a passing whim, as so much Esther thought and did was. How much of that quality was true to the author as well, I'm not sure, but I would guess not quite as much as she gave to Esther - considering that we actually have Plath's writing in hand. It's strange to me how much my appreciation for this book changed based on how ill Esther was. Before we really see her mental health issues manifesting, I found her profoundly unlikeable, and could not identify with her at all. But as she started her decline, I started to empathize and root for her to succeed in her treatment and recover, as much as that is possible - even though her marker for success is to get back to the person she was... which is the person I thought I'd disliked quite a lot. But that just goes to show that understanding and empathy are key. We never know what someone is going through. It's a good lesson to be reminded of. I think that, in the end, this is a book that needs to be read and re-read to fully appreciate it. Just thinking about it over the past couple days, my opinions have shifted several times, and I think that on re-read, I would get so much more out of it. I probably would read the text the next time though. Not that Maggie Gyllenhaal wasn't great, but I think I would like Esther to speak directly to me, instead of through an interpreter.

A bell jar is a piece of laboratory equipment used to contain vacuum. It's a clear glass jar made to be airless. A hose can be connected and the air is pumped out. A famous classroom experiment is to have inside the glass jar an alarm clock which is ringing as the air is pumped out. As the air disappears, you can't hear the alarm clock. If you are inside, perhaps, you can't really feel the world, it can't be touched or experienced except as distant thunder. You are trapped inside, distressed, ringing with sensory deprivation. And no matter how hard you try, all you can feel is the glass wall, not the wind, not touching people, not tasting food. Everything you see is distorted by the glass. It would be similar to being in an isolation tank. The title, I think, is about Esther's condition, a clue. She KNEW it was her brain, not the world and the things that happen. Her mental illness was causing a kind of disassociation, along with the distorted perceptions.The book seems to be a Rorschach test of sorts to readers. Some who I suspect do not have a clue about being permanently unbalanced think 'Esther Greenwood' is a crybaby. Some think the story disjointed - huh? Maybe they need to read it again straight through without interruptions. Others think she needs to toughen up or lighten up, or it's all boring. The worst inability to understand the book, I think, come from some readers who completely miss the fact Esther was almost raped, and she had to hide it, and most glaringly obvious of all, felt numb about it. She wasn't a libertine. She had one desire - to have experiences, adventures, to live. The first half of the book is about having those young adult adventures, which I believe to be common to most of us. Even though I grew up on the West Coast in the 1960's and 1970's, I found myself vibrating in tune with her baby-steps college life and grinning with remembrance (unlike Esther, I'm not going to tell the story about the first time I encountered a finger bowl!). Esther was amused by many things. - the nature of youth, people, men and women together, her errors of judgement and mistakes made - but I think what did her in was a total lack of resilience. I wish I knew where that gift of life comes from. I know I have it, and Esther didn't. If there is anything disjointed about this fictionalized autobiography, it's Esther's coming to terms with everything that happens. She's stuck at 'it happened'. Her failure at loving men who love her back, at making lasting connections, and at finding work she enjoys, devastates her. But the bell jar which encapsulates her silences her mind and senses. She's frozen in a mysterious vacuum of experience without process. Even when falling into various mud puddles of living, she feels virginal, untouched. The deep airless space of sadness surrounding her keeps her own enjoyment and sense of fun out there, and love is miles from her actual being, intellectually known, but she is emotionally numbed and insulated.She was a talented writer without luck or a famous family. At every turn, she was unable to get published, her other true tragedy, besides that of having an incurable mental illness, at the time. Instead, her mother advised learning shorthand (I was so advised, too, in 1968). Today, I think a Paxel-type pill would have helped her a great deal if it was depression, or something like. Of course, if it was schizophrenia, as some have suggested, she might have responded to some of the newer drugs. Either way, it doesn't seem she could fix this, if at all, without today's drugs. She had the kind of mental illness that comes from biochemical or wiring defects, not life experiences, I think. Crybaby? No. The book is disjointed, boring? No. She needed to toughen up or lighten up? Impossible with this type of mental illness, which is more about the brain than about the mind. I think the book is a literary treasure, a perfect description of living with a type of mental illness. Some readers pick up on her lack of options as a women's rights story, but I think in this case it's peripheral; however, it certainly was an issue, too. I can't see how having more respect or being taken more seriously would have helped her, though. So many people today who are talented and famous commit suicide still. If you have everything except resilience, you can remain a doomed person.I loved the writing, but Esther is a very sad case and this is a very depressing book. Given the time period of her suffering, I can't think of a time in American history more difficult to be mentally ill. Soldiers suffering from PTSD were being called out as cowards. Women, who had been building warships and weapons and plumbing, raising children alone, and making do with very little food in the stores, had been forced back into dresses and white gloves and little hats, housewife work, and manicuring lawns. When you married, you lost what little credit you may have possessed at the bank. You couldn't legally sign most contracts as a female, which means no woman could buy a house or car on credit. You even lost your name. Talk about 'the nanny state'. Men thought women were much lesser than themselves in all things. Women were either allowed the respect of uneducated scrubbers of toilets or put on pedestals, not recognized as beings that could scratch, fart or burp. Married people on TV slept in twin beds. But as Esther describes her psychiatric care in the second half of the novel I saw that she was respected by the doctors and worried about.For the ordinary person, at the time, being mentally ill was a case of moral weakness and a lack of personal fiber; and there was nothing more shameful than this to the general population. That perception is obvious from Esther's mom. I hate her, for the record. The others did not know how to help her. I think it was impossible without the proper medications we have today. The synapses of her brain didn't fire right - how could talk therapy or electric shock fix this?Regardless of the mental illness issue, the writing is superb. So many phrases to recall with thrills and chills. The lady WAS a great writer.

“The silence depressed me. It wasn't the silence of silence. It was my own silence.”Before I talk about how much I like this book, I want to mention that there are a lot of instances of blatant racism from the main character and surrounding characters, which is obviously not okay. The Bell Jar is dated and in some ways doesn't hold up to today's standards. Anyway, I'm glad I read this while still a teenager. I don't know if it would've resonated with me as much if I was older. Maybe it would, who knows? Sylvia Plath captures the complicated feelings of being a teenage girl so well and its accuracy was uncomfortable at times. (That's not a critique, btw.) I annotated this book and highlighted a lot of the themes which included femininity, sexuality, identity, class, and the idea of purity vs. impurity. I think all of those things are relevant today, even though the book is almost sixty years old.Esther Greenwood, the main character, is a successful college student in New York City and is passionate about writing. When the novel starts, she's headed on a downward spiral and spends most of her time in a sullen state and contemplates death and the meaning of life, something she isn't able to find no matter how much she wants to. She descends into a state of madness that leads her to dissociate from her life and she attempts suicide multiple times. Esther obsesses over the concept of purity and likes to compare herself to others. She thinks she's better than other women because she's a virgin and that she'll have an easier time finding a husband because of it. "Of course they would try to persuade a girl to have sex and say they would marry her later, but as soon as she gave in, they would lose all respect for her and start saying that if she did that with them she would do that with other men and they would end up by making her life miserable." For a while, Esther is afraid of that happening to her, but she figures out that the same expectation is not put on men and decides she wants to lose her virginity before getting married. Her on and off boyfriend Buddy Willard makes her aware of this by insinuating that he's been with other women. When she ends up losing her virginity to someone she doesn't know, it's a kind of sacrifice as she's letting go of a virtue that has the power to determine her worth. This happens after she's been in the mental hospital and has accepted the reality of her mental illness. She's in a place where keeping up with societal expectations means less to her.Esther's cynicism and sulkiness aren't typical of nineteen-year-old girls at the time, and she's forced to disguise that part of her personality to please others and submit to societal expectations. She withdraws from others and her relationships are built on misunderstandings. She feels like she can never express her thoughts on typically taboo topics because she has to comply with everyone else.Death is also an overarching theme of the novel that is brought up a lot. Esther attempts to commit suicide multiple times but finds small, practical reasons not to go through with it and it isn't until her final attempt that we see her mental illness for how serious it really is. Her final attempt is with pills, and she goes to a crawl space in the basement where she's hopeful she won't be found until after she's dead. She's mostly nonchalant about it and talks about her suicide passively. At other times in the novel, she mentions random deaths she notices in newspapers and the death of her father, whom she was never allowed to properly mourn.As a character, Esther is selfish and rarely considers the feelings of the people around her, though part of this behavior can be attributed to her mental illness and lack of self-awareness. She has no idea who she is and is sometimes unrecognizable even to herself. Her narration is funny and she's actually a lot of fun to listen to. She monologues a lot about various nihilistic topics, but Sylvia Plath's writing is so engaging that it's not strenuous. Esther has so many weird, but often relatable thoughts floating around in her head.I was actually surprised by the ending. I thought that Esther might not make it out of the mental hospital, but was relieved when she did. She was still just as cynical at the end, but at least she knew that there was hope for her life. She had reasons to live and the people around her assured her of that. It was a hopeful ending that showed readers who might be feeling some of the things Esther felt that there are ways to get better, which would've been an important thing to hear in the sixties. If I was a teenager at the time, I'm sure this would've been an extremely important book to me. Mental health isn't as taboo of a topic anymore, but it wasn't like that when this was published.(People aren't lying when they say The Bell Jar is like the female companion to The Catcher in the Rye. Both Esther and Holden have scathing inner monologues.)

, considerado por muitos a sua grande obra.Fazendo uma rápida pesquisa, na internet, podemos encontrar dois poemas, declamados pela própria;Lady LazarusDaddye também um artigo publicado em 2011, no jornal The Telegraph, sobre uma exposição, na The Major Gallery, em que foram exibidos 44 desenhos de Sylvia Plath.Algumas curiosidades sobre The Bell Jar:- Sylvia Plath queria escrever um romance como o The Snake Pit de Mary Jane Ward ;- A Campânula de Vidro foi inicialmente publicado sob o pseudónimo Victoria Lucas por dois motivos: proteger as pessoas que estavam ficcionadas no livro, e não constranger a sua mãe;- Originalmente a personagem principal também tinha o nome de Victoria mas por pressão do seu editor Sylvia alterou-a para Esther.- Em 1953, Sylvia Plath foi “editora” convidada da revista Mademoiselle;- A personagem Philomena Guinea foi baseada na madrinha literária de Sylvia Plath, Olive Higgins Prouty;- Tal como Esther, Sylvia Plath também tentou suicidar-se, e também foi enviada para um Hospital Psiquiátrico; - Depois de alguns anos de bloqueio, Sylvia escreveu este livro muito rapidamente – o rascunho ficou pronto em 70 dias;- The Bell Jar foi adaptado ao cinema e estreou em 1979;- Foi a primeira pessoa a ganhar um Prémio Pulitzer de Poesia, em 1982, a título póstumo.* Campânula - Campânula (também chamada redoma) é um recipiente de metal ou de vidro em forma de sino, utilizado geralmente como equipamento de laboratórios de física e de botânica, para formar e manter o vácuo.

Reading this book is like standing in a whirlpool, feeling the water pull at you, trying to draw you into its vortex. This work is unnerving in its honesty and willingness to share the distressing details of a life that is running off the rails. The confusion and fear are palpable.There are tendencies towards depression that run through my family, and I have felt the cold fingers of depression laid on my forehead more than a few times. There, but for the grace of the universe, go I. It is a sobering thought.  Like Plath, I came as an inexperienced country girl to the city (though not nearly so large a city as New York). I had to find my way through the minefields of city life, university studies, social events, and eventually finding employment. Also like her, I could usually make high academic marks if I paid even a little bit of attention to a subject. Believe it or not, that is not helpful—someone who administered an aptitude test for me looked at the perfectly symmetrical marks that I had scored and said, “Oh my, you don’t know what you want to be when you grow up!” No kidding, that was why I was taking the blessed test! Like all the best oracles, it offered no certain advice. “You can go any direction you choose, but you will have to choose,” reported the tester. No help there with deciding where to aim myself; I might as well have consulted a fortune cookie.It’s hard to find good advice on life’s decisions: what employment would you enjoy, how will you know when you find a good life partner, is everyone else having as difficult a time as I am? We all have to manoeuver through them with minimal experience and hope for the best. I am grateful that I didn’t have to fight the black beast at the same time during that phase of my life. I appreciate the “female-ness” of this book—trying to deal with not being taken seriously as a potential employee, student, even as a patient. Knowing that you must appear “ladylike” in order to make a good impression and that your clothing choices can be more important that you are. The choices that we have to make around sexuality (especially back in the day when there was little reliable birth control available and women were still judged by their “purity”). The Bell Jar was written just as women were starting to strain against the straitjacket of the wife and mother role that they had been shoved into during the 1950s—Plath’s female voice seems startlingly honest for the time.The Bell Jar ends on what seems to me to be a hopeful note, stepping into the doctors’ office to be released from hospital. If only that feeling of hopefulness had held and Plath had been able to resist the pull of the grave—what might she have created?

È il mio primo approccio a Sylvia Plath e non è stato facile. La lettura di questo libro è stata disturbante, a tratti claustrofobica. Ho dovuto prendermi delle pause in alcuni passaggi, perché mi ha provocato uno strano malessere. È un libro straordinario, ma piange dolore e sofferenza. Mi ha fatto sentire appesantita, tolto il respiro, dato i brividi. Per alcune cose, e molto da lontano, mi ha fatto sentire compresa; per altre, mi ha lasciato addosso una sensazione di inquietudine.La scrittura della Plath è incredibilmente fluida: non soltanto perché rende la lettura scorrevole, ma perché muta insieme ad Esther stessa. Le immagini che accompagnano il romanzo hanno una grandissima potenza emotiva ed era da tantissimo che non sentivo un trasporto così intenso. Esther non è un personaggio facile con cui empatizzare, a volte mi è risultata addirittura incomprensibile nei suoi atteggiamenti. Eppure, la maggior parte delle volte, non solo mi sono sentita vicina a Esther, ma mi sono addirittura sentita Esther.A pieno titolo tra i miei preferiti."Vidi la mia vita protendere i suoi rami come il verde albero di fico del racconto.Dalla cima di ogni ramo, come un enorme fico purpureo, ammiccava e occhieggiava un futuro meraviglioso. Un fico simboleggiava un marito con una casa felice e dei bambini, un altro un celebre poeta, un altro un brillante professore universitario, un altro I. G., lo straordinario redattore, un altro ancora rappresentava l'Europa, l'Africa e il Sud America e uno era Constantin, Socrate, Attila e una schiera di altri innamorati dai nomi strani e dalle professioni eccentriche, un altro era una popolare campionessa olimpionica, e, al di là e al di sopra di tutti questi fichi, molti altri fichi c'erano che non potevo neppure scorgere. Mi vidi seduta sulla biforcazione di un ramo di questo albero, mentre morivo di fame, solo perché non sapevo decidermi a fare la mia scelta. Avrei voluto poterli scegliere tutti; ma scegliere voleva dire perdere tutti gli altri e, mentre sedevo là, incapace di decidermi, i fichi si raggrinzirono, diventarono neri e, l'uno dopo l'altro, caddero a terra ai miei piedi."

'Everything she said was like a secret voice speaking straight out of my own bones.'Plath speaks to me in a way that very few writers have ever managed to. I was mindful that I might find a fellow sufferer’s account triggering, but instead I was somewhat comforted by Plath’s ruthless stream of consciousness and waspish humour. It’s unsurprising given the highly autobiographical nature of the novel: she understands. The Bell Jar is a startlingly clear exposé of depression, the pressures of academia and gender expectations. I think we understand each other, Sylvia and me.This depiction of mental illness, or ‘insanity’ as it was so bluntly termed in the 60s, is as exquisite as it is disturbing. Plath’s voice is unparalleled in its bitterness, wit and originality. In the hands of less capable writers, mental illness can sometimes be glamourized or simplified whilst sufferers can be thoroughly misconstrued, sometimes damagingly so (Michelle Hodkin, I am looking at you), but Esther’s story is so startlingly accurate, it makes her actions and decisions feel almost rational. In this way Plath emulates so well how a mental health condition can completely envelop a person and obscure their judgement. I found this incredibly intense - but I can’t attribute that sentiment entirely to the novel alone. My prior knowledge of Plath’s life (namely her suicide by asphyxiation) rendered this exceptionally vivid for me in a way that it probably wouldn’t have been had I not always known that it was drawn from personal experience. Nevertheless, to read a first hand experience of mental ‘therapy’ in the 1960s, especially shock therapy, was absolutely terrifying... and yet simultaneously fascinating.This stunning piece is testimony to Plath’s exceptional ability to transmute traumatic experiences into new, lyrical formats which also have the power to give a poignant insight into a condition that can be so difficult to describe. Astounding.

This isn't the best work about insanity from a literary point of view, other than the fact that this is Sylvia Plath and might mirror her own life. I found it disconcerting, not knowing which parts to accept as reality and which parts to see as her perception of reality. The disconnect between her life in New York and the rest of the book is clear, and points to the beginnings of the moving toward irreconcilable madness.Isn't it strange how even in a disturbing book such as this, there can be feminist themes? Here is an interesting quote:“I saw my life branching out before me like the green fig tree in the story. From the tip of every branch, like a fat purple fig, a wonderful future beckoned and winked. One fig was a husband and a happy home and children, and another fig was a famous poet and another fig was a brilliant professor, and another fig was Ee Gee, the amazing editor, and another fig was Europe and Africa and South America, and another fig was Constantin and Socrates and Attila and a pack of other lovers with queer names and offbeat professions, and another fig was an Olympic lady crew champion, and beyond and above these figs were many more figs I couldn’t quite make out. I saw myself sitting in the crotch of this fig tree, starving to death, just because I couldn’t make up my mind which of the figs I would choose. I wanted each and every one of them, but choosing one meant losing all the rest, and, as I sat there, unable to decide, the figs began to wrinkle and go black, and, one by one, they plopped to the ground at my feet.”

“DyingIs an art, like everything else.I do it exceptionally well.I do it so it feels like hell.I do it so it feels real.I guess you could say I’ve a call.”Lady Lazarus by Sylvia PlathThe day Sylvia Plath took her own life by sticking her head in an oven was exceptionally frightful and isolating. She had spent the entire winter in isolation, in the grip of a long depressive cycle. I imagine a young mother, in her 30s, starting the day as usual: she would prepare bread and milk for her children and place it near their beds; then she’d open their windows and seal off the room with masking tape so the gas wouldn’t reach them because she’d decided to kill herself, but wouldn’t have allowed her children to die with her. The script of this imaginary play has already been written. As many will point out later, her actions were rational and decisive, so there is no way her suicide wasn’t intentional.But was it? Plath’s suicide note reads “Call Dr. Horder” with a phone number written at the bottom of it. She taped it to the children’s stroller and whatever the reason for what’ll follow, she wanted the note to be found. It could have been a cry for help more than a deliberate act of suicide, of course, as she was had already attempted suicide earlier in her life, by driving her car to a lake. Nowadays the case study of Sylvia Plath could be described in other words, synonymous with the term “suicidal artist”. She had written her first poem at the age of eight and was born a prodigy. Unfortunately, the genius poet’s journey to success was interrupted after numerous nervous breakdowns. A few days before she died, she wrote a poem: 
Edge“The Woman is perfected.Her DeadBody where is the smile of accomplishment,The inclusion of a Greek necessityFlows in the scrolls of her toga.Her bareFeet seem to be sayingWe have come so far, it is over.Each dead child coiled, a white serpent,One at each littlePitcher of milk, now emptyShe has foldedThem back into her body as petalsOf a rose close when the gardenStiffens and odours bleedFrom the sweet, deep throats of the night flowers.”
As I was writing this review, I stumbled across many negative opinions about Plath’s suicide, described as an act of selfishness, because she was a mother and her death also caused her son, Nick Hughes, to suffer from some critical issues and on top of that, from depression. There is also a controversy surrounding her husband but honestly, how can you point a finger towards such a delicate situation - that surely needed to be analyzed and treated with care - that potentially happened in a very difficult environment for both Ted Hughes and Sylvia Plath to live in? People are so superficial and that makes me mad. What I want to enlighten instead is a more intimate cry for help that for me comes directly out of Plath’s most famous work, The Bell Jar.
“The trouble was, I had been inadequate all along, I simply hadn’t thought about it.”
Plath had gone through some unpleasant adventures before publishing her masterpiece. She started a career at Mademoiselle magazine in Manhattan and due to the intense pressure she felt while working there, she started to be disillusioned about her career as a writer. She could hope for more, sure, but predatory men, food poisoning and heat waves made it difficult for her to keep the expectations high. She saw a psychiatrist and experienced electroshock therapy at Valley Head Hospital, outside Boston, which left her deep trauma. Her depression worsened, but then she recovered at McLean Hospital, and her mental health improved in early 1954. If you read The Bell Jar and what I described sounds familiar to you, it’s because Plath fictionalised all of her experiences in it. Plath speaks through the character of Esther, and her breakdowns and emotions feel real because Plath experienced them, but unlike me - who could see themselves unfortunately represented during the whole story - and many other people who struggle with depression, Plath is an artist at words and her descriptions come out exceptionally well. The result is a truthful, organic tale. However, The Bell Jar is a critique of the psychiatric system at the time of the author’s life and an attack on patriarchy that saw women’s ambition as neurotic. Both A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man by James Joyce and The Bell Jar treat their characters with a gentle satire, and aim to contain the modernist images of paralysis, decay and ultimately death and urban desolation. I love how the very first line of The Bell Jar hinted at Esther’s fate later in the book, and immediately set the tone: “It was a queer, sultry summer, the summer they electrocuted the Rosenbergs, and I didn’t know what I was doing in New York.” Plath breaks down Esther’s depression without the intention of glamorising it. Instead, she shows her protagonist the empathy the doctors lacked with Esther. The discouraging fate of a woman in a paternalistic psychiatric system is sided with another issue, the male gaze: “At last, obediently, like the mouth of a ventriloquist’s dummy, my own mouth started to quirk up.”The Bell Jar is also full of interesting symbolism. Of course, the most iconic is the fig tree that torments the protagonist. “From the tip of every branch, like a fat purple pig, a wonderful future beckoned and winked. One fig was a husband and a happy home and children, another fig was a famous poet and another fig was a brilliant professor…” Esther’s dilemma consists in a multitude of opportunities she could take in life, but society forces women to choose only one path because it’s impossible for them to be both a mother figure and career driven. “I saw myself sitting in the crotch of the fig-tree, starving to death, just because I couldn’t make up my mind which of the figs I would choose. I wanted each and every one of them, but choosing one meant losing all the rest, and, as I sat there, unable to decide, the figs began to wrinkle and go black, and, one by one, they plopped to the ground at my feet.” On another hand, the fig tree can be viewed as contradictory. Each branch represents a different choice. That means the fig tree could be perceived as a positive image, as it doesn’t really restrict the path a woman could choose to one. That said Esther finds the multitude of choices overwhelming. The question manifests as Esther’s inner turmoil: to be a woman or to be an individual? And does being a woman mean that you have to be a mother? The incapacity of choosing a path leads to starvation which, I guess, is another indicator for Esther’s unhealthy mentality.But, decontextualising the fig tree from its original context, it is still impressive for us because whether we are a woman or a man, there will be a time when we’ll have to choose what to do in life. It can happen shortly after graduating or we’ll find purpose later, growing older. In such a globalized world we live in, it can be overwhelming to just choose one path, hence why I hate the reductiveness of human life. In the end I found that for me the only way to dive into endless possibilities is by telling stories and making them as concrete as possible. I hope to become a director someday and the journey will indeed be just as difficult as choosing one fig out of the many branches on the fig tree. 
“I shut my eyes and all the world drops dead; I lift my eyes and all is born again.”
Sylvia Plath was ahead of her time when she spoke of mental illness. However, I wouldn’t say the same about racism and homophobia. But then again, not to justify anything, but I think (as a queer individual and non binary person) that you cannot judge an author without knowing of the context, both historical and societal, in which they lived in. Though I get that The Bell Jar has the danger of reaching just a certain, targeted, audience, instead of speaking to everyone. Mental illness is something we can all empathize with, because it’s something we can all potentially experience. Through the racist and homophobic commentary, Plath seeks to refer to white and heterosexual individuals who suffer from mental illness, or so it seemed to me. Whatever. I loved this book and hated it at the same time. It’s both a personal attack and a warm hug, a reminder that we are not alone in experiencing awful feelings. One thing that I noticed by going to therapy is that I have never been more dissociated with reality in my entire life; by living constantly in my thoughts, it’s easy to lose track of time and to forget what really matters. That we’re here, present. And nobody can change that. 4.5/5

За първи път ми се случи да чета книга с толкова много цитати, които казват прекалено много, че ако трябва да пиша цялостно ревю, ще е съставено 60% от тях.Отчаянието, в което потъва главната героиня, затворена в своя стъклен похлупак, е безумно. На пръв поглед нямах обяснение за състоянието й. Печелила е безброй награди, а сега и стипендия, която й дава възможността да види свят, или поне Ню Йорк. Има майка, която я е грижа за нея, млада е, има приятели, отличничка е по всички параграфи. На прага е да завърши колеж и да започне истинския си живот, а вместо това вижда само начини и причини да се депресира, да затрива предоставените й шансове. Книгата, обаче, не е депресираща сама по себе си. Напротив - показва ни колко лесно човек може да се отчужди, да се обрече сам на самота, абстрахирайки се напълно от околния свят, самонавивайки се в своята некадърност, безличност и безпътност. Показва го по такъв начин, че да се зарадваме на своето собствено положение, така че да сме благодарни за своя собствен живот, уверявайки ни, че може и по-зле.  Разбира се, в днешно време не отъждествяваме депресията с лабилната психика и не я "лекуваме" с електрошок, но все ще се намери някой, който вместо да се опита да ни помогне истински, да ни надене усмирителната риза, обявявайки ни за неспасяем случай.Нямаме нужда от външни манипулации, защото ние самите сме си напълно достатъчни, но ако в цялата каша се намеси некадърен психиатър, нещата определено няма да свършат добре. Много е важно да срещнем разбиране и подкрепа, и не само да ги срещнем, но и да ги приемем. А не да виждаме враг във всеки, който ни подава ръка, и най-накрая да се опитаме сами да си помогнем по най-егоистичния начин, който познава човека.

They say that there is a very fine line between genius and insanity and perhaps this novel is trying to show that. For all that we know medically, the brain is the organ we know least about. Why does it function in most people and yet in some, it decides to go in a path that is totally alien to the human spirit? I think Ms Plath was trying in this book so show that anyone can be a bit insane and how we deal with the insane moments in our lives makes the difference between normalcy and lunacy. Why is it that the heroine of this story, so filled with giftedness and the ability to be anything she wishes, finds that her one wish is to end the life she has been given? How very sad to see a woman of promise go down the road to insanity and like the rest of us feel that we sometimes are in a jar where we become specimens for someone else? Why is it that some have the ability to burst out of the jar and become something, while others remain confined in the jar and learn to hate themselves?

"To the person in the bell jar, blank and stopped as a dead baby, the world itself is the bad dream."I have realized something today. There are some books that I just cannot write a critical review of. Because they're not just books to me. They're not just great works of literature. They are so much more. This book is one of those. It's a book that I'll cherish all my life, I'm sure. Knowing depression as I now do, I'm really glad I read this. I have never been able to say for certain which book is my favorite. I guess I haven't really had a favorite book. I do now. I might try to write a critical review of it the way I write of other books, but I'm not sure if I would be able to do it justice, so we'll see if I end up writing one or not. Till then, all I can say is that it's my favorite.

Com um forte toque autobiográfico, Sylvia Plath nos apresenta um romance extremamente profundo e perturbador. A narrativa aborda a juventude de Esther e os acontecimentos que a levaram à internação em uma clínica psiquiátrica. Ao longo do livro, e do desenvolvimento da gravíssima depressão que acomete a protagonista, o leitor é sugado para dentro dos pensamentos e angústias da protagonista, acompanhando de perto a solidão de dentro da "redoma de vidro" em que passa a viver. Um livro que nos faz refletir muito, trazendo temas delicados como a depressão e o suicídio e, principalmente, sobre o doloroso processo que é crescer. Também fiquei impressionado com a escrita poética da autora. Nota: 10/10Leia mais resenhas em https://www.instagram.com/book.ster/

When I first started reading the book, I was not sure if I was going to like it, since I found Esther's personality annoying. However, after the reading the third chapter, I knew that I would definitely finish the book. Plath's writing style is fresh and clear, and Esther's personality is revealed to us through an engrossing narrative. Her matter of fact statements about different ways of committing suicide are unsettling, since we know that Sylvia Plath ended her own life. A remarkable book.

Esther Greenwood ist kein Charakter zum Gern haben. Esther ist apathisch, zynisch und depressiv. Man hat das Gefühl Esther ist außer Stande auch nur irgendeinem Menschen - auch nicht sich selbst - Zuneigung oder Liebe entgegenzubringen. Sie ist gefühlskalt gegenüber Menschen die ihr gegenüber Zuneigung empfinden, sie verletzt diese Menschen sogar.Man muss Esther aber auch nicht gern haben um sich, zumindest in Teilen, mit ihr identifizieren zu können, bzw. ihre Handlungen nachvollziehen zu können. Der Roman spielt in den 50ern, eine Zeit in der Frau sich zwischen Familie und Karriere entscheiden musste. Das ist heute auch oft genug noch der Fall, aber während dieses Bild heute (zumindest oberflächlich) unterstützt wird, war dieser Lebensentwurf damals noch nicht einmal in den Vorstellungen der Menschen vorhanden. Esther Greenwood möchte aber beides, einen tollen Job plus Mann und Kinder. Ihr stehen beide Optionen offen, da sie eine hervorragende Studentin ist und einen Verehrer hat. Sie vergleicht ihre Situation mit einem Feigenbaum, wobei jede Frucht eine andere Möglichkeit darstellt und während sie noch da steht und überlegt welche sie wählen soll, verschrumpeln die Feigen und fallen zu Boden. Bevor Esther sich falsch entscheidet, entscheidet sie sich lieber gar nicht. Sie wird apathisch und langsam aber stetig senkt sich eine Glasglocke über sie und schneidet sie von allen anderen Menschen ab. Sie empfindet diese Glasglocke als einen Fremdkörper den sie nicht kontrollieren kann. Selbst am Ende nachdem sich die Glasglocke wieder gehoben hat, spürt sie diese immer noch bedrohlich über sich hängen und weiß, dass die Glasglocke nie verschwinden wird und sich jederzeit wieder über sie herabsenken kann. Wie jeder relativ schnell erkennt, ist die Glasglocke nichts anderes als Depressionen. Wenn man ein bisschen über Sylvia Plath recherchiert, wird schnell klar, dass Die Glasglocke stark autobiographisch eingefärbt ist. Bei Wikipedia heißt es der Roman sei semiautobiographisch. Aus diesem Grund finde ich es fast unmöglich das Buch unabhängig von der Autorin zu betrachten. Das ist auch ein Grund weshalb ich das Geschriebene als realitätsgetreu annehme, auch wenn Esther's Perspektive mehr als nur einmal sehr fragwürdig erscheint. Ihre Sicht auf manche Personen will sich mir nicht ganz erschließen und ich frage mich inwieweit die Depression ihre Wahrnehmung verzerrt und ob Plath genau dies bezwecken wollte.Was der Roman meiner Meinung nach ebenfalls sehr gelungen darstellt, ist die extreme Oberflächlichkeit der Gesellschaft. So tut Esther's Mutter die Depressionen ihrer Tochter als bloße Verstimmungen ab, die sich durch Arbeit kurieren lassen und gibt ihr durch die Blume selbst die Schuld daran. Am Schluss sagt die Mutter, dass sie diesen Lebensabschnitt Esther's einfach vergessen und als bösen Traum ansehen sollen. Nur dass für Esther unter der Glasglocke alles außerhalb ein böser Traum ist.Die "Freundschaften" wirkten auf mich sehr aufgesetzt. Mal versteht man sich total gut mit der einen Freundin, dann findet man sie kurz darauf super ätzend und sehnt sich nach der anderen Freundin über die man vorher noch gelästert hat.Sehr bezeichnend für diese Oberflächlichkeit fand ich zwei Szenen. Eine in der Esther während eines Fototermins in Tränen ausbricht, worauf alle Personen den Raum verlassen sie "ausheulen" lassen und anschließend so tun als sei nichts gewesen. In der anderen Szene, werden alle Gewinnerinnen des Schreibwettbewerbs von einer angesagten Modezeitschrift zu einem schicken Dinner eingeladen und fangen sich eine Lebensmittelvergiftung durch verdorbenes Krabbenfleisch ein. Unter dem glitzernden Schein der Modewelt sitzt das faulende Krabbenfleisch und selbst Bilder von leckeren Gerichten werden geschönt.Ich mochte Sylvia Plath's Schreibstil, sie verwendet viele Metaphern die ich sehr gut nachvollziehen und verstehen konnte. Das ist nicht selbstverständlich, ich bin schnell überfordert von zu vielen Metaphern oder Symbolik, aber in diesem Fall fand ich jede einzelne sehr passend und gut umgesetzt. Das Buch ist so voller Bilder und Gedanken, dass ich hier nur einen Bruchteil angesprochen habe. Ich werde noch eine Weile über diesen dünnen Roman nachdenken müssen.

Dziewiętnastoletnia Esther Greenwood ma urodę, inteligencję, talent i plan na życie. Udaje jej się otrzymać miesięczny staż w Nowym Jorku w redakcji magazynu dla dziewcząt. Rozpoczyna nowe życie, tak bardzo różniące się od tego, które wiodła dotychczas – w biedzie, „na zabitej deskami prowincji”. Wielkie miasto stoi przed nią otworem. Ma okazję zaznać wolności, luksusu i chociaż przez jakiś czas prowadzić życie, wydawałoby się, jak ze snu. Jednak  dziewczyna mimo wszystko najchętniej leżałaby w swoim hotelowym łóżku. Nie ma na nic ochoty. Nie potrafi się odnaleźć w tej sytuacji. Nagle plan, który miała przez całe życie, okazuje się, że nie ma już znaczenia. Dobre oceny, które zdobywała przez cały czas, przestają się liczyć. W momencie kiedy jest na początku wybranej przez siebie życiowej drogi, nagle przestaje wiedzieć na czym jej tak naprawdę zależy i kim naprawdę jest. Nie może spać, jeść, czytać. Zamiast możliwości rozpoczęcia wymarzonej kariery, do Esther przychodzi załamanie.  Niecały miesiąc po wydaniu książki Sylvia Plath popełniła samobójstwo.  Książka Plath mnie zachwyciła. Nie wciągnęła. Ona wręcz pochłonęła mnie tak, że ciężko było mi ją odłożyć. Ogromny wpływ na to miało na pewno to, że nie miałam problemu z tym, żeby utożsamić się z główną bohaterką. Czytając o losach Esther, często miałam wrażenie, że czytam o sobie.  Bardzo poruszył mnie moment, w którym podczas rozmowy bohaterki z Jotką padła prośba „(…) ale niech mi pani powie, jakie są pani plany na przyszłość”. I nagle odpowiedź, która przez cały czas była dla dziewczyny oczywistością – stypendium, uczelnia, pisanie - z przerażeniem, nieświadomie, odpowiedziała „Sama nie wiem”. I dopiero po wypowiedzeniu tego na głos, uświadomiła sobie, że to prawda. W tym momencie musiałam się zatrzymać, żeby zastanowić się nad tym fragmentem i z równym przerażeniem co Esther, stwierdziłam, że rozumiem ją wręcz doskonale. Od dzieciaka zaplanowane życie, nagle stało się jedną wielką niewiadomą, a droga do przyszłości została drastycznie przerwana chorobą. Wszystko nagle straciło sens.  Esther wprawdzie zaczyna chodzić do psychiatry i rozpoczyna leczenie farmakologiczne. Nie daje ono jednak żadnych rezultatów. Do życia dziewczyny wkradają się coraz cięższe myśli samobójcze. Żyletka staje się jej nieodłącznym elementem. Niedziałające leczenie jest coraz bardziej frustrujące. Zaczynają się próby samobójcze. Jej choroba przybiera na tyle ciężki wymiar, że potrzebna jest hospitalizacja. Potem dzięki pewnej kobiecie Esther trafia do renomowanej, prywatnej kliniki, gdzie pod opieką doktora Gordona rozpoczyna najcięższą walkę jaką może toczyć człowiek – walkę o swoje życie. Walkę z najtrudniejszym przeciwnikiem – własnym umysłem, samym sobą.Odniosłam wrażenie, że dziewczyna toczy walkę sama ze sobą. Mimo chęci zabicia się, boi się śmierci. Jednak równie mocno boi się życia. Próbuje ze sobą skończyć, ale ostatecznie strach (a może głęboko ukryta iskierka nadziei na poprawę?) wygrywa.  Akcja dzieje się w latach pięćdziesiątych XX wieku. Wtedy rzeczy takie jak choroby psychiczne, psychiatria były jeszcze większym tematem tabu niż dzisiaj. Osobiście uważam, że w dzisiejszych czasach i tak o chorobach psychicznych mówi się zdecydowanie za mało i nadal pozostają one po części tym tematem tabu, jednak na pewno nie tak bardzo jak w czasach, w których dzieje się akcja powieści.  Automatycznie też po głowie zaczynają krążyć myśli, czy gdyby wiedza o chorobach psychicznych i psychiatrii była większa i nie byłby to temat tak przemilczany, Sylvia Plath przeżyłaby więcej niż zaledwie 30 lat? Czy mielibyśmy okazję przeczytać więcej wspaniałych dzieł, które mogłyby wypłynąć spod pióra autorki? Na te pytania niestety nigdy nie poznamy odpowiedzi.  Pozostaje jedynie mieć nadzieję, że o chorobach psychicznych zacznie się mówić tak, jak o chorobach fizycznych. I że życie nie będzie przerastało tylu wspaniałych osób - takich jak Sylvia Plath.  Lena Dunham pisze o książce „(…) Sylvia Plath była taka jak my. Tyle że nie miała na półce Szklanego klosza.” Uważam, że jest to idealne podsumowanie mojej opinii o „Szklanym kloszu”.

"I took a deep breath and listened to the old brag of my heart. I am, I am, I am.”
This book is a semi-autobiographical work, the only published novel we have from Sylvia Plath, firstly published under a pseudonym in 1963, and after her death, under her own name.major trigger warnings: suicide attempts, sexual assault, self-harm.There are several lenses to go about a review of this book, but all I think must emphasize how remarkable it is, and also say upfront what this book is about: suicide. There is no beating around this. Yes it talks about womanhood, yes it critiques the 50s, but this book is about suicide and major depression, and it feels strange the blurbs of the book don’t reflect that. I'm new to Sylvia’s writings but from what I’ve read, I think it was important for Plath to take hold of her own story and tell it, maybe control it through manipulating it as she wished, while looking back with more insight into what was happening to her, through the Bell Jar. I think, yes the book draws many many experiences from her real life, but to say the voice of this book is her own is a disservice to her writing power. It’s interesting that she took her own experiences and decided to tell them through this very obviously flawed character. Esther’s presence was so brilliantly achieved, that it becomes almost the main reason as to why some will dislike the book. It’s the best aspect of it but it can also draw away a lot of readers. More than anything, this book is important simply from being a full open window, a first hand telling of suicide ideation. The waves of depression are now more and more talked of and normalized but often times people don’t, or can’t really, understand what is the state of mind that leads to taking your own life. The suffering in this book is so intense and vivid, and told through such a lense of detachment and numbness, that you start understanding why it seems like there is no escape. The estrangement from oneself, the slow paralysis of feeling trapped and seeing life perish away and loved ones hurt — all contributing to this spiral that keeps descending and descending. The fact the book ended on a rather hopeful note is even more heart breaking considering the author committed suicide shortly after the publishing of the book. It was too soon, and just a few years later, her books would be greatly appreciated, and maybe medicine a bit more advanced and aware of treatments for her disease. The second lens is of course the subject of sex and feminism. The way the author recalled her experiences as an adolescent, the view of sex and men was extremely important then and continues to be now. We are not alone, and sexual assault continues to be frequent, unfortunately. These experiences need to be consistently written and talked about, even if they are so painful it physically hurt to read sometimes. I could say so much more about this story, this is not nearly enough, and I am just fresh out of reading it, I want to keep reading more about it! about Sylvia, and re-read this book, absolutely.

3.5 stars. "Bell jar" was a foreign term to me except as a book title. But what else it is, I had no inkling. I picture it as a glass dome, which might fit over a cake plate or a cheese platter. For Ms Plath it was a perfect depiction of what descends over a mentally ill person when s/he is beginning an episode of feeling trapped, isolated, and suicidal.With the book being based on Sylvia Plath's dark and brooding life, I wondered if writing about it -- reliving it in a sense -- was at all cathartic for her, or did it simply exacerbate her feelings of being stuck beneath the bell jar? I'd like to think it granted her some relief and gave her more time on earth to enjoy her life and children. But I doubt it. She seemed to be headed in the direction of suicide and that's where she landed (with her head in a kitchen oven). Sad to know -- and I only know because she wrote it in the book -- that she never wanted to get married, have children, or live as was expected of a woman of the 1950s, yet turned out that was exactly what she did. She also earned notoriety and respect as a writer, but was she ever happy? This book felt haunted by Ms Plath's ghost, circling above Esther, dictating her every thought, ready to drop the bell jar on her at any time. Esther's thinking and obsessing were quite different to the way my thoughts operate, so it took me some time to get used to it. Not being able to reread on an audiobook, Esther's descent into her breakdown seemed to come on rather suddenly and spun out of control quickly, or else I just didn't understand it. The use of electro- shock therapy was quite popular then and I don't understand that either. The story itself ended on a positive note with hope for the future, quickly debunked in the Afterword, however, with how her life ended.The writing: At first, while I was still trying to warm up to it, the prose seemed rambling and laden with words pulled straight out of a thesaurus, as if written for a professor grading a thesis. The writing improved page by page, chapter by chapter, and I admit to finally getting caught up in it.I didn't care much for (actress) Maggie Gyllenhaal's narration in the beginning, thinking she sounded young, immature, unemotional, and depressed. Then, duh, quickly realized that's exactly how she should sound portraying someone who is 19 and bi-polar. 'Twas an honorable portrayal. I just can't use the word "love" on this one, but it has haunted my thoughts for several days since finishing it.

Wow... I really did not like this book. I looked at some of the other reviews and again I just don't get what people loved so much about this book. I had very high expectations as " The Bell Jar" is known to all as a classic in the world of feminism literature and psychology. I am highly critical because of my background in psychology, but this books falls so much off the mark I can't understand the high praise. During a high school psychology class we were given a choice of novels to read and present on and " The Bell Jar" and "Sybil" were two of the books on the list. I struggled to figure out which book to read but finally settled on "Sybil". "Sybil" remains to this day my favorite book regarding psychological illness and treatment. So, I believe I made a really good decision because after finally reading " The Bell Jar" (many years removed from my high school psychology class and my work as a psychotherapist) I am highly disappointed. This novel is not well paced and more than 60% of the book is about the Esther Greenwood's life in NYC and college life. Only the very latter of the book deals with her subsequent "nervous breakdown" and time spent in the asylum. Unlike " Sybil" there was no in depth commentary on the treatment that Greenwood received besides the fact that she had shock treatments. There was no mention of diagnosis, of therapuetic modules used in psychotherapy or medication (besides insulin which as far as I know has never been sued for psychological treatment I could be wrong on this -- I never spent much time on the hx of psychopharmcology ) Although shock treatments were very popular during the time Mrs. Plath's wrote this novel, which most say is closely based on her own life experiences suffering from depression and anxiety (leading to her own suicide just a few years after this book's publication), she definitely would have been able to add more to this narrative of a young women's struggles with mental illness and her treatment in the 1950's.Skip this book -- Read Sybil!
